1.01Â  TITLE.
This code of ordinances shall be known and may be cited as the Code of
Ordinances of the City of Clear Lake, Iowa, 2003.
1.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
Where words and phrases used in this Code of Ordinances are defined in the Code
of Iowa, such definitions apply to their use in this Code of Ordinances unless
such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the Council
or repugnant to the context of the provision.Â  Other words and phrases used
herein have the following meanings, unless specifically defined otherwise in
another portion of this Code of Ordinances or unless such construction would be
inconsistent with the manifest intent of the Council or repugnant to the
context of the provision:
1.Â Â Â â€œAlleyâ€ means a public right-of-way, other than a street, affording
secondary means of access to abutting property.
2.Â Â Â â€œCityâ€ means the City of Clear Lake, Iowa.
3.Â Â Â â€œClerkâ€ means the city clerk of Clear Lake, Iowa.
4.Â Â Â â€œCodeâ€ means the specific chapter of this Code of Ordinances in which a
specific subject is covered and bears a descriptive title word (such as the
Building Code and/or a standard code adopted by reference).
5.Â Â Â â€œCode of Ordinancesâ€ means the Code of Ordinances of the City of Clear
Lake, Iowa, 2003.
6.Â Â Â â€œCouncilâ€ means the city council of Clear Lake, Iowa.
7.Â Â Â â€œCountyâ€ means Cerro Gordo County, Iowa.
8.Â Â Â â€œMayâ€ confers a power.
9.Â Â Â â€œMeasureâ€ means an ordinance, amendment, resolution or motion.
10.Â Â Â â€œMustâ€ states a requirement.
11.Â Â Â â€œOccupantâ€ or â€œtenant,â€ applied to a building or land, includes any
person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone
or with others.
12.Â Â Â â€œOrdinancesâ€ means the ordinances of the City of Clear Lake, Iowa, as
embodied in this Code of Ordinances, ordinances not repealed by the ordinance
adopting this Code of Ordinances, and those enacted hereafter.
13.Â Â Â â€œPersonâ€ means an individual, firm, partnership, domestic or foreign
corporation, company, association or joint stock association, trust, or other
legal entity, and includes a trustee, receiver, assignee, or similar
representative thereof, but does not include a governmental body.
14.Â Â Â â€œPublic wayâ€ includes any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway,
sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare.
15.Â Â Â â€œShallâ€ imposes a duty.
16.Â Â Â â€œSidewalkâ€ means that surfaced portion of the street between the edge of
the traveled way, surfacing, or curb line and the adjacent property line,
intended for the use of pedestrians.
17.Â Â Â â€œStateâ€ means the State of Iowa.
18.Â Â Â â€œStatutesâ€ or â€œlawsâ€ means the latest edition of the Code of Iowa, as
amended.
19.Â Â Â â€œStreetâ€ or â€œhighwayâ€ means the entire width between property lines of
every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use
of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic.
Words that are not defined in this Code of Ordinances or by the Code of Iowa
have their ordinary meaning unless such construction would be inconsistent with
the manifest intent of the Council, or repugnant to the context of the
provision.
1.03Â  CITY POWERS.
The City may, except as expressly limited by the Iowa Constitution, and if not
inconsistent with the laws of the Iowa General Assembly, exercise any power and
perform any function it deems appropriate to protect and preserve the rights,
privileges and property of the City and of its residents, and preserve and
improve the peace, safety, health, welfare, comfort and convenience of its
residents and each and every provision of this Code of Ordinances shall be
deemed to be in the exercise of the foregoing powers and the performance of the
foregoing functions.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.1)
1.04Â  INDEMNITY.
The applicant for any permit or license under this Code of Ordinances, by
making such application, assumes and agrees to pay for all injury to or death
of any person or persons whomsoever, and all loss of or damage to property
whatsoever, including all costs and expenses incident thereto, however arising
from or related to, directly, indirectly or remotely, the issuance of the
permit or license, or the doing of anything thereunder, or the failure of such
applicant, or the agents, employees or servants of such applicant, to abide by
or comply with any of the provisions of this Code of Ordinances or the terms
and conditions of such permit or license, and such applicant, by making such
application, forever agrees to indemnify the City and its officers, agents and
employees, and agrees to save them harmless from any and all claims, demands,
lawsuits or liability whatsoever for any loss, damage, injury or death,
including all costs and expenses incident thereto, by reason of the foregoing.Â 
The provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a part of any permit or
license issued under this Code of Ordinances or any other ordinance of the City
whether expressly recited therein or not.
1.05Â  PERSONAL INJURIES.
When action is brought against the City for personal injuries alleged to have
been caused by its negligence, the City may notify in writing any person by
whose negligence it claims the injury was caused.Â  The notice shall state the
pendency of the action, the name of the plaintiff, the name and location of the
court where the action is pending, a brief statement of the alleged facts from
which the cause arose, that the City believes that the person notified is
liable to it for any judgment rendered against the City, and asking the person
to appear and defend.Â  A judgment obtained in the suit is conclusive in any
action by the City against any person so notified, as to the existence of the
defect or other cause of the injury or damage, as to the liability of the City
to the plaintiff in the first named action, and as to the amount of the damage
or injury.Â  The City may maintain an action against the person notified to
recover the amount of the judgment together with all the expenses incurred by
the City in the suit.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.14)
1.06Â  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
In the construction of this Code of Ordinances, the rules of statutory
construction as set forth in Chapter 4 of the Code of Iowa shall be utilized to
ascertain the intent of the Council with the understanding that the term
â€œstatuteâ€ as used therein will be deemed to be synonymous with the term
â€œordinanceâ€ when applied to this Code of Ordinances.
1.07Â  EXTENSION OF AUTHORITY.
Whenever an officer or employee is required or authorized to do an act by a
provision of this Code of Ordinances, the provision shall be construed as
authorizing performance by a regular assistant, subordinate or a duly
authorized designee of said officer or employee.
1.08Â  AMENDMENTS.
All ordinances which amend, repeal or in any manner affect this Code of
Ordinances shall include proper reference to chapter, section, subsection or
paragraph to maintain an orderly codification of ordinances of the City.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.2)
1.09Â  CATCHLINES AND NOTES.
The catchlines of the several sections of the Code of Ordinances, titles,
headings (chapter, section and subsection), editorâ€™s notes, cross references
and State law references, unless set out in the body of the section itself,
contained in the Code of Ordinances, do not constitute any part of the law, and
are intended merely to indicate, explain, supplement or clarify the contents of
a section.
1.10Â  ALTERING CODE.
It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to change or amend by additions or
deletions, any part or portion of the Code of Ordinances, or to insert or
delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with the Code of
Ordinances in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City to be
misrepresented thereby.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 718.5)
1.11Â  SEVERABILITY.
If any section, provision or part of the Code of Ordinances is adjudged invalid
or unconstitutional, such adjudication will not affect the validity of the Code
of Ordinances as a whole or any section, provision or part thereof not adjudged
invalid or unconstitutional.
1.12Â  RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION.
Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any ordinance or whenever
there is reasonable cause to believe there exists an ordinance violation in any
building or upon any premises within the jurisdiction of the City, any
authorized official of the City, upon presentation of proper credentials, may
enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or
to perform any duty imposed upon such official by this Code of Ordinances.Â 
Except in emergency situations or when consent of the owner and/or occupant to
the inspection has otherwise been obtained, the City official shall give the
owner and/or occupant, if they can be located after reasonable effort, twenty-
four (24) hoursâ€™ written notice of the officialâ€™s intention to inspect.
1.13Â  WARRANTS.
If consent to enter upon or inspect any building, structure or property
pursuant to a municipal ordinance is withheld by any person having the lawful
right to exclude, the City officer or employee having the duty to enter upon or
conduct the inspection may apply to the Iowa District Court in and for the
County, pursuant to Section 808.14 of the Code of Iowa, for an administrative
search warrant.Â  No owner, operator or occupant or any other person having
charge, care or control of any dwelling unit, rooming unit, structure, building
or premises shall fail or neglect, after presentation of a search warrant, to
permit entry therein by the municipal officer or employee.
1.14Â  GENERAL STANDARDS FOR ACTION.
Whenever this Code of Ordinances grants any discretionary power to the Council
or any commission, board or officer or employee of the City and does not
specify standards to govern the exercise of the power, the power shall be
exercised in light of the following standard:Â  The discretionary power to
grant, deny or revoke any matter shall be considered in light of the facts and
circumstances then existing and as may be reasonably foreseeable, and due
consideration shall be given to the impact upon the public health, safety and
welfare, and the decision shall be that of a reasonably prudent person under
similar circumstances in the exercise of the police power.
1.15Â  STANDARD PENALTY.
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by this Code of Ordinances for
violation of any particular provision, section, or chapter, any person failing
to perform a duty required by this Code of Ordinances or otherwise violating
any provision of this Code of Ordinances or any rule or regulation adopted
herein by reference shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of $65.00. If
a court appearance is requested, shall upon conviction, be subject to a fine of
at least $65.00 but not to exceed $625.00.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.3[2])
(Ord. 852 - Aug. 20 Supp.)
CHAPTER 2

Â 
2.01Â  TITLE.
This chapter may be cited as the charter of the City of Clear Lake, Iowa. â€ 
Â 
Notes
â€â€  EDITORâ€™S NOTE:Â  Ordinance No. 379 adopting a charter for the City was passed and
  approved by the Council on July 1, 1975.
2.02Â  FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
The form of government of the City is the Mayor-Council form of government.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)
2.03Â  POWERS AND DUTIES.
The Council and Mayor and other City officers have such powers and shall
perform such duties as are authorized or required by State law and by the
ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the City.
2.04Â  NUMBER AND TERM OF COUNCIL.
The Council consists of two (2) Council Members elected at large and one (1)
Council Member from each of three (3) wards as established by this Code of
Ordinances, elected for overlapping terms of four (4) years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.2)
2.05Â  TERM OF MAYOR.
The Mayor is elected for a term of four (4) years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.2)
2.06Â  COPIES ON FILE.
The Clerk shall keep an official copy of the charter on file with the official
records of the Clerk and the Secretary of State, and shall keep copies of the
charter available at the Clerkâ€™s office for public inspection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.1)
CHAPTER 3
PRECINCTS AND WARDS

3.01Â  DEFINITIONS.
For the purposes of this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires:
1.Â Â Â "Annexed territory" means territory annexed to the City after census day.
2.Â Â Â "Census day" means April 1, 2010, the official date of the 2010 United
States Decennial Census.
3.Â Â Â "Commissioner of Elections" means the County Auditor of Cerro Gordo
County.
4.Â Â Â "Corporate limits" means the corporate limits of the City on census day.
The corporate limits do not embrace the annexed territories.
5.Â Â Â "Legislative district" means a district represented by a member of the
House of Representatives of the General Assembly of the State of Iowa, as
established by the legislature.
6.Â Â Â Points of the compass are approximate unless otherwise stated.
7.Â Â Â All names, boundaries, lines, features and fixtures are to be construed as
they existed on census day.
3.02Â  BOUNDARIES OF VOTING PRECINCTS.
1.Â Â Â The first precinct consists of that territory bounded by a line as
follows:
Beginning at the intersection of the north corporation limits and N. 8th
Street, which is also designated as County Highway S28; thence south on said N.
8th Street to its intersection with 14th Avenue N.; thence west on 14th Avenue
N. to its intersection with Buddy Holly Place; thence south on Buddy Holly
Place to its intersection with 10th Avenue N.; thence east on 10th Avenue N. to
its intersection with N. 6th Street; thence south on N. 6th Street to its
intersection with 4th Avenue N.; thence southwesterly on 4th Avenue N. to its
intersection with North Shore Drive; thence north on North Shore Drive to its
intersection with 5th Avenue N.; thence west on 5th Avenue N. to the shore of
Clear Lake; thence westerly along the shore of Clear Lake to the west corporate
limits of Clear Lake; thence north and east along the corporation limits to
place of beginning; and including the portion of Clear Lake within the City's
corporate limits, all of which is located in the 4th Congressional District.
2.Â Â Â The second precinct consists of that territory bounded by a line as
follows:
Beginning at a point where 5th Avenue N. intersects with the shore line of
Clear Lake, which is a point on the boundary of the first precinct, thence
northeasterly on 5th Avenue N. to its intersection with North Shore Drive;
thence south on North Shore Drive to its intersection with 4th Avenue N.;
thence northeasterly on 4th Avenue N. to its intersection with N. 6th Street;
thence north on N. 6th Street to its intersection with 10th Avenue N.; thence
east on 10th Avenue N. to its intersection with N. 10th Street; thence south on
N. 10th Street to its intersection with 1st Avenue N.; thence west on 1st
Avenue N. to its intersection with N. 8th Street; thence south on N. 8th Street
to its intersection with 1st Avenue S.; thence east on said 1st Avenue S. to
its intersection with S. 10th Street; thence south on S. 10th Street to its
intersection with 4th Avenue S.; thence east on said 4th Avenue S. to the east
Clear Lake corporate limits; thence south on the east corporate limits, which
is also designated as S. 56th Street, to its intersection with 12th Avenue S.;
thence west along the Clear Lake corporate limits on said 12th Avenue S. to its
intersection with S. 40th Street; thence south along the corporate limits on
said S. 40th Street to its intersection with 27th Avenue S.; thence west and
south along the corporate limits of Clear Lake to the shore of Clear Lake;
thence northerly along the shore of Clear Lake to the place of beginning, all
of which is located in the 41h Congressional District.
3.Â Â Â The third precinct consists of that territory bounded by a line as
follows:

Avenue N. to its intersection with Buddy Holly Place; thence south on Buddy
Holly Place to its intersection with 10th Avenue N.; thence east on 10th Avenue
N. to its intersection with N. 10th Street; thence south on N. 10th Street to

intersection with N. 8th Street; thence south on N. 8th Street to its

3.03Â  WARDS ESTABLISHED.
The City is divided into three (3) wards, as follows:
1.Â Â Â The first ward consists of the first precinct.
2.Â Â Â The second ward consists of the second precinct.

CHAPTER 4

4.01Â  MUNICIPAL INFRACTION.
A violation of this Code of Ordinances or any ordinance or code herein adopted
by reference or the omission or failure to perform any act or duty required by
the same, with the exception of those provisions specifically provided under
State law as a felony, an aggravated misdemeanor, or a serious misdemeanor, or
a simple misdemeanor under Chapters 687 through 747 of the Code of Iowa, is a
municipal infraction punishable by civil penalty as provided herein.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[3])
4.02Â  ENVIRONMENTAL VIOLATION.
A municipal infraction which is a violation of Chapter 455B of the Code of Iowa
or of a standard established by the City in consultation with the Department of
Natural Resources, or both, may be classified as an environmental violation.Â 
However, the provisions of this section shall not be applicable until the City
has offered to participate in informal negotiations regarding the violation or
to the following specific violations:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22 [1])
1.Â Â Â A violation arising from noncompliance with a pretreatment standard or
requirement referred to in 40 C.F.R. Â§403.8.
2.Â Â Â The discharge of airborne residue from grain, created by the handling,
drying or storing of grain, by a person not engaged in the industrial
production or manufacturing of grain products.
3.Â Â Â The discharge of airborne residue from grain, created by the handling,
drying or storing of grain, by a person engaged in such industrial production
or manufacturing if such discharge occurs from September 15 to January 15.
4.03Â  PENALTIES.
A municipal infraction is punishable by the following civil penalties:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22 [1])
1.Â Â Â Standard Civil Penalties.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â First Offense -Â  Not to exceed $500.00
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each Repeat Offense - Not to exceed $750.00
Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to exist constitutes a repeat
offense.
2.Â Â Â Special Civil Penalties.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A municipal infraction arising from noncompliance with a pretreatment
standard or requirement, referred to in 40 C.F.R. Â§403.8, by an industrial user
is punishable by a penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for each day a violation exists or continues.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A municipal infraction classified as an environmental violation is
punishable by a penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each occurrence.Â  However, an environmental violation is not subject to such
penalty if all of the following conditions are satisfied:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The violation results solely from conducting an initial startup,
cleaning, repairing, performing scheduled maintenance, testing, or conducting a
shutdown of either equipment causing the violation or the equipment designed to
reduce or eliminate the violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The City is notified of the violation within twenty-four (24) hours
from the time that the violation begins.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The violation does not continue in existence for more than eight
(8) hours.
4.04Â  CIVIL CITATIONS.
Any officer authorized by the City to enforce this Code of Ordinances may issue
a civil citation to a person who commits a municipal infraction.Â  The citation
may be served by personal service as provided in Rule of Civil Procedure 1.305,
by certified mail addressed to the defendant at defendantâ€™s last known mailing
address, return receipt requested, or by publication in the manner as provided
in Rule of Civil Procedure 1.310 and subject to the conditions of Rule of Civil
Procedure 1.311.Â  A copy of the citation shall be retained by the issuing
officer, and one copy shall be sent to the Clerk of the District Court.Â  The
citation shall serve as notification that a civil offense has been committed
and shall contain the following information:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22 [4])
1.Â Â Â The name and address of the defendant.
2.Â Â Â The name or description of the infraction attested to by the officer
issuing the citation.
3.Â Â Â The location and time of the infraction.
4.Â Â Â The amount of civil penalty to be assessed or the alternative relief
sought, or both.
5.Â Â Â The manner, location, and time in which the penalty may be paid.
6.Â Â Â The time and place of court appearance.
7.Â Â Â The penalty for failure to appear in court.
4.05Â  ALTERNATIVE RELIEF.
Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this chapter does not preclude the
City from seeking alternative relief from the court in the same action.Â  Such
alternative relief may include, but is not limited to, an order for abatement
or injunctive relief.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22 [8])
4.06Â  CRIMINAL PENALTIES.
This chapter does not preclude a peace officer from issuing a criminal citation
for a violation of this Code of Ordinances or regulation if criminal penalties
are also provided for the violation.Â  Nor does it preclude or limit the
authority of the City to enforce the provisions of this Code of Ordinances by
criminal sanctions or other lawful means.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[11])

in January of the first year of the term for which the officer was elected.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 63.1)
2.Â Â Â Prescribed Oath.Â  The prescribed oath is:Â  â€œI, (name), do solemnly swear
that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution

5.02Â  BONDS.

1.Â Â Â Required.Â  The Council shall provide by resolution for a surety bond or

5.06Â  MEETINGS.
All meetings of the Council, any board or commission, or any multi-membered
body formally and directly created by any of the foregoing bodies shall be held
in accordance with the following:
1.Â Â Â Notice of Meetings.Â  Reasonable notice, as defined by State law, of the
time, date and place of each meeting, and its tentative agenda shall be given.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.4)
2.Â Â Â Meetings Open.Â  All meetings shall be held in open session unless closed
sessions are held as expressly permitted by State law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.3)
3.Â Â Â Minutes.Â  Minutes shall be kept of all meetings showing the date, time and
place, the members present, and the action taken at each meeting.Â  The minutes
shall show the results of each vote taken and information sufficient to
indicate the vote of each member present.Â  The vote of each member present
shall be made public at the open session.Â  The minutes shall be public records
open to public inspection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.3)
4.Â Â Â Closed Session.Â  A closed session may be held only by affirmative vote of
either two-thirds of the body or all of the members present at the meeting and
in accordance with Chapter 21 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.5)
5.Â Â Â Cameras and Recorders.Â  The public may use cameras or recording devices at
any open session.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.7)
6.Â Â Â Electronic Meetings.Â  A meeting may be conducted by electronic means only
in circumstances where such a meeting in person is impossible or impractical
and then only in compliance with the provisions of Chapter 21 of the Code of
Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.8)
5.07Â  CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
A City officer or employee shall not have an interest, direct or indirect, in
any contract or job of work or material or the profits thereof or services to
be furnished or performed for the City, unless expressly permitted by law.Â  A
contract entered into in violation of this section is void.Â  The provisions of
this section do not apply to:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5)
1.Â Â Â Compensation of Officers.Â  The payment of lawful compensation of a City
officer or employee holding more than one City office or position, the holding
of which is not incompatible with another public office or is not prohibited by
law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[1])
2.Â Â Â Investment of Funds.Â  The designation of a bank or trust company as a
depository, paying agent, or for investment of funds.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[2])
3.Â Â Â City Treasurer.Â  An employee of a bank or trust company, who serves as
Treasurer of the City.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[3])
4.Â Â Â Stock Interests.Â  Contracts in which a City officer or employee has an
interest solely by reason of employment, or a stock interest of the kind
described in subsection 8 of this section, or both, if the contract is for
professional services not customarily awarded by competitive bid, if the
remuneration of employment will not be directly affected as a result of the
contract, and if the duties of employment do not directly involve the
procurement or preparation of any part of the contract.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[5])
5.Â Â Â Newspaper.Â  The designation of an official newspaper.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[6])
6.Â Â Â Existing Contracts.Â  A contract in which a City officer or employee has an
interest if the contract was made before the time the officer or employee was
elected or appointed, but the contract may not be renewed.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[7])
7.Â Â Â Volunteers.Â  Contracts with volunteer fire fighters or civil defense
volunteers.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[8])
8.Â Â Â Corporations.Â  A contract with a corporation in which a City officer or
employee has an interest by reason of stock holdings when less than five
percent (5%) of the outstanding stock of the corporation is owned or controlled
directly or indirectly by the officer or employee or the spouse or immediate
family of such officer or employee.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[9])
9.Â Â Â Contracts.Â  Contracts made by the City upon competitive bid in writing,
publicly invited and opened.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[4])
10.Â Â Â Cumulative Purchases.Â  Contracts not otherwise permitted by this section,
for the purchase of goods or services which benefit a City officer or employee,
if the purchases benefiting that officer or employee do not exceed a cumulative
total purchase price of fifteen hundred dollars ($1500.00) in a fiscal year.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[10])
11.Â Â Â Franchise Agreements.Â  Franchise agreements between the City and a
utility and contracts entered into by the City for the provision of essential
City utility services.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 362.5[12])
12.Â Â Â Dual Office Holding Prohibition.Â  It is prohibited as a matter of law for
an employee of the municipality of Clear Lake to hold elective public office as
a member of the governing body of the municipality of Clear Lake, while at the
same time continuing as an employee of the City of Clear Lake.
5.08Â  RESIGNATIONS.
An elected officer who wishes to resign may do so by submitting a resignation
in writing to the Clerk so that it shall be properly recorded and considered.Â 
A person who resigns from an elective office is not eligible for appointment to
the same office during the time for which the person was elected, if during
that time the compensation of the office has been increased.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[9])
5.09Â  REMOVAL OF APPOINTED OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
Except as otherwise provided by State or City law, all persons appointed to
City office or employment may be removed by the officer or body making the
appointment, but every such removal shall be by written order.Â  The order shall
give the reasons, be filed in the office of the Clerk, and a copy shall be sent
by certified mail to the person removed, who, upon request filed with the Clerk
within thirty (30) days after the date of mailing the copy, shall be granted a
public hearing before the Council on all issues connected with the removal.Â 
The hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days after the date the request is
filed, unless the person removed requests a later date.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.15)
5.10Â  VACANCIES.
A vacancy in an elective City office during a term of office shall be filled,
at the Councilâ€™s option, by one of the two following procedures:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13 [2])
1.Â Â Â Appointment.Â  By appointment following public notice by the remaining
members of the Council within forty (40) days after the vacancy occurs, except
that if the remaining members do not constitute a quorum of the full
membership, or if a petition is filed requesting an election, the Council shall
call a special election as provided by law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13 [2a])
2.Â Â Â Election.Â  By a special election held to fill the office for the remaining
balance of the unexpired term as provided by law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13 [2b])
5.11Â  GIFTS.
Except as otherwise provided in Chapter 68B of the Code of Iowa, a public
official, public employee or candidate, or that personâ€™s immediate family
member, shall not, directly or indirectly, accept or receive any gift or series
of gifts from a â€œrestricted donorâ€ as defined in Chapter 68B and a restricted
donor shall not, directly or indirectly, individually or jointly with one or
more other restricted donors, offer or make a gift or a series of gifts to a
public official, public employee or candidate.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 68B.22)
CHAPTER 6

6.01Â  NOMINATING METHOD TO BE USED.
All candidates for elective municipal offices shall be nominated under the
provisions of Chapter 45 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.3)
6.02Â  NOMINATIONS BY PETITION.
Nominations for elective municipal offices of the City may be made by
nomination paper or papers signed by not less than twenty-five (25) eligible
electors, residents of the City or ward.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 45.1)
6.03Â  ADDING NAME BY PETITION.
The name of a candidate placed upon the ballot by any other method than by
petition shall not be added by petition for the same office.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 45.2)
6.04Â  PREPARATION OF PETITION AND AFFIDAVIT.Â 
Nomination papers shall include a petition and an affidavit of candidacy.Â  The
petition and affidavit shall be substantially in the form prescribed by the
State Commissioner of Elections, shall include information required by the Code
of Iowa, and shall be signed in accordance with the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 45.3, 45.5 & 45.6)
6.05Â  FILING, PRESUMPTION, WITHDRAWALS, OBJECTIONS.
The time and place of filing nomination petitions, the presumption of validity
thereof, the right of a candidate so nominated to withdraw and the effect of
such withdrawal, and the right to object to the legal sufficiency of such
petitions, or to the eligibility of the candidate, shall be governed by the
appropriate provisions of Chapter 44 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 45.4)
6.06Â  PERSONS ELECTED.
The candidates who receive the greatest number of votes for each office on the
ballot are elected, to the extent necessary to fill the positions open.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.8[3])
CHAPTER 7

7.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and provide for rules and
regulations governing the management of the financial affairs of the City.
7.02Â  FINANCE OFFICER.
The City Administrator shall appoint a finance officer to serve as the finance
and accounting officer of the City.Â  The City Administrator and finance officer
shall be responsible for the administration of the provisions of this chapter.
7.03Â  CASH CONTROL.
To assure the proper accounting and safe custody of moneys the following shall
apply:
1.Â Â Â Deposit of Funds.Â  All moneys or fees collected for any purpose by any
City officer shall be deposited through the office of the City Administrator.Â 
If any said fees are due to an officer, they shall be paid to the officer by
check drawn by the City Administrator and approved by the Council only upon
such officerâ€™s making adequate reports relating thereto as required by law,
ordinance or Council directive.
2.Â Â Â Deposits and Investments.Â  All moneys belonging to the City shall be
promptly deposited in depositories selected by the Council in amounts not
exceeding the authorized depository limitation established by the Council or
invested in accordance with the Cityâ€™s written investment policy and State law,
including joint investments as authorized by Section 384.21 of the Code of
Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.21, 12B.10, 12C.1)
7.04Â  FUND CONTROL.
There shall be established and maintained separate and distinct funds in
accordance with the following:
1.Â Â Â Revenues.Â  All moneys received by the City shall be credited to the proper
fund as required by law, ordinance or resolution.
2.Â Â Â Expenditures.Â  No disbursement shall be made from a fund unless such
disbursement is authorized by law, ordinance or resolution, was properly
budgeted, and supported by a claim approved by the Council.
3.Â Â Â Emergency Fund.Â  No transfer may be made from any fund to the Emergency
Fund.
(IAC, 545-2.5 [384,388], Sec. 2.5[2])
4.Â Â Â Debt Service Fund.Â  Except where specifically prohibited by State law,
moneys may be transferred from any other City fund to the Debt Service Fund to
meet payments of principal and interest.Â  Such transfers must be authorized by
the original budget or a budget amendment.
(IAC, 545-2.5[384,388] Sec. 2.5[3])
5.Â Â Â Capital Improvements Reserve Fund.Â  Except where specifically prohibited
by State law, moneys may be transferred from any City fund to the Capital
Improvements Reserve Fund.Â  Such transfers must be authorized by the original
budget or a budget amendment.
(IAC, 545-2.5[384,388] Sec. 2.5[4])
6.Â Â Â Utility and Enterprise Funds.Â  A surplus in a Utility or Enterprise Fund
may be transferred to any other City fund, except the Emergency Fund and Road
Use Tax Funds, by resolution of the Council.Â  A surplus may exist only after
all required transfers have been made to any restricted accounts in accordance
with the terms and provisions of any revenue bonds or loan agreements relating
to the Utility or Enterprise Fund.Â  A surplus is defined as the cash balance in
the operating account or the unrestricted retained earnings calculated in
accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in excess of:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The amount of the expense of disbursements for operating and
maintaining the utility or enterprise for the preceding three (3) months, and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The amount necessary to make all required transfers to restricted
accounts for the succeeding three (3) months.
(IAC, 545-2.5[384,388], Sec. 2.5[5])
7.Â Â Â Balancing of Funds.Â  Fund accounts shall be reconciled at the close of
each month and a report thereof submitted to the Council.
7.05Â  OPERATING BUDGET PREPARATION.
The annual operating budget of the City shall be prepared in accordance with
the following:
1.Â Â Â Proposal Prepared.Â  The finance officer is responsible for preparation of
the annual budget detail, for review by the Mayor and Council and adoption by
the Council in accordance with directives of the Council.
2.Â Â Â Boards and Commissions.Â  All boards, commissions and other administrative
agencies of the City that are authorized to prepare and administer budgets must
submit their budget proposals to the City Administrator for inclusion in the
proposed City budget at such time and in such form as required by the Council.
3.Â Â Â Submission to Council.Â  The City Administrator shall submit the completed
budget proposal to the Council no later than February 15 of each year.
4.Â Â Â Council Review.Â  The Council shall review the proposed budget and may make
any adjustments in the budget which it deems appropriate before accepting such
proposal for publication, hearing and final adoption.
5.Â Â Â Notice of Hearing.Â  Upon adopting a proposed budget the Council shall set
a date for public hearing thereon to be held before March 15 and cause notice
of such hearing and a summary of the proposed budget to be published not less
than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days before the date established for
the hearing.Â  Proof of such publication must be filed with the County Auditor.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.16[3])
6.Â Â Â Copies of Budget on File.Â  Not less than twenty (20) days before the date
that the budget must be certified to the County Auditor and not less than ten
(10) days before the public hearing, the City Administrator shall make
available a sufficient number of copies of the detailed budget to meet the
requests of taxpayers and organizations, and have them available for
distribution at the offices of the Mayor and City Clerk and at the City
library.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.16[2])
7.Â Â Â Adoption and Certification.Â  After the hearing, the Council shall adopt,
by resolution, a budget for at least the next fiscal year and the City
Administrator shall certify the necessary tax levy for the next fiscal year to
the County Auditor and the County Board of Supervisors.Â  The tax levy certified
may be less than, but not more than, the amount estimated in the proposed
budget.Â  Two copies each of the detailed budget as adopted and of the tax
certificate must be transmitted to the County Auditor.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.16[5])
7.06Â  BUDGET AMENDMENTS.
A City budget finally adopted for the following fiscal year becomes effective
July 1 and constitutes the City appropriation for each program and purpose
specified therein until amended as provided by this section.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.18)
1.Â Â Â Program Increase.Â  Any increase in the amount appropriated to a program
must be prepared, adopted and subject to protest in the same manner as the
original budget.
(IAC, 545-2.2 [384, 388])
2.Â Â Â Program Transfer.Â  Any transfer of appropriation from one program to
another must be prepared, adopted and subject to protest in the same manner as
the original budget.
(IAC, 545-2.3 [384, 388])
3.Â Â Â Activity Transfer.Â  Any transfer of appropriation from one activity to
another activity within a program must be approved by resolution of the
Council.
(IAC, 545-2.4 [384, 388])
4.Â Â Â Administrative Transfers.Â  The City Administrator shall have the authority
to adjust, by transfer or otherwise, the appropriations allocated within a
specific activity without prior Council approval.
(IAC, 545-2.4 [384, 388])
7.07Â  ACCOUNTING.
The accounting records of the City shall consist of not less than the
following:
1.Â Â Â Books of Original Entry.Â  There shall be established and maintained books
of original entry to provide a chronological record of cash received and
disbursed.
2.Â Â Â General Ledger.Â  There shall be established and maintained a general
ledger controlling all cash transactions, budgetary accounts and for recording
unappropriated surpluses.
3.Â Â Â Checks.Â  Checks shall be prenumbered and signed by the City Administrator
and Mayor following Council approval, except as provided by subsection 5
hereof.
4.Â Â Â Budget Accounts.Â  There shall be established such individual accounts to
record receipts by source and expenditures by program and activity as will
provide adequate information and control for budgeting purposes as planned and
approved by the Council.Â  Each individual account shall be maintained within
its proper fund and so kept that receipts can be immediately and directly
compared with revenue estimates and expenditures can be related to the
authorizing appropriation.Â  No expenditure shall be posted except to the
appropriation for the function and purpose for which the expense was incurred.
5.Â Â Â Immediate Payment Authorized.Â  The Council may authorize the City
Administrator to issue checks for immediate payment of amounts due, which if
not paid promptly would result in loss of discount, penalty for late payment or
additional interest cost.Â  Any such payments made shall be reported to the
Council for review and approval with and in the same manner as other claims at
the next meeting following such payment.Â  Such authorization may include but is
not limited to payment of utility bills, contractual obligations, payroll and
bond principal and interest.
6.Â Â Â Utilities.Â  The City Administrator shall perform and be responsible for
accounting functions of the municipally owned utilities.
7.08Â  FINANCIAL REPORTS.
The finance officer shall prepare and file the following financial reports:
1.Â Â Â Monthly Reports.Â  There shall be submitted to the Council each month a
report showing the activity and status of each fund, program, sub-program and
activity for the preceding month.
2.Â Â Â Annual Report.Â  Not later than December first of each year there shall be
published an annual report containing a summary for the preceding fiscal year
of all collections and receipts, all accounts due the City, and all
expenditures, the current public debt of the City, and the legal debt limit of
the City for the current fiscal year.Â  A copy of the annual report must be
filed with the Auditor of State not later than December 1 of each year.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.22)

CHAPTER 8
INDUSTRIAL PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTIONS
Â 
8.01Â  Purpose                       8.06Â  Applications
8.02Â  Definitions                   8.07Â  Approval
8.03Â  Period of Partial Exemption   8.08Â  Exemption Repealed
8.04Â  Amounts Eligible for Exemption8.09Â  Dual Exemptions Prohibited
8.05Â  Limitations
Â 
8.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for a partial exemption from property
taxation of the actual value added to industrial real estate by the new
construction of industrial real estate, research-service facilities, warehouses
and distribution centers.
8.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œActual value addedâ€ means the actual value added as of the first year for
which the exemption is received.
2.Â Â Â â€œDistribution centerâ€ means a building or structure used primarily for the
storage of goods which are intended for subsequent shipment to retail outlets.Â 
Distribution center does not mean a building or structure used primarily to
store raw agricultural products, used primarily by a manufacturer to store
goods to be used in the manufacturing process, used primarily for the storage
of petroleum products, or used for the retail sale of goods.
3.Â Â Â â€œNew constructionâ€ means new buildings and structures and includes new
buildings and structures which are constructed as additions to existing
buildings and structures.Â  New construction does not include reconstruction of
an existing building or structure which does not constitute complete
replacement of an existing building or structure or refitting of an existing
building or structure unless the reconstruction of an existing building or
structure is required due to economic obsolescence and the reconstruction is
necessary to implement recognized industry standards for the manufacturing and
processing of specific products and the reconstruction is required for the
owner of the building or structure to continue competitively to manufacture or
process those products, which determination shall receive prior approval from
the City Council of the City upon the recommendation of the Iowa Department of
Economic Development.
4.Â Â Â â€œResearch-service facilitiesâ€ means a building or group of buildings
devoted primarily to research and development activities, including, but not
limited to, the design and production or manufacture of prototype products for
experimental use, and corporate research services which do not have a primary
purpose of providing on-site services to the public.
5.Â Â Â â€œWarehouseâ€ means a building or structure used as a public warehouse for
the storage of goods pursuant to Chapter 554, Article 7, of the Code of Iowa,
except that it does not mean a building or structure used primarily to store
raw agricultural products or from which goods are sold at retail.
8.03Â  PERIOD OF PARTIAL EXEMPTION.
The actual value added to industrial real estate by the new construction of
industrial real estate, research-service facilities, warehouses and
distribution centers is eligible to receive a partial exemption from taxation
for a period of five (5) years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.3)
8.04Â  AMOUNTS ELIGIBLE FOR EXEMPTION.
The amount of actual value added which is eligible to be exempt from taxation
shall be as follows:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.3)
1.Â Â Â For the first year, seventy-five percent (75%)
2.Â Â Â For the second year, sixty percent (60%)
3.Â Â Â For the third year, forty-five percent (45%)
4.Â Â Â For the fourth year, thirty percent (30%)
5.Â Â Â For the fifth year, fifteen percent (15%)
8.05Â  LIMITATIONS.
The granting of the exemption under this chapter for new construction
constituting complete replacement of an existing building or structure shall
not result in the assessed value of the industrial real estate being reduced
below the assessed value of the industrial real estate before the start of the
new construction added.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.3)
8.06Â  APPLICATIONS.
An application shall be filed for each project resulting in actual value added
for which an exemption is claimed.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.4)
1.Â Â Â The application for exemption shall be filed by the owner of the property
with the local assessor by February 1 of the assessment year in which the value
added is first assessed for taxation.
2.Â Â Â Applications for exemption shall be made on forms prescribed by the
Director of Revenue and Finance and shall contain information pertaining to the
nature of the improvement, its cost, and other information deemed necessary by
the Director of Revenue and Finance.
8.07Â  APPROVAL.
A person may submit a proposal to the City Council to receive prior approval
for eligibility for a tax exemption on new construction.Â  If the City Council
resolves to consider such proposal, it shall publish notice and hold a public
hearing thereon.Â  Thereafter, at least thirty days after such hearing the City
Council, by ordinance, may give its prior approval of a tax exemption for new
construction if the new construction is in conformance with City zoning.Â  Such
prior approval shall not entitle the owner to exemption from taxation until the
new construction has been completed and found to be qualified real estate.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.4)
8.08Â  EXEMPTION REPEALED.
When in the opinion of the City Council continuation of the exemption granted
by this chapter ceases to be of benefit to the City, the City Council may
repeal this chapter, but all existing exemptions shall continue until their
expiration.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.5)
8.09Â  DUAL EXEMPTIONS PROHIBITED.
A property tax exemption under this chapter shall not be granted if the
property for which the exemption is claimed has received any other property tax
exemption authorized by law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 427B.6)

CHAPTER 9
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTION
Â 
9.01Â  Purpose    9.03Â  Eligibility
9.02Â  Definitions9.04Â  Application
Â 
9.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for a property tax exemption for
shell buildings constructed by community development organizations for
speculative purposes in accordance with Section 427.1 of the Code of Iowa.
9.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œCommunity development organizationâ€ means a City organization or a multi-
community group formed for one or more of the following purposes:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To promote, stimulate, develop, and advance the business prosperity and
economic welfare of the community, area, or region and its citizens.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To encourage and assist the location of new business and industry.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â To rehabilitate and assist existing business and industry.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â To stimulate and assist in the expansion of business activity.
For purposes of this definition, a community development organization must have
at least fifteen (15) members with representation from the government at the
level or levels corresponding to the community development organizationâ€™s area
of operation; a private sector lending institution; a community organization in
the area; business in the area; and private citizens in the community.
2.Â Â Â â€œNew constructionâ€ means new buildings or structures and includes new
buildings or structures which are constructed as additions to existing
buildings or structures.Â  â€œNew constructionâ€ also includes reconstruction or
renovation of an existing building or structure which constitutes complete
replacement of an existing building or structure or refitting of an existing
building or structure, if the reconstruction or renovation of the existing
building or structure is required due to economic obsolescence, if the
reconstruction or renovation is necessary to implement recognized industry
standards for the manufacturing or processing of products, and the
reconstruction or renovation is required in order to competitively manufacture
or process products or for community development organizations to market a
building or structure as a speculative shell building, which determination must
receive prior approval from the Council.
3.Â Â Â â€œSpeculative shell buildingâ€ means a building or structure owned and
constructed or reconstructed by a community development organizationÂ  without a
tenant or buyer for the purpose of attracting an employer or user which will
complete the building to the employerâ€™s or userâ€™s specification for
manufacturing, processing, or warehousing the employerâ€™s or userâ€™s product
line.
9.03Â  ELIGIBILITY.
The new construction of shell buildings, or the portion of the value added to
buildings being reconstructed or renovated in order to become speculative shell
buildings, by the community development organization is eligible for property
tax exemption commencing the assessment year in which the building is first
assessed or in which the reconstruction or renovation first adds value.Â  The
exemption shall continue until the property is leased or sold or until
terminated by ordinance of the Council.Â  Eligibility for an exemption as a
speculative shell building shall be determined as of January 1 of the
assessment year.
9.04Â  APPLICATION.
An application shall be filed with the local assessor for each project for
which an exemption is claimed in accordance with Section 427B.4 of the Code of
Iowa.

15.01Â  TERM OF OFFICE.
The Mayor is elected for a term of four (4) years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.2)
15.02Â  POWERS AND DUTIES.
The powers and duties of the Mayor are as follows:
1.Â Â Â Chief Executive Officer.Â  Act as the chief executive officer of the City
and presiding officer of the Council, supervise all departments of the City,
except for supervisory duties delegated to the City Administrator.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[1])
2.Â Â Â Proclamation of Emergency.Â  Have authority to take command of the police
and govern the City by proclamation, upon making a determination that a time of
emergency or public danger exists.Â  Within the City limits, the Mayor has all
the powers conferred upon the Sheriff to suppress disorders.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[2])
3.Â Â Â Special Meetings.Â  Call special meetings of the Council when the Mayor
deems such meetings necessary to the interests of the City.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[1])
4.Â Â Â Mayorâ€™s Veto.Â  Sign, veto or take no action on an ordinance, amendment or
resolution passed by the Council.Â  The Mayor may veto an ordinance, amendment
or resolution within fourteen days after passage.Â  The Mayor shall explain the
reasons for the veto in a written message to the Council at the time of the
veto.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.5 & 380.6[2])
5.Â Â Â Reports to Council.Â  Make such oral or written reports to the Council as
required.Â  These reports shall concern municipal affairs generally, the
municipal departments, and recommendations suitable for Council action.
6.Â Â Â Negotiations.Â  Represent the City in all negotiations properly entered
into in accordance with law or ordinance.Â  The Mayor shall not represent the
City where this duty is specifically delegated to another officer by law,
ordinance, or Council direction.
7.Â Â Â Contracts.Â  Whenever authorized by the Council, sign contracts on behalf
of the City.
8.Â Â Â Professional Services.Â  Upon order of the Council, secure for the City
such specialized and professional services not already available to the City.Â 
In executing the order of the Council, the Mayor shall act in accordance with
the Code of Ordinances and the laws of the State.
9.Â Â Â Licenses and Permits.Â  Sign all licenses and permits which have been
granted by the Council, except those designated by law or ordinance to be
issued by another municipal officer.
10.Â Â Â Nuisances.Â  Issue written order for removal, at public expense, any
nuisance for which no person can be found responsible and liable.
11.Â Â Â Absentee Officer.Â  Make appropriate provision that duties of any absentee
officer be carried on during such absence.
15.03Â  APPOINTMENTS.
The Mayor shall appoint the Mayor Pro Tem and the Mayor also appoints, with
Council approval, the following officials:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)
1.Â Â Â Library Board of Trustees
2.Â Â Â Parks and Recreation Board
3.Â Â Â Police Chief
4.Â Â Â Plumbing and Electrical Examining Board
5.Â Â Â Zoning Board of Adjustment
15.04Â  COMPENSATION.

payable monthly.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
15.05Â  VOTING.
The Mayor is not a member of the Council and shall not vote as a member of the

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)

17.01Â  NUMBER AND TERM OF COUNCIL.
The Council consists of two (2) Council Members elected at large and one
Council Member from each of three (3) wards as established by the Code of
Ordinances, elected for overlapping terms of four (4) years.
17.02Â  POWERS AND DUTIES.
The powers and duties of the Council include, but are not limited to the
following:
1.Â Â Â General.
All powers of the City are vested in the Council except as otherwise provided
by law or ordinance.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1])
2.Â Â Â Wards.Â  By ordinance, the Council may divide the City into wards based
upon population, change the boundaries of wards, eliminate wards or create new
wards.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[7])
3.Â Â Â Fiscal Authority.Â  The Council shall apportion and appropriate all funds,
and audit and allow all bills, accounts, payrolls and claims, and order payment
thereof.Â  It shall make all assessments for the cost of street improvements,
sidewalks, sewers and other work, improvement or repairs which may be specially
assessed.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1], 384.16 & 384.38 [1])
4.Â Â Â Public Improvements.Â  The Council shall make all orders for the
construction of any improvements, bridges or buildings.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1])
5.Â Â Â Contracts.Â  The Council shall make or authorize the making of all
contracts.Â  No contract shall bind or be obligatory upon the City unless
adopted by resolution of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.100)
6.Â Â Â Employees.Â  The Council shall authorize, by resolution, the number,
duties, term of office and compensation of employees or officers not otherwise
provided for by State law or the Code of Ordinances.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
7.Â Â Â Setting Compensation for Elected Officers.Â  By ordinance, the Council
shall prescribe the compensation of the Mayor, Council members, and other
elected City officers, but a change in the compensation of the Mayor does not
become effective during the term in which the change is adopted, and the
Council shall not adopt such an ordinance changing the compensation of any
elected officer during the months of November and December in the year of a
regular City election.Â  A change in the compensation of Council members becomes
effective for all Council members at the beginning of the term of the Council
members elected at the election next following the change in compensation.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
17.03Â  EXERCISE OF POWER.
The Council shall exercise a power only by the passage of a motion, a
resolution, an amendment or an ordinance in the following manner:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.3[1])
1.Â Â Â Action by Council.Â  Passage of an ordinance, amendment or resolution
requires a majority vote of all of the members of the Council.Â  Passage of a
motion requires a majority vote of a quorum of the Council.Â  A resolution must
be passed to spend public funds in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) on any one project, or to accept public improvements and
facilities upon their completion.Â  Each Council memberâ€™s vote on a measure must
be recorded.Â  A measure which fails to receive sufficient votes for passage
shall be considered defeated.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.4)
2.Â Â Â Overriding Mayorâ€™s Veto.Â  Within thirty (30) days after the Mayorâ€™s veto,
the Council may pass the measure again by a vote of not less than two-thirds of
all of the members of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[2])
3.Â Â Â Measures Become Effective.Â  Measures passed by the Council become
effective in one of the following ways:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An ordinance or amendment signed by the Mayor becomes effective when
the ordinance or a summary of the ordinance is published, unless a subsequent
effective date is provided within the ordinance or amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1a])
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A resolution signed by the Mayor becomes effective immediately upon
signing.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1b])
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A motion becomes effective immediately upon passage of the motion by
the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1c])
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If the Mayor vetoes an ordinance, amendment or resolution and the
Council repasses the measure after the Mayorâ€™s veto, a resolution becomes
effective immediately upon repassage, and an ordinance or amendment becomes a
law when the ordinance or a summary of the ordinance is published, unless a
subsequent effective date is provided within the ordinance or amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[2])
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If the Mayor takes no action on an ordinance, amendment or resolution,
a resolution becomes effective fourteen (14) days after the date of passage,
and an ordinance or amendment becomes law when the ordinance or a summary of
the ordinance is published, but not sooner than fourteen (14) days after the
date of passage, unless a subsequent effective date is provided within the
ordinance or amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[3])
â€œAll of the members of the Councilâ€ refers to all of the seats of the Council
including a vacant seat and a seat where the member is absent, but does not
include a seat where the Council member declines to vote by reason of a
conflict of interest.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.4)
17.04Â  COUNCIL MEETINGS.
Procedures for giving notice of meetings of the Council and other provisions

(Ord. 835 - Feb. 18 Supp.)
2.Â Â Â Special Meetings.Â  Special meetings shall be held upon call of the Mayor

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[5])
3.Â Â Â Quorum.Â  A majority of all Council members is a quorum.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[1])
4.Â Â Â Rules of Procedure.Â  The Council shall determine its own rules and
maintain records of its proceedings.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[5])
5.Â Â Â Compelling Attendance.Â  Any three (3) members of the Council can compel
the attendance of the absent members at any regular, adjourned or duly called

The Council shall appoint the following officials and prescribe their powers,

1.Â Â Â City Clerk

3.Â Â Â City Administrator

2.Â Â Â Effective January 1, 2014, the salary of the members of the City Council

2.Â Â Â Custody.Â  Have custody and be responsible for the safekeeping of all

specifically directed by law or ordinance.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
3.Â Â Â Maintenance.Â  Maintain all City records and documents, or accurate
reproductions, for at least five (5) years except that ordinances, resolutions,
Council proceedings, records and documents, or accurate reproductions, relating
to the issuance, cancellation, transfer, redemption or replacement of public
bonds or obligations shall be kept for at least eleven (11) years following the
final maturity of the bonds or obligations.Â  Ordinances, resolutions, Council
proceedings, records and documents, or accurate reproductions, relating to real
property transactions shall be maintained permanently.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[3 & 5])
4.Â Â Â Provide Copy.Â  Furnish upon request to any municipal officer a copy of any
record, paper or public document under the Clerkâ€™s control when it may be

ordinance and Code of Ordinances are required to be attested by the affixing of
the seal.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4 & 5] and 380.7[5])
5.Â Â Â Filing of Communications.Â  Keep and file all communications and petitions
directed to the Council or to the City generally.Â  The Clerk shall endorse

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
18.09Â  ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS.

18.12Â  ELECTIONS.

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.6)
2.Â Â Â Accept the nomination petition of a candidate for a City office for filing

18.13Â  CITY SEAL.

1.Â Â Â Custody of Funds.Â  Be responsible for the safe custody of all funds of the

3.Â Â Â Record Receipts.Â  Keep an accurate record of all money or securities

4.Â Â Â Record Disbursements.Â  Keep an accurate account of all disbursements,

5.Â Â Â Special Assessments.Â  Keep a separate account of all money received by the

6.Â Â Â Deposit Funds.Â  Upon receipt of moneys to be held in the Treasurerâ€™s

7.Â Â Â Reconciliation.Â  Reconcile depository statements with the Treasurerâ€™s

8.Â Â Â Debt Service.Â  Keep a register of all bonds outstanding and record all
payments of interest and principal.
9.Â Â Â Other Duties.Â  Perform such other duties as specified by the Council by

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
20.03Â  POWER OF ATTORNEY.

20.10Â  RECORD KEEPING.

20.11Â  REPRESENTATION OF CITY EMPLOYEES.

before any court or tribunal for the purely private benefit of said officer or
employee.Â  The City Attorney shall, however, if directed by the Council, appear

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 670.8)

21.02Â  ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSIBILITY.
The City Administrator is directly responsible to the Council for the

responsible to the City Administrator.Â  All departmental activity requiring the
attention of the Council shall be brought before the Council by the City

coordinated through the City Administrator.
21.03Â  POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
The powers and duties of the City Administrator include the following:
1.Â Â Â Attend Council meetings to receive direction from the Council and also to
provide input to agenda items;
2.Â Â Â Administer City policies as established by the Council;
3.Â Â Â Make a continuous study of City government operating procedures,

4.Â Â Â Administer the Cityâ€™s annual operating budget;
5.Â Â Â Supervise the Cityâ€™s administrative policies and procedures including

6.Â Â Â Keep the Mayor and Council informed on the progress of its programs and

7.Â Â Â Coordinate and direct all City services provided through the various

8.Â Â Â Make recommendations on the employment, promotions, and the termination of

9.Â Â Â Study possible joint administrative arrangements with independent boards
and commissions such as the Library Board, the Parks and Recreation Board, and
the Planning and Zoning Commission, and make recommendations for such
arrangements as are mutually acceptable;
10.Â Â Â Transfer an employee from one department to another on a temporary basis;
11.Â Â Â Represent the City in direct contact with the citizens, and serve as
public relations officer of the City, regarding complaints, misunderstandings
and suggestions pertaining to any employee, department or service of the City;
12.Â Â Â Supervise all City purchasing; approve capital and repair expenditures up
to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for operational needs and up
to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for emergency needs;
13.Â Â Â In the absence of the City Clerk perform all duties of the City Clerk as
may be required by the Code of Iowa and this Code;
14.Â Â Â Negotiate and administer labor contracts;
15.Â Â Â Attend meetings and seminars as the City representative as directed by
the Council to improve operations of the City;
16.Â Â Â Perform such other duties as may be directed by the Council.

23.01Â  PUBLIC LIBRARY.
The public library for the City is known as the Clear Lake Public Library.Â  It
is referred to in this chapter as the Library.
23.02Â  LIBRARY TRUSTEES.
The Board of Trustees of the Library, hereinafter referred to as the Board,
consists of six (6) resident members and one nonresident member.Â  All resident
members are to be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the Council.Â  The
nonresident member is to be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the
County Board of Supervisors.
23.03Â  QUALIFICATIONS OF TRUSTEES.
All resident members of the Board shall be bona fide citizens and residents of
the City.Â  The nonresident member of the Board shall be a bona fide citizen and
resident of the unincorporated County.Â  Members shall be over the age of
eighteen (18) years.
23.04Â  ORGANIZATION OF THE BOARD.
The organization of the Board shall be as follows:
1.Â Â Â Term of Office.Â  All appointments to the Board shall be for six (6) years,
except to fill vacancies.Â  Each term shall commence on July 1.Â  Appointments
shall be made every two (2) years of one-third (1/3) the total number or as
near as possible, to stagger the terms.Â  No member shall be appointed for more
than two (2) consecutive terms or serve more than twelve (12) consecutive
years.
2.Â Â Â Vacancies.Â  The position of any resident Trustee shall be vacated if such
member moves permanently from the City.Â  The position of a nonresident Trustee
shall be vacated if such member moves permanently from the County or into the
City.Â  The position of any Trustee shall be deemed vacated if such member is
absent from six (6) consecutive regular meetings of the Board, except in the
case of sickness or temporary absence from the City or County.Â  Vacancies in
the Board shall be filled in the same manner as an original appointment except
that the new Trustee shall fill out the unexpired term for which the
appointment is made.
3.Â Â Â Compensation.Â  Trustees shall receive no compensation for their services.
23.05Â  POWERS AND DUTIES.
The Board shall have and exercise the following powers and duties:
1.Â Â Â Officers.Â  To meet and elect from its members a President, a Secretary,
and such other officers as it deems necessary.
2.Â Â Â Physical Plant.Â  To have charge, control and supervision of the Library,
its appurtenances, fixtures and rooms containing the same.
3.Â Â Â Charge of Affairs.Â  To direct and control all affairs of the Library.
4.Â Â Â Hiring of Personnel.Â  To employ a librarian, and authorize the librarian
to employ such assistants and employees as may be necessary for the proper
management of the Library, and fix their compensation; provided, however, that
prior to such employment, the compensation of the librarian, assistants and
employees shall have been fixed and approved by a majority of the members of
the Board voting in favor thereof.
5.Â Â Â Removal of Personnel.Â  To remove the librarian, by a two-thirds vote of
the Board, and provide procedures for the removal of the assistants or
employees for misdemeanor, incompetence or inattention to duty, subject
however, to the provisions of Chapter 35C of the Code of Iowa.
6.Â Â Â Purchases.Â  To authorize the librarian to select, and make purchases of
books, pamphlets, magazines, periodicals, papers, maps, journals, other Library
materials, furniture, fixtures, stationery and supplies for the Library within
budgetary limits set by the Board.
7.Â Â Â Use by Nonresidents.Â  To authorize the use of the Library by nonresidents
and to fix charges therefor unless a contract for free service exists.
8.Â Â Â Rules and Regulations.Â  To make and adopt, amend, modify or repeal rules
and regulations, not inconsistent with this Code of Ordinances and the law, for
the care, use, government and management of the Library and the business of the
Board, fixing and enforcing penalties for violations.
9.Â Â Â Expenditures.Â  To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all funds
allocated for Library purposes by the Council, and of all moneys available by
gift or otherwise for the erection of Library buildings, and of all other
moneys belonging to the Library including fines and rentals collected under the
rules of the Board.
10.Â Â Â Gifts.Â  To accept gifts of real property, personal property, or mixed
property, and devises and bequests, including trust funds; to take the title to
said property in the name of the Library; to execute deeds and bills of sale
for the conveyance of said property; and to expend the funds received by them
from such gifts, for the improvement of the Library.
11.Â Â Â Enforce the Performance of Conditions on Gifts.Â  To enforce the
performance of conditions on gifts, donations, devises and bequests accepted by
the City on behalf of the Library.
(Code of Iowa, Ch. 661)
12.Â Â Â Record of Proceedings.Â  To keep a record of its proceedings.
13.Â Â Â County Historical Association.Â  To have authority to make agreements with
the local County historical association where such exists, and to set apart the
necessary room and to care for such articles as may come into the possession of
the association.Â  The Trustees are further authorized to purchase necessary
receptacles and materials for the preservation and protection of such articles
as are in their judgment of a historical and educational nature and pay for the
same out of funds allocated for Library purposes.
23.06Â  CONTRACTING WITH OTHER LIBRARIES.
The Board has power to contract with other libraries in accordance with the
following:
1.Â Â Â Contracting.Â  The Board may contract with any other boards of trustees of
free public libraries, with any other city, school corporation, private or
semiprivate organization, institution of higher learning, township, or County,
or with the trustees of any County library district for the use of the Library
by their respective residents.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 392.5 & Ch. 28E)
2.Â Â Â Termination.Â  Such a contract may be terminated at any time by mutual
consent of the contracting parties.Â  It also may be terminated by a majority
vote of the electors represented by either of the contracting parties.Â  Such a
termination proposition shall be submitted to the electors by the governing
body of a contracting party on a written petition of not less than five percent
(5%) in number of the electors who voted for governor in the territory of the
contracting party at the last general election.Â  The petition must be presented
to the governing body not less than forty (40) days before the election.Â  The
proposition may be submitted at any election provided by law that is held in
the territory of the party seeking to terminate the contract.
23.07Â  NONRESIDENT USE.
The Board may authorize the use of the Library by persons not residents of the
City or County in any one or more of the following ways:
1.Â Â Â Lending.Â  By lending the books or other materials of the Library to
nonresidents on the same terms and conditions as to residents of the City, or
County, or upon payment of a special nonresident Library fee.
2.Â Â Â Depository.Â  By establishing depositories of Library books or other
materials to be loaned to nonresidents.
3.Â Â Â Bookmobiles.Â  By establishing bookmobiles or a traveling library so that
books or other Library materials may be loaned to nonresidents.
4.Â Â Â Branch Library.Â  By establishing branch libraries for lending books or
other Library materials to nonresidents.
23.08Â  EXPENDITURES.
All money appropriated by the Council for the operation and maintenance of the
Library shall be set aside in an account for the Library.Â  Expenditures shall
be paid for only on orders of the Board, signed by its President and Secretary.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.20 & 392.5)
23.09Â  ANNUAL REPORT.
The Board shall make a report to the Council immediately after the close of the
fiscal year.Â  This report shall contain statements as to the condition of the
Library, the number of books added, the number circulated, the amount of fines
collected, and the amount of money expended in the maintenance of the Library
during the year, together with such further information as may be required by
the Council.
23.10Â  INJURY TO BOOKS OR PROPERTY.
It is unlawful for a person willfully, maliciously or wantonly to tear, deface,
mutilate, injure or destroy, in whole or in part, any newspaper, periodical,
book, map, pamphlet, chart, picture or other property belonging to the Library
or reading room.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
23.11Â  THEFT.
No person shall take possession or control of property of the Library with the
intent to deprive the Library thereof.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 714.1)
23.12Â  NOTICE POSTED.
There shall be posted in clear public view within the Library notices informing
the public of the following:
1.Â Â Â Failure To Return.Â  Failure to return Library materials for two (2) months
or more after the date the person agreed to return the Library materials, or
failure to return Library equipment for one (1) month or more after the date
the person agreed to return the Library equipment, is evidence of intent to
deprive the owner, provided a reasonable attempt, including the mailing by
restricted certified mail of notice that such material or equipment is overdue
and criminal actions will be taken, has been made to reclaim the materials or
equipment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 714.5)
2.Â Â Â Detention and Search.Â  Persons concealing Library materials may be
detained and searched pursuant to law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 808.12)

2.Â Â Â Adopt Rules and Regulations.Â  The Commission shall adopt such rules and

3.Â Â Â Zoning.Â  The Commission shall have and exercise all the powers and duties

4.Â Â Â Recommendations of Improvements.Â  No statuary, memorial or work of art in

5.Â Â Â Review and Comment on Plats.Â  All plans, plats, or re-plats of subdivision

6.Â Â Â Review and Comment of Street and Park Improvements.Â  No plan for any

8.Â Â Â Limitation on Entering Contracts.Â  The Commission shall have no power to

9.Â Â Â Annual Report.Â  The Commission shall each year make a report to the Mayor

25.01Â  PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD CREATED.
A Parks and Recreation Advisory Board is hereby created to advise the Council
on the needed facilities to provide open space such as parks, playgrounds and
community facilities for other forms of recreation.Â  It shall also plan and
oversee City programs and encourage other programs to enhance the leisure time
activities of the City's residents of all ages.
25.02Â  BOARD ORGANIZATION.
The Board shall consist of five (5) members, all residents of the City,
appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the Council, for overlapping terms
of three (3) years.Â  No member shall be appointed for more than two (2)
consecutive terms.Â  The Board shall annually choose from its membership a
Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and Secretary.Â  Members shall serve without
compensation, but may receive reimbursement for expenses incurred in the
performance of their duties.Â  A vacancy shall be filled by appointment.Â  If the
appointed member serves for more than one-half a term, this shall be considered
as a full term with regard to the limitation of two consecutive terms.Â  If the
appointed member served for less than half a term, it shall not be counted as a
full term for the purpose of limiting service to no more than two consecutive
terms.
25.03Â  DUTIES OF THE BOARD.
Subject to the approval of the Council, the Board shall plan the City's parks
and recreational programs and care for, supervise, control and improve such
parks and programs.Â  The Board has the power to make rules and regulations for
the use of parks or other recreational facilities or for the conduct of
recreation programs, subject to the approval of the rules by the Council.Â  Such
rules shall be either posted on the facility or otherwise publicized in a
manner to provide adequate notice to the using public.Â  Violation of a rule or
regulation so posted or publicized may be cause for denial of use of the
facility or if it is a violation of this Code of Ordinances may be prosecuted
as a simple misdemeanor.
25.04Â  REPORTS.
The Board shall make reports to the Council of its activities from time to time
as it deems advisable, or upon Council request.Â  Its revenues and expenditures
shall be reported monthly by the Clerk in the manner of other departmental
expenditures, and a copy shall be provided to each member of the Board and in
the Clerk's report to the Council.
25.05Â  PARKS AND RECREATION DIRECTOR.
The Parks and Recreation Director shall assume such duties as established in
the job description approved by the City Administrator and the Council.Â  The
Parks and Recreation Director shall be advised by and work with the Board, but
shall be under the direct supervision of the City Administrator.

26.01Â  Â  PURPOSE.
The City Council of the City of Clear lake deems it in the best interest and
the general welfare of the citizens and residents of the City of Clear Lake to
be advised as to water quality and environmental issues within the Clear Lake
Watershed and to encourage the protection and preservation of the Clear Lake
Watershed.
26.02Â  Â  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
The Clear Lake Watershed Advisory Board shall be composed of the following
members, whose representative's appointment shall be confirmed by the Clear
Lake City Council:Â  Cerro Gordo County Board of Supervisors (1); Cerro Gordo
County Soil & Water Conservation District Board of Trustees (1); Hancock County
Soil & Water Conservation District Board of Trustees (1); Clear Lake City
Council (1); Ventura City Council (1); the Association for the Preservation of
Clear Lake (1); and the Clear Lake Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors (1).
1.Â Â Â Term of Office.Â  Duly appointed Advisory Board Members shall serve a term
of 3 years, except that the initial appointments shall be so staggered that the
terms of no more than 2 members of the membership expire each year.
2.Â Â Â Expiration of Term.Â  Advisory Board members shall serve on a calendar year
basis from January 1st to December 31st.
3.Â Â Â Liaison Member.Â  The City of Clear Lake Public Works Director, City of

4.Â Â Â Meetings.Â  The Board shall meet monthly.
26.03Â  Â  CHAIRMAN; COMPENSATION.
The Chairperson of the Board shall be elected by the Board at their first
meeting held in each calendar year. Board members shall receive no compensation
for their service.
26.04Â  Â  POWERS & DUTIES.
It shall be the duty and responsibility of the Clear Lake Watershed Advisory
Board to:
1.Â Â Â Study, investigate, counsel, and advise the political subdivisions and
non-profit organizations of the Clear Lake Watershed on any matter which
affects the aesthetics, visibility, or user friendliness of the lake watershed.
2.Â Â Â Advise the political subdivisions and non-profit organizations of the
Clear Lake Watershed on any matter which affects water quality or the fish or
waterfowl populations of the Clear Lake Watershed.
26.05Â  Â  ANNUAL REPORT.
The Board shall keep records of its meetings and activities and shall make an
annual report to the Clear Lake City Council and any other outside funding
organizations. Minutes of each meeting shall be forwarded to all political
subdivisions and non-profits organizations with membership on the board.

30.01Â  DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
The police department of the City is established to provide for the

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 80B.11)
