90.01Â  DEFINITIONS.
The following terms are defined for use in the chapters in this Code of
Ordinances pertaining to the Water Service System:
1.Â Â Â â€œCombined service accountâ€ means a customer service account for the
provision of two or more utility services.
2.Â Â Â â€œCustomerâ€ means, in addition to any person receiving water service from
the City, the owner of the property served, and as between such parties the
duties, responsibilities, liabilities and obligations hereinafter imposed shall
be joint and several.
3.Â Â Â â€œSuperintendentâ€ means the Superintendent of the City water system or any
duly authorized assistant, agent or representative.
4.Â Â Â â€œWater mainâ€ means a water supply pipe provided for public or community
use.
5.Â Â Â â€œWater service pipeâ€ means the pipe from the water main to the building
served.
6.Â Â Â â€œWater systemâ€ or â€œwater worksâ€ means all public facilities for securing,
collecting, storing, pumping, treating and distributing water.
90.02Â  SUPERINTENDENTâ€™S DUTIES.
The Superintendent shall supervise the installation of water service pipes and
their connection to the water main and enforce all regulations pertaining to
water services in the City in accordance with this chapter.Â  This chapter shall
apply to all replacements of existing water service pipes as well as to new
ones.Â  The Superintendent shall make such rules, not in conflict with the
provisions of this chapter, as may be needed for the detailed operation of the
water system, subject to the approval of the Council.Â  In the event of an
emergency the Superintendent may make temporary rules for the protection of the
system until due consideration by the Council may be had.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
90.03Â Â Â Â MANDATORY CONNECTIONS.
The owners of any houses, buildings or structures used for human occupancy,
employment or use, situated within the City and abutting on any street, alley
or right-of-way in which there is located a public water main are hereby
required to connect such facilities to the Cityâ€™s public water system in
accordance with the provisions of these Water Service chapters within sixty
(60) days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that said public
water main is located within two hundred (200) feet of the property line of
such owner.Â  Billing for water service will begin the date of official notice
to connect to the public water system and the property owner shall be billed
the minimum service charge each month until connection is made.
90.04Â  ABANDONED CONNECTIONS.
If a building is destroyed or removed and no building permit is issued to
rebuild within six (6) months, the property owner shall remove the service line
from the water main at the expense of the owner.Â  If the owner fails to remove
same, the Superintendent may employ such plumbers, excavators or other
personnel that may be needed to make the removal and the persons employed shall
have the right to make such removal on either public or private property and
the property owner shall be billed for the charges.Â  If such charges are not
paid within thirty (30) days after presentation, the Clerk shall certify the
same to the County Treasurer for collection with and in the same manner as
property taxes.Â  If a destroyed, removed or damaged building is to be rebuilt
or remodeled, the service line may remain after inspection by the
Superintendent and written approval to use the service line is given by the
Superintendent.
90.05Â  APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.
Before any person makes a connection with the public water system, an
application for service must be made to the City.Â  The application for service
shall include the address of the property, the name of the property owner, the
name and address of the person who will do the work, and the general uses of
the water.Â  The property owner shall complete installation and connection of
the service line to the public water system within sixty (60) days after the
application for service, except that when such time period is inequitable or
unfair due to conditions beyond the control of the property owner, an extension
of time within which to complete the work may be granted.
90.06Â  CONNECTION CHARGE.
The person who makes the application for service shall pay to the City a
connection charge in accordance with the following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
1.Â Â Â Three-fourths (Â¾) inch service - $50.00.
2.Â Â Â One (1) inch service - $60.00.
3.Â Â Â One and one-half (1 Â½) inch service - $80.00.
4.Â Â Â Two (2) inch service and larger - $100.00.
5.Â Â Â In multiple dwellings there shall be a service charge of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each service connection, whether a metered or non-metered
connection or regardless of the number of service lines.
90.07Â  COMPLIANCE WITH PLUMBING CODE.
The installation of any water service pipe and any connection with the water
system shall comply with all pertinent and applicable provisions, whether
regulatory, procedural or enforcement provisions, of Division 4, Plumbing Rules
and Regulations, of the State Building Code.
90.08Â  PLUMBER OR EXCAVATOR REQUIRED.
All installations of water service pipes and connections to the water system
shall be made by a licensed plumber or excavator, and a plumber or excavator
license may be suspended or revoked for violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter.
90.09Â  TAPPING MAINS.
All taps into the water main shall be made by or under the direct supervision
of the Superintendent and in accord with the following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
1.Â Â Â Independent Services.Â  No more than one house, building or premises shall
be supplied from one tap unless special written permission is obtained from the
Superintendent and unless provision is made so that each house, building or
premises may be shut off independently of the other.
2.Â Â Â Sizes and Location of Taps.Â  All mains four (4) inches or less in diameter
shall receive no larger than a three-fourths (3/4) inch tap.Â  All mains six (6)
inches or larger in diameter shall receive no larger than a one inch tap.Â 
Where a larger connection than a one inch tap is desired, two (2) or more small
taps or saddles, or other appropriate device, shall be used, as the
Superintendent shall order.Â  All taps in the mains shall be made in the top
half of the pipe, at least eighteen (18) inches apart.Â  No main shall be tapped
nearer than two (2) feet of the joint in the main.
3.Â Â Â Corporation Stop.Â  A brass corporation stop, of the pattern and weight
approved by the Superintendent, shall be inserted in every tap in the main.Â 
The corporation stop in the main shall be of the same size as the service pipe.
4.Â Â Â Location Record.Â  An accurate and dimensional sketch showing the exact
location of the tap shall be filed with the Superintendent in such form as the
Superintendent shall require.
90.10Â  INSTALLATION OR REPLACEMENT OF WATER SERVICE PIPE.
Water service pipes two (2) inches or less in diameter shall be Type K copper
from the main to the meter setting.Â  Water service pipes four (4) inches or
larger in diameter shall be ductile iron pipe or DR18 (C900) PVC from the main
to the meter setting.Â  Pipe must be laid sufficiently waving, and to such
depth, as to prevent rupture from settlement or freezing.Â  A tracer wire shall
be installed running parallel with the pipe on all new and replacement water
service lines.Â  Service lines presently in use and made of materials other than
specified herein shall be replaced by the property owner when, in the opinion
of the Superintendent, such lines have become unfit for further use or if the
lines contain hazardous material (e.g., lead).Â  All service pipes shall run
directly from the water main to the property served and no service pipes shall
be installed across lots or buildings to adjoining premises.
90.11Â  RESPONSIBILITY FOR WATER SERVICE PIPE.
All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection and maintenance
of the water service pipe from the main to the building served, including the
curb valve, shall be borne by the owner.Â  The owner shall indemnify the City
from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation or maintenance of said water service pipe.
90.12Â  FAILURE TO MAINTAIN.
When any portion of the water service pipe which is the responsibility of the
property owner becomes defective or creates a nuisance and the owner fails to
correct the same the City may employ such plumbers, excavators or other
personnel that may be needed to make the repairs and the persons or firms
employed shall have the right to make such repairs on either public or private
property.Â  The property owner shall be billed for the charges and if the bill
is not paid within thirty (30) days after presentation, the Clerk shall certify
the bill to the County Treasurer for collection with and in the same manner as
property taxes.Â  Provided, however, that when repairs are needed to any
nonworking curb valve the City and property owner may enter into a special
assessment agreement.Â  The City shall determine the interest rate and each such
agreement shall be approved by the Council and filed with the County Treasurer.
90.13Â  CURB VALVE.
There shall be installed within the public right-of-way a main shut-off valve
on the water service pipe of a pattern approved by the Superintendent.Â  The
shut-off valve shall be constructed to be visible and even with the pavement or
ground.
90.14Â  INTERIOR VALVE.
There shall be installed a shut-off valve on every service pipe inside the
building as close to the entrance of the pipe within the building as possible
and so located that the water can be shut off conveniently.Â  Where one service
pipe supplies more than one customer within the building, there shall be
separate valves for each such customer so that service may be shut off for one
without interfering with service to the others.
90.15Â  INSPECTION AND APPROVAL.
All water service pipes and their connections to the water system must be
inspected and approved in writing by the Superintendent before they are
covered, and the Superintendent shall keep a record of such approvals.Â  If the
Superintendent refuses to approve the work, the plumber or property owner must
proceed immediately to correct the work.Â  Every person who uses or intends to
use the municipal water system shall permit the Superintendent to enter the
premises to inspect or make necessary alterations or repairs at all reasonable
hours and on proof of authority.
90.16Â  COMPLETION BY THE CITY.
Should any excavation be left open or only partly refilled for twenty-four (24)
hours after the water service pipe is installed and connected with the water
system, or should the work be improperly done, the City shall have the right to
finish or correct the work, and the Council shall assess the costs to the
property owner.Â  Such assessment may be collected with and in the same manner
as general property taxes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3a & h])
90.17Â  SHUTTING OFF WATER SUPPLY.
The Superintendent may shut off the supply of water to any customer because of
any violation of the regulations contained in these Water Service System
chapters that is not being contested in good faith.Â  The supply shall not be
turned on again until all violations have been corrected and the Superintendent
has ordered the water to be turned on.
90.18Â  OPERATION OF CURB VALVE, MAIN LINE VALVE AND HYDRANTS.
It is unlawful for any person, unless specifically authorized by the City, to
turn water on or off at the curb valve or main line valve or to open or attempt
to draw water from any fire hydrant for any purpose whatsoever.
90.19Â  CITY LIABILITY LIMITED.
The City shall not be responsible to any person for any damage or injury
resulting from or because of the use of City water, operation of waterworks,
pressure of mains, pipes or equipment, breaking of or injury to any mains or
other equipment used with City water or through failure of supply or arising
from shutting off or turning on water, or in any part of the administration of
the waterworks.
90.20Â  CONTROL OF WATER SUPPLY.
Whenever in the judgment of the Council it becomes necessary to conserve the
water supply in the public interest, a resolution may be adopted to:
1.Â Â Â Regulate during certain hours or on certain days of the week, the water
that may be used for car and vehicle washing, watering lawns, gardens, or other
similar uses, or prohibit the use of water for any such purposes for such time
as the Council may determine;
2.Â Â Â Regulate the amount of water that any customer may use on any particular
day or for any period of time and specify the purposes for which water may be
used by any customer.
90.21Â  PRIVATE WELLS.
No person shall drill or cause to be drilled any private well in the City
without first making written application to the Council and obtaining a permit
to do so.
90.22Â  EASEMENTS.
Each customer shall grant or convey or shall cause to be granted or conveyed to
the City a permanent easement and right-of-way across any property owned or
controlled by the customer wherever said easement or right-of-way is necessary
for the public water system.Â  The Superintendent and other duly authorized
employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification shall be
permitted to enter all private properties through which the City holds an
easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, repair, and
maintenance of any portion of the public water system lying within said
easement.Â  The City shall not be responsible to any person for any damage or
injury to any landscaping, fences, or other encroachment in any easement area.
90.23Â  UNDERGROUND IMPROVEMENTS.
The City may include underground water, sewer, gas or electrical connections to
the street or property line for private property as a part of a public
improvement, or the City may order the property owner to make, repair, or
relocate such connections by publication of a notice once each week for two
consecutive weeks in the manner provided by Section 362.3 of the Code of Iowa,
and if the order is not complied with at the end of thirty days after the date
of the first publication, the City may cause the work to be done and assess the
cost against the property served by the connection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.40)
CHAPTER 91
WATER METERS
Â 
91.01Â  Purpose                          91.08Â  Right of Entry
91.02Â  Water Use Metered                91.09Â  Meter Installation Fee
91.03Â  Fire Sprinkler Systems- Exception91.10Â  Irrigation Meters

Â 
91.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to encourage the conservation of water and
facilitate the equitable distribution of charges for water service among
customers.
91.02Â  WATER USE METERED.
All water furnished customers shall be measured through meters furnished by the
City and installed by a licensed plumber.
91.03Â  FIRE SPRINKLER SYSTEMS - EXCEPTION.
Fire sprinkler systems may be connected to water mains by direct connection
without meters under the direct supervision of the Superintendent.Â  No open
connection can be incorporated in the system, and there shall be no valves
except a main control valve at the entrance to the building which must be
sealed open.
91.04Â  LOCATION OF METERS.
All meters shall be so located that they are easily accessible to meter readers
and repairmen and protected from freezing.Â  All meters shall be equipped with a
remote reader except that the Superintendent may waive this requirement for
business and commercial premises.
91.05Â  METER SETTING.
The property owner shall provide all necessary piping and fittings for proper
setting of the meter including a valve on the inlet side of the meter.Â  Meter
pits may be used only upon approval of the Superintendent and shall be of a
design and construction approved by the Superintendent.
91.06Â  METER COSTS.
The full cost of any meter larger than that required for a single-family
residence shall be paid to the City by the property owner or customer prior to
the installation of any such meter by the City, or, at the sole option of the
City, the property owner or customer may be required to purchase and install
such meter in accordance with requirements established by the City.
91.07Â  METER REPAIRS.
Whenever a water meter owned by the City is found to be out of order the
Superintendent shall have it repaired.Â  If it is found that damage to the meter
has occurred due to the carelessness or negligence of the customer or property
owner, or the meter is not owned by the City, then the property owner shall be
liable for the cost of repairs.
91.08Â  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
The Superintendent shall be permitted to enter the premises of any customer at
any reasonable time to read, remove, or change a meter orÂ  to examine pipes,
fixtures, or the manner in which water is used.
91.09Â  METER INSTALLATION FEE.
Effective July 1, 2008 the property owner shall pay an installation fee of one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each new installation of a water meter to a
three-fourths inch (Â¾") line.Â  Effective July 1, 2009, and on each successive
July 1 thereafter, the meter installation fee shall be increased automatically
by three percent (3%) or an amount equal to the twelve month percent change to
the increase in the Consumer Price Index-All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) for the
preceding month of March, whichever is the lesser amount.Â  Such meter is to
remain the property of the City.Â  The property owner shall pay an upgrade fee
of twenty-eight dollars ($28.00) to upgrade a meter that does not have an
outside remote reader to a radio read meter.Â  The property owner shall pay an
upgrade fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to upgrade a meter that has an odometer
style reader to a radio read meter.
91.10Â  IRRIGATION METERS.
An irrigation meter may also be installed to measure water that is not disposed
of through the public sanitary sewer system.Â  The water measured by an
irrigation meter may include water for swimming pools, watering yards, watering
gardens or other similar uses.Â  The following regulations apply to irrigation
meters:
1.Â Â Â Irrigation meters shall be installed not more than four (4) feet from the
prime meter and shall be installed parallel to the prime meter.
2.Â Â Â Any request for the installation of an irrigation meter shall be directed
to the Superintendent.Â  The Superintendent shall review the request and make a
determination that the separate line will not discharge into the sanitary sewer
system of the City.
3.Â Â Â A City-approved backflow preventer must be installed after the irrigation
meter to protect against contamination of the water system.
4.Â Â Â The irrigation meter must be installed horizontal to the floor with the
arrow of the meter being in the direction of the flow of water to the outside.
5.Â Â Â No underground irrigation systems are allowed in the public right-of-way.
The City will furnish the meter and the meter must be installed by a licensed
plumber.Â  The full cost of the meter and a one hundred dollar ($100.00) deposit
shall be paid by the customer or property owner prior to the installation of
the meter.Â  Sewer service charges shall not apply to the water measure by the
irrigation meter.
91.11Â  WATER FOR CONSTRUCTION USE.
Water for building construction purposes shall be furnished by meter
measurement only after suitable deposit has been made (the minimum deposit
being $10.00 and the amount to be determined by the City, depending upon the
size of the construction work contemplated.)Â  All water for building or
construction purposes must pass through one and the same meter.
91.12Â  MULTI-FAMILY DWELLINGS.
Each individual dwelling unit in any multi-family dwelling constructed after
the effective date of the 2003 Code of Ordinances shall be served by a separate
water meter.Â  All meters in the multi-family dwelling shall be installed in a
meter bank and each individual dwelling unit must have a separate shutoff
valve.
91.13Â  METER TESTING.
The City shall have access to all water meters at any reasonable time for the
purpose of inspecting or testing a meter.Â  The City shall test the meter of any
customer upon written request submitted to the Superintendent.Â  If the meter is
found not to be over two percent (2%) fast, the customer shall pay a testing
charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) which, if not paid at the time of testing,
shall be charged to the customerâ€™s utility bill.Â  If the meter is found to be
more than two percent (2%) fast the City shall test and adjust the meter at no
charge to the customer.
91.14Â  METER READINGS.
1.Â Â Â If a meter cannot be read for three consecutive months as a result of the
meter reader not being able to gain entrance to the premises, and if the
customer fails to read the meter and deliver the information to the Clerk,
water service to the premises shall be discontinued.
2.Â Â Â If there is a variance in the readings on the water meter and the remote
reader, the reading on the water meter shall be considered to be correct for
billing purposes.
CHAPTER 92

92.01Â  SERVICE CHARGES.
Each customer shall pay for water service provided by the City based upon use
of water as determined by meters provided for in Chapter 91.Â  Each location,
building, premises or connection shall be considered a separate and distinct
customer whether owned or controlled by the same person or not.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
92.02Â  RATES FOR SERVICE.
Water shall be furnished at the following monthly rates within the City:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
1.Â Â Â Effective July 1, 2008, and on each successive July 1 thereafter, the
monthly billing for the base minimum charge and the consumption charge for
water used over one thousand five hundred gallons shall be increased
automatically by three percent (3%) or an amount equal to the twelve month
percent change to the increase in the Consumer Price Index-All Urban Consumers
(CPI-U) for the preceding month of March, whichever is the lesser amount.
2.Â Â Â Effective January 1, 2009, the base minimum charge shall increase by
eighteen cents ($0.18) and the consumption charge shall increase by five cents
($0.05).
3.Â Â Â Effective January 1, 2010, the base minimum charge shall increase by
eighteen cents ($0.18) and the consumption charge shall increase by five cents
($0.05).
92.03Â  RATES OUTSIDE THE CITY.
Water service shall be provided to any customer located outside the corporate
limits of the City which the City has agreed to serve at rates one hundred
fifty percent (150%) of the rates provided in Section 92.02.Â  No such customer,
however, will be served unless the customer shall have signed a service
contract agreeing to be bound by the ordinances, rules and regulations applying
to water service established by the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.4 & 384.84)
92.04Â  BILLING FOR WATER SERVICE.
Water service shall be billed as part of a combined service account, payable in
accordance with the following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
1.Â Â Â Bills Issued.Â  The Clerk shall prepare and issue bills for combined
service accounts on or before the first day of each month.
2.Â Â Â Bills Payable.Â  Bills for combined service accounts shall be due and
payable at the office of the Clerk by the fifteenth day of each month.
3.Â Â Â Late Payment Penalty.Â  Bills not paid when due shall be considered
delinquent.Â  A one-time late payment penalty of ten percent (10%) of the amount
due shall be added to each delinquent bill.
92.05Â  SERVICE DISCONTINUED.
Water service to delinquent customers shall be discontinued in accordance with
the following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
1.Â Â Â Notice.Â  The Utility Billing Clerk shall notify each delinquent customer
that service will be discontinued if payment of the combined service account,
including late payment charges, is not received by the date specified in the
notice of delinquency.Â  Such notice shall be sent by ordinary mail and shall
inform the customer of the nature of the delinquency and afford the customer
the opportunity for a hearing prior to the discontinuance.
2.Â Â Â Notice to Landlords.Â  If the customer is a tenant, and if the owner or
landlord of the property has made a written request for notice, the notice of
delinquency shall also be given to the owner or landlord.
3.Â Â Â Hearing.Â  If a hearing is requested by noon of the day preceding the shut
off the City Administrator shall conduct an informal hearing and shall make a
determination as to whether the disconnection is justified.Â  The customer has
the right to appeal the Administratorâ€™s decision to the Council, and if the
Council finds that disconnection is justified, then such disconnection shall be
made, unless payment has been received.
4.Â Â Â Fees.Â  A fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) during normal business hours and
thirty-five ($35.00) after normal business hours shall be charged before
service is restored to a delinquent customer.Â  No fee shall be charged for the
usual or customary trips in the regular changes in occupancies of property.
92.06Â  LIEN FOR NONPAYMENT.
The owner of the premises served and any lessee or tenant thereof shall be
jointly and severally liable for water service charges to the premises.Â  Water
service charges remaining unpaid and delinquent shall constitute a lien upon
the premises served and shall be certified by the Clerk to the County Treasurer
for collection in the same manner as property taxes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
92.07Â  LIEN EXEMPTION.
The lien for nonpayment shall not apply to a residential rental property where
water service is separately metered and the rates or charges for the water
service are paid directly to the City by the tenant, if the landlord gives
written notice to the City that the property is residential rental property and
that the tenant is liable for the rates or charges.Â  The City may require a
deposit not exceeding the usual cost of ninety (90) days of water service be
paid to the City.Â  The landlordâ€™s written notice shall contain the name of the
tenant responsible for charges, the address of the rental property and the date
of occupancy.Â  A change in tenant shall require a new written notice to be
given to the City within ten (10) business days of the change in tenant.Â  When
the tenant moves from the rental property, the City shall refund the deposit if
the water service charges are paid in full.Â  A change in the ownership of the
residential rental property shall require written notice of such change to be
given to the City within ten (10) business days of the completion of the change
of ownership.Â  The lien exemption does not apply to delinquent charges for
repairs to a water service.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
92.08Â  LIEN NOTICE.
A lien for delinquent water service charges shall not be certified to the
County Treasurer unless prior written notice of intent to certify a lien is
given to the customer.Â  If the customer is a tenant and if the owner or
landlord of the property has made a written request for notice, the notice
shall also be given to the owner or landlord.Â  The notice shall be sent to the
appropriate persons by ordinary mail not less than thirty (30) days prior to
certification of the lien to the County Treasurer.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
92.09Â  CUSTOMER DEPOSITS.
There shall be required from every customer not the owner of the premises
served a deposit in an amount equal to three times the minimum monthly charge
intended to guarantee the payment of bills for service.Â  A homeowner who
receives two (2) consecutive disconnect notices shall pay a deposit in an
amount equal to three times the minimum monthly charge.Â  A homeowner's deposit
may be refunded following twelve months of consecutive timely payments.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
92.10Â  TEMPORARY VACANCY.
A property owner may request water service be temporarily discontinued and shut
off at the curb valve when the property is expected to be vacant for an
extended period of time.Â  There shall be a twenty dollar ($20.00) fee collected
for shutting the water off at the curb valve and a twenty dollar ($20.00) fee
for restoring service.Â  During a period when service is temporarily
discontinued as provided herein there shall be no minimum service charge
provided that the property owner has a licensed plumber remove the water meter
and return it to the water plant.Â  The City will not drain pipes or pull meters
for temporary vacancies.

CHAPTER 95
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
Â 
95.01Â  Purpose                  95.06Â  Service Outside the City
95.02Â  Definitions              95.07Â  Right of Entry
95.03Â  Superintendent           95.08Â  Use of Easements
95.04Â  Prohibited Acts          95.09Â  Special Penalties
95.05Â  Sewer Connection Required
Â 
95.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of the chapters of this Code of Ordinances pertaining to Sanitary
Sewers is to establish rules and regulations governing the disposal of sanitary
sewage within the City in order to protect the public health, safety and
welfare.
95.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
For use in these chapters, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise,
the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œBuilding drainâ€ means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a
building drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and
other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the
building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of
the building wall.
2.Â Â Â â€œBuilding sewerâ€ means that part of the horizontal piping from the
building wall to its connection with the main sewer or the primary treatment
portion of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system conveying the
drainage of one building site.
3.Â Â Â â€œCombined sewerâ€ means a sewer receiving both surface run-off and sewage.
4.Â Â Â â€œCustomerâ€ means any person responsible for the production of domestic,
commercial or industrial waste which is directly or indirectly discharged into
the public sewer system.
5.Â Â Â â€œNatural outletâ€ means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake,
or other body of surface or groundwater.
6.Â Â Â â€œOn-site wastewater treatment and disposal systemâ€ means all equipment and
devices necessary for proper conduction, collection, storage, treatment, and
disposal of wastewater from four or fewer dwelling units or other facilities
serving the equivalent of fifteen persons (1500 gpd) or less.
7.Â Â Â â€œPublic sewerâ€ means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties
have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority.
8.Â Â Â â€œSanitary sewageâ€ means sewage discharging from the sanitary conveniences
of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings,
factories or institutions, and free from storm, surface water, and industrial
waste.
9.Â Â Â â€œSanitary sewerâ€ means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm,
surface, and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted.
10.Â Â Â â€œSewageâ€ means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences,
business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with
such ground, surface, and storm waters as may be present.
11.Â Â Â â€œSewage worksâ€ or â€œsewage systemâ€ means all facilities for collecting
sewage owned and operated by the City.
12.Â Â Â â€œSewerâ€ means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
13.Â Â Â â€œSewer service chargesâ€ means any and all charges, rates or fees levied
against and payable by customers, as consideration for the servicing of said
customers by said sewer system.
14.Â Â Â â€œStorm drainâ€ or â€œstorm sewerâ€ means a sewer which carries storm and
surface waters and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other
than unpolluted cooling water.
15.Â Â Â â€œSuperintendentâ€ means the Public Works Director of the City or any
authorized deputy, agent, or representative.
16.Â Â Â â€œWatercourseâ€ means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either
continuously or intermittently.
95.03Â  SUPERINTENDENT.
The Superintendent shall exercise the following powers and duties:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
1.Â Â Â Operation and Maintenance.Â  Operate and maintain the City sewage system.
2.Â Â Â Inspection and Tests.Â  Conduct necessary inspections and tests to assure
compliance with the provisions of these Sanitary Sewer chapters.
3.Â Â Â Records.Â  Maintain a complete and accurate record of all sewers, sewage
connections and manholes constructed showing the location and grades thereof.
95.04Â  PROHIBITED ACTS.
No person shall do, or allow, any of the following:
1.Â Â Â Damage Sewer System.Â  Maliciously, willfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the sewer system.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
2.Â Â Â Surface Run-off or Groundwater.Â  Connect a roof downspout, sump pump,
exterior foundation drain, areaway drain, or other source of surface run-off or
groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
3.Â Â Â Manholes.Â  Open or enter any manhole of the sewer system, except by
authority of the Superintendent.
4.Â Â Â Objectionable Wastes.Â  Place or deposit in any unsanitary manner on public
or private property within the City, or in any area under the jurisdiction of
the City, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste.
5.Â Â Â Septic Tanks.Â  Construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank,
cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage except
as provided in these chapters.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
6.Â Â Â Untreated Discharge.Â  Discharge to any natural outlet within the City, or
in any area under its jurisdiction, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of these chapters.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
95.05Â  SEWER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
The owners of any houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy,
employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the City and abutting
on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located, or may in
the future be located, a public sanitary or combined sewer, are hereby required
to install, at such ownerâ€™s expense, suitable toilet facilities therein and a
building sewer connecting such facilities directly with the proper public
sewer, and to maintain the same all in accordance with the provisions of these
Sanitary Sewer chapters, such compliance to be completed within sixty (60) days
after date of official notice from the City to do so provided that said public
sewer is located within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of such
owner and is of such design as to receive and convey by gravity such sewage as
may be conveyed to it.Â  Billing for sanitary sewer service will begin the date
of official notice to connect to the public sewer and the property owner shall
be billed the minimum service charge each month until connection is made.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12 [3f])
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
95.06Â  SERVICE OUTSIDE THE CITY.
The owners of property outside the corporate limits of the City so situated
that it may be served by the City sewer system may apply to the Council for
permission to connect to the public sewer upon the terms and conditions
stipulated by resolution of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.4 [2 & 3])
95.07Â  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all
properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling,
and testing in accordance with the provisions of these Sanitary Sewer
chapters.Â  The Superintendent or representatives shall have no authority to
inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining,
ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing
on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities
for waste treatment.
95.08Â  USE OF EASEMENTS.
The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the City holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within said easement.Â  All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement,
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved.
95.09Â  SPECIAL PENALTIES.
The following special penalty provisions shall apply to violations of these
Sanitary Sewer chapters:
1.Â Â Â Notice of Violation.Â  Any person found to be violating any provision of
these chapters except subsections 1, 3 and 4 of Section 95.04, shall be served
by the City with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof.Â  The
offender shall, within the periodÂ  of time stated in such notice, permanently
cease all violations.
2.Â Â Â Continuing Violations.Â  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond
the time limit provided for in subsection 1 hereof shall be in violation of
this Code of Ordinances.Â  Each day in which any such violation shall continue
shall be deemed a separate offense.
3.Â Â Â Liability Imposed.Â  Any person violating any of the provisions of these
chapters shall become liable to the City for any expense, loss, or damage
occasioned the City by reason of such violation.

96.01Â  APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.
No person shall make any connection to the public sewer system without first
making an application for service to the City.Â  The application for service
shall set forth the location and description of the property to be connected
with the sewer system and the purpose for which the sewer is to be used, and
shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information
considered pertinent.Â  The property owner shall complete construction and
connection of the building sewer to the public sewer within sixty (60) days
after the application for service, except that when a property owner makes
sufficient showing that due to conditions beyond the ownerâ€™s control or
peculiar hardship, such time period is inequitable or unfair, an extension of
time within which to comply with the provisions herein may be granted.
96.02Â  CONNECTION CHARGE.
The person who makes the application for service shall pay to the City a
connection charge in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00).
96.03Â  PLUMBER OR EXCAVATOR REQUIRED.
All installations of building sewers and connections to the public sewer shall
be made by a licensed plumber or excavator, and a plumber or excavator license
may be suspended or revoked for violation of any of the provisions of these
Sanitary Sewer chapters.
96.04Â  CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS.
The installation of the building sewer and its connection to the public sewer
shall conform to the requirements of Division 4, Plumbing Rules and
Regulations, of the State Building Code, the laws of the State and other
applicable rules and regulations of the City.
96.05Â  SEWER TAP.
Connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at a â€œYâ€
or â€œTâ€ branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location.Â  If no
properly located â€œYâ€ or â€œTâ€ branch is available, a saddle â€œYâ€ or â€œTâ€ shall be
installed at the location specified by the Superintendent.Â  The public sewer
shall be tapped with a hole saw and a saddle appropriate to the type of public
sewer shall be attached with a gasket and stainless steel clamps to the sewer.Â 
At no time shall a building sewer be constructed so as to enter a manhole
unless special written permission is received from the Superintendent and in
accordance with the Superintendentâ€™s direction if such connection is approved.
96.06Â  INSPECTION REQUIRED.
No building sewer shall be covered, concealed or put into use until it has been
tested, inspected and accepted as prescribed in the Division 4, Plumbing Rules
and Regulations, of the State Building Code.
96.07Â  PROPERTY OWNERâ€™S RESPONSIBILITY.
All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection and maintenance
of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner.Â  The owner shall indemnify
the City from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.
96.08Â  ABATEMENT OF VIOLATIONS.
Building sewers, whether located upon the private property of any owner or in
the public right-of-way, which are constructed or maintained in violation of
any of the requirements of this chapter shall be deemed a nuisance and the same
shall be abated by the City in the manner provided for the abatement of
nuisances.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3])
96.09Â  ABANDONED CONNECTIONS.
If a building is destroyed or removed and not rebuilt, the property owner shall
remove the building sewer from the sewer main at the expense of the owner.Â  If
the owner fails to remove same, the Superintendent may employ such plumbers,
excavators or other personnel that may be needed to make the removal and the
persons employed shall have the right to make such removal on either public or
private property and the property owner shall be billed for the charges.Â  If
such charges are not paid within thirty (30) days after presentation, the Clerk
shall certify the same to the County Treasurer for collection with and in the
same manner as property taxes.Â  If a destroyed, removed or damaged building is
to be rebuilt or remodeled, the building sewer may remain after inspection by
the Superintendent and written approval to use the building sewer is given by
the Superintendent.
96.10Â  INSTALLATION OR REPLACEMENT OF BUILDING SEWER.
The building sewer pipe from the main to the building drain shall be of one of
the following materials:
1.Â Â Â Polyvinyl Chloride Pipe.Â  Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) pipe meeting the
requirements of A.S.T.M. D-3034, SDR 23.5.Â  Joints shall be integral bell, bell
and spigot type, rubber gasket.Â  Fittings shall conform to A.S.T.M. D-1784.
2.Â Â Â Ductile Iron Pipe.Â  Ductile Iron Pipe (DIP) meeting the requirements of
A.W.W.A. C-151 mechanical joint or slip joint pipe.
All building sewer pipes shall run directly from the sewer main to the property
served and no building sewer pipe shall be installed across lots or buildings
to adjoining premises.
CHAPTER 97

97.01Â  STORM WATER.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface
water, groundwater, roof run-off, sub-surface drainage, uncontaminated cooling
water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.Â  Storm
water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as
are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural
outlet approved by the Superintendent.Â  Industrial cooling water or unpolluted
process waters may be discharged on approval of the Superintendent, to a storm
sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
97.02Â  SURFACE WATERS EXCEPTION.
Special permits for discharging surface waters to a public sanitary sewer may
be issued by the Council upon recommendation of the Superintendent where such
discharge is deemed necessary or advisable for purposes of flushing, but any
permit so issued shall be subject to revocation at any time when deemed to the
best interests of the sewer system.
97.03Â  PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following
described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
1.Â Â Â Flammable or Explosive Material.Â  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel
oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
2.Â Â Â Toxic or Poisonous Materials.Â  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or
poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment
process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or
create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant,
including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two (2) milligrams per liter
as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer.
3.Â Â Â Corrosive Wastes.Â  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
4.Â Â Â Solid or Viscous Substances.Â  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or
of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other
interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not
limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc.,
either whole or ground by garbage grinders.
5.Â Â Â Excessive B.O.D., Solids or Flow.Â  Any waters or wastes having (a) a five
(5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three hundred (300) parts per
million by weight, or (b) containing more than three hundred fifty (350) parts
per million by weight of suspended solids, or (c) having an average daily flow
greater than two percent (2%) of the average sewage flow of the City, shall be
subject to the review of the Superintendent.Â  Where necessary in the opinion of
the Superintendent, the owner shall provide, at the ownerâ€™s expense, such
preliminary treatment as may be necessary to (a) reduce the biochemical oxygen
demand to three hundred (300) parts per million by weight, or (b) reduce the
suspended solids to three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight, or
(c) control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes.Â 
Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed
preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the
Superintendent and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until
said approvals are obtained in writing.
97.04Â  PROHIBITED DISCHARGES - POWERS.
If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the
public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the
characteristics enumerated in Section 97.03 and which in the judgment of theÂ 
may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or
receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a
public nuisance, theÂ  may:
1.Â Â Â Rejection.Â  Reject the wastes by requiring disconnection from the public
sewage system;
2.Â Â Â Pretreatment.Â  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for
discharge to the public sewers;
3.Â Â Â Controls Imposed.Â  Require control over the quantities and rates of
discharge; and/or
4.Â Â Â Special Charges.Â  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and
treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the
provisions of Chapter 99.
97.05Â  SPECIAL FACILITIES.
If theÂ  permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and
installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and
approval of theÂ  and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes,
ordinances, and laws.Â  Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing
facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained
continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at the
ownerâ€™s expense.
97.06Â  CONTROL MANHOLES.
When required by the , the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer
carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together
with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to
facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes.Â  Such manhole,
when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed
in accordance with plans approved by the .Â  The manhole shall be installed by
the owner at the ownerâ€™s expense, and shall be maintained by the owner so as to
be safe and accessible at all times.
97.07Â  TESTING OF WASTES.
All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, and
shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples
taken at said control manhole.Â  In the event that no special manhole has been
required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream
manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is
connected.Â  Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to
reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the
existence of hazards to life, limb, and property.Â  (The particular analyses
involved will determine whether a twenty-four (24) hour composite of all
outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples
should be taken.Â  Normally, but not always, B.O.D. and suspended solids
analyses are obtained from twenty-four (24) hour composites of all outfalls
whereas pHâ€™s are determined from periodic grab samples.)
CHAPTER 98

98.01Â  WHEN PROHIBITED.
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or
maintain any on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.02Â  WHEN REQUIRED.
When a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of Section
95.05, every building wherein persons reside, congregate or are employed shall
be provided with an approved on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system
complying with the provisions of this chapter.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
98.03Â  COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
The type, capacity, location and layout of a private on-site wastewater
treatment and disposal system shall comply with the specifications and
requirements set forth by the Iowa Administrative Code 567, Chapter 69, and
with such additional requirements as are prescribed by the regulations of the
County Board of Health.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3 & 4])
98.04Â  PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall install or alter an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system without first obtaining a permit from the County Board of Health.
98.05Â  DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS.
It is unlawful to discharge any wastewater from an on-site wastewater treatment
and disposal system (except under an NPDES permit) to any ditch, stream, pond,
lake, natural or artificial waterway, drain tile or to the surface of the
ground.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
98.06Â  MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM.
The owner of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system shall operate
and maintain the system in a sanitary manner at all times and at no expense to
the City.
98.07Â  SYSTEMS ABANDONED.
At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by an on-
site wastewater treatment and disposal system, as provided in Section 95.05, a
direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with these
Sanitary Sewer chapters and the on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.08Â  DISPOSAL OF SEPTAGE.
No person shall dispose of septage from an on-site treatment system at any
location except an approved disposal site.

99.07Â  LIEN FOR NONPAYMENT.
The owner of the premises served and any lessee or tenant thereof shall be
jointly and severally liable for sewer service charges to the premises.Â  Sewer
service charges remaining unpaid and delinquent shall constitute a lien upon

for collection in the same manner as property taxes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
99.08Â  CUSTOMER DEPOSITS.
There shall be required from every customer not the owner of the premises
served a deposit in an amount equal to three times the minimum monthly charge
intended to guarantee the payment of bills for service.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
99.09Â  SPECIAL AGREEMENTS PERMITTED.
No statement in these chapters shall be construed as preventing a special
agreement, arrangement or contract between the Council, and any industrial
concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be
accepted subject to special conditions, rate and cost as established by the
Council.

100.01Â  PURPOSE AND FINDINGS.
The purpose of this chapter is to establish the Storm Water Utility, authorize
charges, rates and fees for use of, and discharge to, the public storm and
surface water drainage system, to provide a process for appeals from certain
decisions of the Council relating to such charges, and to provide for
collection of delinquent charges.Â  The Council finds that the construction,
operation and maintenance of the Cityâ€™s storm water system should, in part, be
funded through user charges imposed for the discharge of storm and surface
water to the storm water drainage system, thereby charging those persons and
activities using or receiving service from that system.Â  The City may be
required to provide increased quantity or quality controls to mitigate those
impacts of pollutants from discharging storm and surface waters into the storm
water system.Â  Therefore, it is appropriate to impose a storm and surface water
user charge upon all users of property which may discharge, directly or
indirectly, into the storm water system.
100.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
The following words shall have the following definitions when used in this
chapter, and any resolution and order adopted pursuant hereto, unless the
context requires otherwise or unless such word is expressly defined otherwise:
1.Â Â Â â€œConnectionâ€ means the physical act or process of directing or allowing
the flow of storm and surface waters to the storm sewer or drainage line, or
joining onto an existing side sewer, for the purpose of connecting private
impervious surface or other storm and surface water sources or systems to the
public storm and surface water system.Â  It also includes creation or
maintenance of impervious surface that causes or is likely to cause an increase
in the quantity or decrease in quality or both from the natural state of storm
water runoff, and which drains, directly or indirectly, to the storm and
surface water system.
2.Â Â Â â€œDate of impositionâ€ or â€œimposition dateâ€ means the first day of each
month or such other date designated by the Council at which time a charge is
imposed and becomes the legal obligation of the user.Â  The obligation may
include the cost of services to be provided during the billing period or for
services previously provided to the same person under this chapter.
3.Â Â Â â€œDaysâ€ means calendar days unless otherwise specified.
4.Â Â Â â€œEquivalent service unitâ€ or â€œESUâ€ means a measurement unit based on the
impervious surface area of an average improved single family dwelling lot or
parcel within the City (as determined by a statistical sampling performed by
the City).Â  Except as provided otherwise, one equivalent service unit shall be
deemed to be 3,000 square feet of impervious surface.
5.Â Â Â â€œImpervious surface areaâ€ means all land area that has been altered from
its natural state such that it does not allow the infiltration and retention of
water equivalent to that of undisturbed soil.Â  This includes, but is not
limited to:Â  pavement, buildings, decks, parking areas, and compacted gravel
areas.Â  â€œImpervious surfaceâ€ does not include improved streets, roads, and
sidewalks within the public right-of-way; bike paths; railroad beds or quarry
excavation areas and temporary service roads in the excavation areas.Â  Rather
such facilities are deemed to be a part of the public surface water drainage
conveyance system or to constitute non-impervious surfaces.
6.Â Â Â â€œMulti-family dwelling unitâ€ means a residential unit located within a
building that accommodates more than one (1) residential living unit and in
which each residential living unit has a separate water meter.
7.Â Â Â â€œOccupantâ€ means the person residing or doing business on the property.Â 
In a family or household situation, the occupants responsible for the
obligation herein imposed are the adult heads of the household, jointly and
severally.Â  In a dwelling or office sharing situation, the adult occupant
legally responsible for the management or condition of the property shall be
responsible.
8.Â Â Â â€œOther developed userâ€ means any parcel, lot or property other than a
single family dwelling unit or a multi-family dwelling unit.
9.Â Â Â â€œOwnerâ€ means the legal owner(s) of records as shown on the tax rolls of
Cerro Gordo County, or where there is a recorded land sale contract, the
purchaser thereunder.
10.Â Â Â â€œPersonâ€ means any individual, public or private corporation, political
subdivision, governmental agency, municipality, partnership, association, firm,
trust, or any other legal entity whatsoever.
11.Â Â Â â€œRuleâ€ means any written standard, directive, interpretation, policy,
regulation, procedure or other provision, adopted by the Council as a
resolution and order to carry out the provisions of this chapter.
12.Â Â Â â€œSingle family dwelling unitâ€ means a lot or parcel on which a single
family dwelling or a duplex with a single water meter exists at any time as the
imposition of the charge.
13.Â Â Â â€œStorm and surface water drainage systemâ€ means any combination of
publicly owned storm and surface water quantity and quality facilities, pumping
or lift facilities, storm and secondary drain pipes and culverts, open
channels, creeks, ditches and rivers, force mains, laterals, manholes, catch
basins and inlets, including the grates and covers thereof, detention and
retention facilities, laboratory facilities and equipment, and any other
publicly owned facilities for the collection, conveyance, treatment and
disposal of storm and surface water within the City, to which sanitary sewage
flows are not intentionally admitted.
14.Â Â Â â€œUserâ€ means any person who uses property which maintains connection to,
discharges to, or otherwise receives services from the City for surface water
management.Â  The occupant of occupied property is deemed the user.Â  If the
property is not occupied, the person who has the right to occupy it shall be
deemed the user.
100.03Â  STORM WATER UTILITY ESTABLISHED.
Pursuant to the authority of Section 384.84 of the Code of Iowa, as amended,
the Council hereby establishes a storm water utility in the City.Â  The entire

100.04Â  CHARGES AND FEES.

1.Â Â Â Service Charge.Â  Each customer shall pay for public storm water drainage

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Effective January 1, 2010, the monthly billing per equivalent service

rates to be charged for the storm water drainage system.
100.05Â  STORM WATER UTILITY USER CHARGE.
1.Â Â Â There is hereby established a storm water utility system user charge.Â 
This charge hereby is imposed on every user within the City of the storm and
surface water drainage system on the imposition date.Â  The charge may be
required to be paid in advance of the provision of service for the billing
period.Â  The charge due for the billing period shall be the obligation of the
user of the public storm system on the imposition date, notwithstanding whether
the user is the addressee of the bill.
2.Â Â Â The charge shall be the personal obligation of the user on the imposition
date, regardless of whether that person has any ownership interest in the
property.Â  This charge shall constitute a debt due the City as of the date of
imposition.
3.Â Â Â Any person who has paid the full amount due in advance of receiving
service shall be entitled to a refund if the person ceases to be the user.Â  The
refund shall be effective on the date the property is vacated or sold and based
on the number of days remaining in the billing period.Â  The refund is waived
unless a written request for refund is filed within thirty (30) days of
vacating or selling the property.Â  The request shall include documentation
reasonably deemed adequate by the City.Â  Notwithstanding any other provision,
the new user shall be responsible for the remaining balance of the service
charge, which may be billed immediately or added to the bill for the next
period.
4.Â Â Â There shall be a rebuttable presumption that the owner of the real
property, as shown in the records of the County Assessor, is the occupant.
5.Â Â Â The storm water utility user charge shall be imposed upon any person who
uses or discharges to the public storm and surface water drainage system by:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Maintaining impervious surface connected to (directly or indirectly)
and capable of discharge to the public surface water management systems; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Actually discharging storm or surface water into the system; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Making a specific request for storm and surface water management
service.
Said charge shall be charged for all users of properties within the boundaries
of the City.Â  A property, whether unimproved or containing impervious surface,
is presumed to discharge storm water to the storm and surface water drainage
system, and to generate a demand for storm and surface water drainage services.
100.06Â  CALCULATION OF EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNITS AND AMOUNT OF CHARGE.
This section shall be used to determine the number of equivalent service units
(ESUs) for a property for purposes of determining the amount of the storm water
utility (SWU) service charges.
1.Â Â Â Single family residential dwelling units and multi-family residential
dwelling units shall be charged at a rate of one (1) ESU per water meter.
2.Â Â Â Other developed users shall be charged at a rate of two (2) ESUs per water
meter.
3.Â Â Â Any agricultural use of land or other user that does not have a water
account with the City shall be considered exempt from the storm water utility
(SWU) service charges.
100.07Â  ADJUSTMENT OF ESU DETERMINATION.
1.Â Â Â Any Other Developed User with an impervious surface area equal to or less
than the impervious area for an ESU may request an adjustment of the storm
water utility service charge to one ESU.
2.Â Â Â The request for adjustment from two (2) ESUs to one (1) ESU shall be
submitted to the City in writing on forms provided by the City requesting an
adjustment of the applicable number of ESUs.
3.Â Â Â The request for adjustment shall be submitted within ninety (90) days of
receipt of the first billing of the storm water utility service charge to that
user.
4.Â Â Â Any request for adjustment shall include sufficient documentation to allow
the City to determine from the documentation provided the impervious surface
area.
5.Â Â Â Within twenty (20) days after receipt of the request for adjustment, the
City shall review the adjustment.Â  If the City determines the impervious area
is less than the area of an ESU, the parcel shall be classified as subject to
the charge of one (1) ESU.Â  The City shall adjust for any previous payments
greater than one (1) ESU.Â  If the City determines there is insufficient
information to complete the evaluation, the City shall notify the applicant and
request additional information.Â  If the City determines the impervious area is
greater than the impervious area of an ESU, the City shall notify the applicant
the request for the adjustment is denied.
6.Â Â Â If the City requests additional information, the applicant shall submit
additional information within twenty (20) days after the determination by the
City.Â  If additional information is not submitted within twenty (20) days, the
request for the adjustment shall be considered to have been withdrawn.
100.08Â  BILLING.
1.Â Â Â The City shall send a bill for the amount due by regular mail to every
user in the City.Â  Mailing to the user of record as shown in the City water
billing records shall satisfy this requirement.Â  The billing period shall be
the same as for water usage.
2.Â Â Â The recipient has twenty (20) days from the billing date to file a notice
of non-occupancy.Â  The notice shall indicate the relationship of the recipient
to the property (e.g. owner, lessor, mortgagee), whether on the imposition date
the property was occupied, and if so, by whom.
3.Â Â Â Upon receipt of the notice, the City shall determine who is obligated for
payment.Â  Based on this determination, the City shall:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Issue a new bill to the occupant if the property was occupied by
someone other than the original recipient;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Reissue the bill to the recipient if it is found that that person was
the occupant;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Issue a bill to the owner as the user, if the property was not
occupied.
The City may take into account any reasonably reliable information available to
it, including utility records.
4.Â Â Â Failure to file the notice so that it is actually received by the City
within the twenty (20) days of the mailing date of the bill shall conclusively
establish that the original addressee was the user on the imposition date.
5.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any person may agree
in writing to be responsible for payment of the charge.Â  Upon filing of such a
writing with the City, subsequent bills shall be sent to that person, and that
person shall be deemed to be the user.
6.Â Â Â It is a violation of this chapter to knowingly provide false information
to the City regarding any fact related to billing of a storm water utility
service charge or other charge of the City.
100.09Â  DELINQUENCY, COLLECTION, INTEREST AND PENALTIES.
1.Â Â Â Charges imposed under this chapter are deemed delinquent when not paid in
full by the due date provided in a billing for the charge.
2.Â Â Â It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to discharge
wastewater into the Cityâ€™s storm water utility system.Â  It is also unlawful and
a violation of this chapter to maintain a connection to or use the Cityâ€™s storm
water utility system without paying the appropriate charges and fees
established in this chapter or any rule adopted pursuant hereto.Â  Even if no
billing is received, such charges shall be due and owning and the user is
obligated to pay any charges in a timely fashion.
3.Â Â Â Delinquent charges may be collected pursuant to the same procedure as with
delinquent water bills by the City, with the assistance of City legal counsel,
without further action or authorization by the Council.
4.Â Â Â Delinquent charges may be recovered by the City in the same manner as
provided in Chapter 92.
5.Â Â Â In addition to remedies provided for collection of a debt, the City may
seek a temporary or permanent injunction prohibiting continued occupancy of
premises, requiring disconnection of the premises from the public storm water
utility system, and termination of water and sewer service to the userâ€™s
premises.
6.Â Â Â The Council may prescribe, by resolution and order, a schedule of interest
and penalty charges to be imposed upon delinquent charges.
7.Â Â Â In a collection action under this chapter, the City shall be entitled to
its costs and reasonable attorney fees, including at trial and on appeal, if it
is the prevailing party.
8.Â Â Â In addition to the right of the City to bring a civil action to collect
any delinquent charges or enforce any provision of the chapter, the City may
take any of the following actions to secure payment:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The City may refuse to issue any permit to any person who is delinquent
in any payment due under this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The City may terminate provision of storm and surface water service to
premises used by the user.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The City may terminate sanitary sewer service to premises used by the
user.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The City may terminate water service to the premises used by the user.
Termination of service pursuant to this subsection shall be according to
procedures adopted under Section 100.10.Â  If the City terminates service as
provided in this subsection, the cost of such disconnection shall be added to
the amount of any other delinquent charges and shall be recoverable in the same
manner as are such charges.
9.Â Â Â The owner and the tenant must comply with the same procedures as set out
in Section 92.06.Â  All obligations of the owner and tenant shall be the same as
stated in Section 92.07.
10.Â Â Â Where a lien against the property can be imposed when the owner is
liable, it shall exist from the date the bill was last brought current in the
same manner as with a lien for water service.Â  The provisions of Section 92.08
shall apply to delinquent storm water utility bills.
100.10Â  REQUEST FOR SERVICE; DISCONNECTION FROM SERVICE; USE RECLASSIFICATION;
TERMINATION OF USER CHARGES.
1.Â Â Â The opening of a water billing account shall be deemed to be a specific
request for provision of storm and surface water service to that property.
2.Â Â Â Any user of the public storm water utility system may disconnect property
served by the system from service and terminate further user charges by
terminating an active water billing account to the property.
3.Â Â Â Any user of the public storm water utility may remove all or part of the
impervious surface on the property served by the system and apply for use
reclassification by utilizing the procedure in this section.Â  Removal of
impervious surface shall entitle the user to submit a request for an
administrative adjustment within sixty (60) days after removal of the
impervious surface.
4.Â Â Â If at any time an impervious surface is added to a property, the City
shall consider such an addition as a reconnection to the storm water utility
and as a specific request for storm water utility service.
100.11Â  ADOPTION OF RULES; INTERPRETATIONS AND APPEALS.
1.Â Â Â Adoption of Rules.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Council may, by resolution and order, promulgate rules pertaining
to matters within the scope of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any rule adopted pursuant to this section shall require a public
hearing.Â  Not less than four (4) or more than twenty (20) days before such
hearing, public notice of such hearing shall be given by publication in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City.Â  Such notice shall include
the place, time and purpose of the hearing and the location at which copies of
the full text of the proposed rules may be obtained.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â At the public hearing, the Council shall hear testimony concerning the
proposed rules.Â  At the conclusion of the public hearing, the Council shall
either adopt the proposal, modify or reject it.Â  If a modification is made, an
additional public hearing shall be held but no additional notice shall be
required if such additional hearing is announced at the meeting at which the
modification is made.Â  All rules shall be effective upon adoption by the
Council and shall be filed in the office of the City.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Notwithstanding paragraphs B and C of this subsection, a rule maybe
adopted without prior notice upon a finding that failure of the Council to act
promptly will result in serious prejudice to the public interest or the
interest of the affected parties, including the specified reasons for such
prejudice.
2.Â Â Â Appeals.Â  The following may be appealed to the Council:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A determination that the person is obligated to pay the service charge
imposed herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A dispute as to the proper calculation of the amount due from the
person.Â  This does not include, however, an objection to the overall
establishment of the storm water utility charge or the amount per ESU
established by the Council or the establishment of classes of impervious
surface area.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A discretionary decision implementing a rule adopted by the Council if
an appeal is provided in the Order adopting the rule.
3.Â Â Â The appeal shall be filed in writing and must be actually received by the
City no later than the thirtieth (30th) day after the action appealed.Â  The
thirty (30) days shall be calculated from the due date of the original or
reissued bill in response to a notice of non-occupancy, whichever is later.
4.Â Â Â The appeal shall be heard by the Public Works Director and City
Administrator in an informal proceeding.Â  The appellant shall be provided a
reasonable opportunity to submit written and oral support for the appellantâ€™s
position.Â  The Public Works Director and City Administrator shall issue a
written decision within ten (10) days of the proceeding.Â  The written decision
of the Public Works Director and City Administrator may be appealed to the
Council by writ of review.Â  Failure to properly exhaust the administrative
remedy provided for herein shall constitute a bar to judicial relief.
5.Â Â Â The appeal from the Public Works Director and City Administrator shall be
heard by the Council in an informal proceeding.Â  The appellant shall be
provided a reasonable opportunity to submit written and oral support for the
appellantâ€™s position.Â  The Council shall issue a written decision with thirty
(30) days of the proceeding.Â  The written decision of the Council may be
appealed to the Circuit Court of Cerro Gordo County by writ of review.Â  Failure
to properly exhaust the administrative remedy provided for herein shall
constitute a bar to judicial relief.
