136.01Â  PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to enhance safe passage by citizens on
sidewalks, to place the responsibility for the maintenance, repair, replacement
or reconstruction of sidewalks upon the abutting property owner and to minimize
the liability of the City.
136.02Â  DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œBroom finishâ€ means a sidewalk finish that is made by sweeping the
sidewalk when it is hardening.
2.Â Â Â â€œDefective sidewalkâ€ means any public sidewalk exhibiting one or more of
the following characteristics:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Vertical separations equal to three-fourths (Â¾) inch or more.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Horizontal separations equal to one (1) inch or more.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Holes or depressions equal to three-fourths (Â¾) inch or more and at
least four (4) inches in diameter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Spalling over fifty percent (50%) of a single square of the sidewalk
with one or more depressions equal to one-half (Â½) inch or more.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Spalling over less than fifty percent (50%) of a single square of the
sidewalk with one or more depressions equal to three-fourths (Â¾) inch or more.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â A single square of sidewalk cracked in such a manner that no part
thereof has a piece greater than one square foot.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â A sidewalk with any part thereof missing to the full depth.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â A change from the design or construction grade equal to or greater than
three-fourths (Â¾) inch per foot.
3.Â Â Â â€œEstablished gradeâ€ means that grade established by the City for the
particular area in which a sidewalk is to be constructed.
4.Â Â Â â€œOne-course constructionâ€ means that the full thickness of the concrete is
placed at one time, using the same mixture throughout.
5.Â Â Â â€œOwnerâ€ means the person owning the fee title to property abutting any
sidewalk and includes any contract purchaser for purposes of notification
required herein.Â  For all other purposes, â€œownerâ€ includes the lessee, if any.
6.Â Â Â â€œSidewalkâ€ means all permanent public walks in business, residential or
suburban areas.
7.Â Â Â â€œSidewalk improvementsâ€ means the construction, reconstruction, repair,
replacement or removal, of a public sidewalk and/or the excavating, filling or
depositing of material in the public right-of-way in connection therewith.
8.Â Â Â â€œWood float finishâ€ means a sidewalk finish that is made by smoothing the
surface of the sidewalk with a wooden trowel.
136.03Â  REMOVAL OF SNOW, ICE AND ACCUMULATIONS.
It is the responsibility of the abutting property owners to remove snow, ice
and accumulations promptly from sidewalks.Â  If a property owner does not remove
snow, ice or accumulations within forty-eight (48) hours after such
accumulation, the City may do so and assess the costs against the property
owner for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2b & e])
136.04Â  SNOW REMOVAL EXEMPTIONS.
At the discretion of the Public Works Director, an exemption from the
requirements of Section 136.03 may be granted, upon application by the property
owner abutting the sidewalk.Â  Such exemption may be canceled at any time by the
Public Works Director, but prior to the effective date of such cancellation,
the Public Works Director shall give a written notice to the property owner by
mailing said notice to the property owner by ordinary first class mail at least
fifteen (15) days before the date said cancellation becomes effective.
136.05Â  RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE.
It is the responsibility of the abutting property owners to repair, replace or
reconstruct, or cause to be repaired, replaced or reconstructed, all broken or
defective sidewalks and to maintain in a safe and hazard-free condition any
sidewalk outside the lot and property lines and inside the curb lines or
traveled portion of the public street.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12 [2c])
136.06Â  CITY MAY ORDER REPAIRS.
If the abutting property owner does not maintain sidewalks as required, the
Council may serve notice on such owner, by certified mail, requiring the owner
to repair, replace or reconstruct sidewalks within a reasonable time and if
such action is not completed within the time stated in the notice, the Council
may require the work to be done and assess the costs against the abutting
property for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2d & e])
136.07Â  SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION ORDERED.
The Council may order the construction of permanent sidewalks upon any street
or court in the City and may specially assess the cost of such improvement to
abutting property owners in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 384 of
the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.38)
136.08Â  PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall remove, reconstruct or install a sidewalk unless such person
has obtained a permit from the City and has agreed in writing that said
removal, reconstruction or installation will comply with all ordinances and
requirements of the City for such work.Â  A written application for such permit
shall be filed with the City and shall be accompanied by a permit fee of five
dollars ($5.00).
136.09Â  SIDEWALK STANDARDS.
Sidewalks repaired, replaced or constructed under the provisions of this
chapter shall be of the following construction and meet the following
standards:
1.Â Â Â Cement.Â  Portland cement shall be the only cement used in the construction
and repair of sidewalks.
2.Â Â Â Construction.Â  Sidewalks shall be of one-course construction.Â  A Type C
IDOT Concrete Mix shall be used.
3.Â Â Â Sidewalk Base.Â  Concrete may be placed directly on compact and well-
drained soil.Â  Where soil is not well drained, a three (3) inch sub-base of
compact, clean, coarse gravel or sand shall be laid.Â  The adequacy of the soil
drainage is to be determined by the City.
4.Â Â Â Sidewalk Bed.Â  The sidewalk bed shall be so graded that the constructed
sidewalk will be at established grade.
5.Â Â Â Length, Width and Depth.Â  Length, width and depth requirements are as
follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Residential sidewalks shall be at least four (4) feet wide and four (4)
inches thick, and each section shall be no more than four (4) feet in length.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All sidewalks throughout the Business District shall be constructed
from lot line to the curb line unless the location of the sidewalk is varied by
an appropriate resolution of the Council upon application by the landowner.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sidewalks through driveway areas shall be not less than six (6) inches
in thickness.
6.Â Â Â Location.Â  Residential sidewalks shall be located with the inner edge
(edge nearest the abutting private property) one foot from the property line,
unless the Council establishes a different distance due to special
circumstances.
7.Â Â Â Grade.Â  Curb tops shall be on level with the centerline of the street
which shall be the established grade.
8.Â Â Â Elevations.Â  The street edge of a sidewalk shall be at an elevation even
with the curb at the curb or not less than one-half (Â½) inch above the curb for
each foot between the curb and the sidewalk.
9.Â Â Â Slope.Â  All sidewalks shall slope one-quarter (Â¼) inch per foot toward the
curb.
10.Â Â Â Finish.Â  All sidewalks shall be finished with a â€œbroomâ€ or â€œwood floatâ€
finish.
11.Â Â Â Ramps for Persons with Disabilities.Â  Curb cuts or ramps shall be located
at all locations where a public sidewalk intersects any public or private
street.Â  Each curb cut or ramp shall be at least thirty (30) inches wide, shall
be sloped at not greater than one inch of rise per twelve (12) inches lineal
distance, except that a slope no greater than one inch of rise per eight (8)
inches lineal distance may be used where necessary, shall have a nonskid
surface, and shall otherwise be so constructed as to allow reasonable access to
the crosswalk for persons with disabilities using the sidewalk.
136.10Â  BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS.
Whenever any material of any kind is deposited on any street, avenue, highway,
passageway or alley when sidewalk improvements are being made or when any
sidewalk is in a dangerous condition, it shall be the duty of all persons
having an interest therein, either as the contractor or the owner, agent, or
lessee of the property in front of or along which such material may be
deposited, or such dangerous condition exists, to put in conspicuous places at
each end of such sidewalk and at each end of any pile of material deposited in
the street, a sufficient number of approved warning lights or flares, and to
keep them lighted during the entire night and to erect sufficient barricades
both at night and in the daytime to secure the same.Â  The party or parties
using the street for any of the purposes specified in this chapter shall be
liable for all injuries or damage to persons or property arising from any
wrongful act or negligence of the party or parties, or their agents or
employees or for any misuse of the privileges conferred by this chapter or of
any failure to comply with provisions hereof.
136.11Â  FAILURE TO REPAIR OR BARRICADE.
It is the duty of the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk, or the
ownerâ€™s contractor or agent, to notify the City immediately in the event of
failure or inability to make necessary sidewalk improvements or to install or
erect necessary barricades as required by this chapter.
136.12Â  INTERFERENCE WITH SIDEWALK IMPROVEMENTS.
No person shall knowingly or willfully drive any vehicle upon any portion of
any sidewalk or approach thereto while in the process of being improved or upon
any portion of any completed sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove or
destroy any part or all of any sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove,
destroy, mar or deface any sidewalk at any time or destroy, mar, remove or
deface any notice provided by this chapter.
136.13Â  ENCROACHING STEPS.
It is unlawful for a person to erect or maintain any stairs or steps to any
building upon any part of any sidewalk without permission by resolution of the
Council.
136.14Â  OPENINGS AND ENCLOSURES.
It is unlawful for a person to:
1.Â Â Â Stairs and Railings.Â  Construct or build a stairway or passageway to any
cellar or basement by occupying any part of the sidewalk, or to enclose any
portion of a sidewalk with a railing without permission by resolution of the
Council.
2.Â Â Â Openings.Â  Keep open any cellar door, grating or cover to any vault on any
sidewalk except while in actual use with adequate guards to protect the public.
3.Â Â Â Protect Openings.Â  Neglect to properly protect or barricade all openings
on or within six (6) feet of any sidewalk.
136.15Â  FIRES OR FUELS ON SIDEWALKS.
It is unlawful for a person to make a fire of any kind on any sidewalk or to
place or allow any fuel to remain upon any sidewalk.
136.16Â  DEFACING.
It is unlawful for a person to scatter or place any paste, paint or writing on
any sidewalk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
136.17Â  DEBRIS ON SIDEWALKS.
It is unlawful for a person to throw or deposit on any sidewalk any glass,
nails, glass bottle, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter, offal,
or any other debris, or any substance likely to injure any person, animal or
vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12 [2])
136.18Â  MERCHANDISE DISPLAY.
It is unlawful for a person to place upon or above any sidewalk, any goods or
merchandise for sale or for display in such a manner as to interfere with the
free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians on the sidewalk; in no case shall
more than three (3) feet of the sidewalk next to the building be occupied for
such purposes.
136.19Â  SALES STANDS.
It is unlawful for a person to erect or keep any vending machine or stand for
the sale of fruit, vegetables or other substances or commodities on any
sidewalk without first obtaining a written permit from the Council.
CHAPTER 137

137.01Â  POWER TO VACATE.
When, in the judgment of the Council, it would be in the best interest of the
City to vacate a street, alley, portion thereof or any public grounds, the
Council may do so by ordinance in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12 [2a])
137.02Â  PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
Any proposal to vacate a street, alley, portion thereof or any public grounds
shall be referred by the Council to the Planning and Zoning Commission for its
study and recommendation prior to further consideration by the Council.Â  The
Commission shall submit a written report including recommendations to the
Council within thirty (30) days after the date the proposed vacation is
referred to the Commission.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 392.1)
137.03Â  NOTICE OF VACATION HEARING.
The Council shall cause to be published a notice of public hearing of the time
at which the proposal to vacate shall be considered.
137.04Â  FINDINGS REQUIRED.
No street, alley, portion thereof or any public grounds shall be vacated unless
the Council finds that:
1.Â Â Â Public Use.Â  The street, alley, portion thereof or any public ground
proposed to be vacated is not needed for the use of the public, and therefore,
its maintenance at public expense is no longer justified.
2.Â Â Â Abutting Property.Â  The proposed vacation will not deny owners of property
abutting on the street or alley reasonable access to their property.
137.05Â  DISPOSAL OF VACATED STREETS OR ALLEYS.
When in the judgment of the Council it would be in the best interest of the
City to dispose of a vacated street or alley, portion thereof or public ground,
the Council may do so in accordance with the provisions of Section 364.7, Code
of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.7)
137.06Â  DISPOSAL BY GIFT LIMITED.
The City may not dispose of real property by gift except to a governmental body
for a public purpose.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.7[3])

140.01Â  EXERCISE OF POLICE POWER.
This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the City under
Chapter 306A, Code of Iowa, for the preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and for the promotion of the general welfare.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 306A.1)
140.02Â  DEFINITION.
The term â€œcontrolled access facilityâ€ means a highway or street especially
designed for through traffic, and over, from or to which owners or occupants of
abutting land or other persons have no right or easement or only a controlled
right or easement of access, light, air or view by reason of the fact that
their property abuts upon such controlled access facility or for any other
reason.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 306A.2)
140.03Â  RIGHT OF ACCESS LIMITED.
No person has any right of ingress or egress to or from abutting lands onto or
across any controlled access facility, except at such designated points at
which access is permitted.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 306A.4)
140.04Â  ACCESS CONTROLS IMPOSED.
There are hereby fixed and established controlled access facilities within the
City, described as follows:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 306A.3)

Project No. FN-979, Primary Road No. 106, within the City, described as
follows:

to Station 58+48 (ECL)
regulating access to and from Station 7+00 to Station 58+48, abutting
properties along said highway all in accordance with the plans for such
improvement identified as Project No. FN-979, on file in the office of the
Clerk.
2.Â Â Â Project No. F-888(4) and F-1(7).Â  On the Primary Road System extension
improvement, Project No. F-888(4) and F-1(7), Primary Road No. U.S. 18, within
the City, described as follows:

regulating access to and from Primary Road No. U.S. 18 from Station 256+85.0 to
Station 376+12.6 and the abutting properties along said highway all in
accordance with the plans for such improvement identified as Project No. F-888
(4) and F-1(7) on file in the office of the Clerk.
140.05Â  UNLAWFUL USE OF CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITY.
It is unlawful for any person to:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 306A.3 and 321.366)
1.Â Â Â Cross Dividing Line.Â  Drive a vehicle over, upon or across any curb,
central dividing section, or other separation or dividing line on such
controlled access facilities.
2.Â Â Â Turns.Â  Make a left turn or a semicircular or U-turn except through an
opening provided for that purpose in the dividing curb section, separation or
line.
3.Â Â Â Use of Lanes.Â  Drive any vehicle except in the proper lane provided for
that purpose and in the proper direction and to the right of the central
dividing curb, separation, section or line.
4.Â Â Â Enter Facility.Â  Drive any vehicle into the controlled access facility
from a local service road except through an opening provided for that purpose
in the dividing curb or dividing section or dividing line which separates such
service road from the controlled access facility property.

CHAPTER 141
DRIVEWAY REGULATIONS
Â 
141.01Â  Definitions                      141.07Â  Sidewalks
141.02Â  Permit Required                  141.08Â  Driveway Requirements
141.03Â  Fee for Permit                   141.09Â  Excavations
141.04Â  Width and Number of Curb Openings141.10Â  Inspection and Approval
141.05Â  Location of Driveway             141.11Â  Existing Driveways Altered
141.06Â  Method of Cutting Curb
Â 
141.01Â Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œDrivewayâ€ means that part of any approach for motor vehicles to private
property that lies between the property line and roadway of the public street.
2.Â Â Â â€œPavingâ€ means surfacing with Portland cement concrete or bituminous
concrete, with the necessary base.Â  â€œPavingâ€ does not include surfacing with
oil, gravel, oil and gravel, or chloride.
141.02Â Â PERMIT REQUIRED.
Before any person shall construct or repair a driveway, such person shall
obtain a written permit from the Building Official.Â  A written application for
the permit shall be filed with the Building Official.Â  The application shall
include a legal description of the property, the name of the property owner,
the name and address of the person who will do the work, and the proposed plan
of construction or repair which shall include the depth, width, and type of
surfacing material to be used.Â  No other plan shall be followed except by
written permission of the Building Official, who may allow amendments to the
application or permit that do not conflict with this chapter.Â  The Building
Official shall issue the permit, bearing the signature of the Building Official
and the date of issuance, if the proposed plan meets all of the requirements of
this chapter, if the fee required under this chapter has been paid, and if the
construction or repair as planned will not create any substantial hazard in the
use of the street or sidewalk for public travel or drainage, or create any
defect.Â  Each permit shall expire six (6) months from the date of issuance, if
not constructed within that time.
141.03Â  FEE FOR PERMIT.
Before any permit is issued the person who makes the application shall pay a
permit fee of twenty dollars ($20.00).
141.04Â Â Â Â WIDTH AND NUMBER OF CURB OPENINGS.
The drive width for a single drive shall not be less than twelve (12) feet or
more than sixteen (16) feet and the width for a double drive shall not exceed
twenty-two (22) feet.Â  Drives greater than double shall have a maximum drive
width of twenty-eight (28) feet.Â  In general, only one (1) opening shall be
granted per residence in residential areas.Â  The Building Official may grant
additional openings in special cases such as for larger corner lots, etc.Â  The
width and number of curb openings for business and commercial places shall be
determined as to the need by the Planning and Zoning Commission.Â  Any opening
onto a State-owned road will have to be approved by the State Department of
Transportation and the Building Official.
141.05Â Â Â Â LOCATION OF DRIVEWAY.
Where possible, no driveway shall be placed nearer than five (5) feet to the
sidelines of ownerâ€™s property.Â  The driveway flare must remain within the
property lines of the ownerâ€™s property.Â  No driveway shall be within fifteen
(15) feet of any intersection at the property line.
141.06Â Â Â Â METHOD OF CUTTING CURB.
The curb shall be cut utilizing one of the following methods:
1.Â Â Â A thirty (30) inch curb and gutter section shall be saw cut at least six
(6) inches deep and shall be removed and placed to full depth of pavement.
2.Â Â Â If diamond grinding or sawing is utilized, an epoxy sealer shall be placed
on the cut.
141.07Â Â Â Â SIDEWALKS.
The grade of any sidewalk shall not be altered by the work done.Â  The driveway
shall be at the same level as any existing sidewalk.
141.08Â Â Â Â DRIVEWAY REQUIREMENTS.
All driveways shall be paved to the property line in accordance with the
following:
1.Â Â Â Residential.Â  Residential driveways shall be paved with six (6) inches of
Type C IDOT concrete mix or a six (6) inch crushed stone baseÂ  with four (4)
inches asphaltic concrete.
2.Â Â Â Commercial and Industrial.Â  Commercial and industrial driveways shall be
paved with a minimum of seven (7) inches of Type C IDOT concrete mix or a six
(6) inch crushed stone base with seven (7) inches asphaltic concrete.
141.09Â  EXCAVATIONS.
Excavations to do work under this chapter shall be dug so as to occasion the
least possible inconvenience to the public and to provide for the passage of
water along the gutter.Â  All such excavations shall have proper barricades at
all times, and warning lights placed from one-half hour before sunset to one-
half hour after sunrise.Â  In refilling the excavation, the earth must be laid
in layers and each layer tamped thoroughly.Â  Any street, sidewalk or other
public property that is affected by the work shall be restored to as good a
condition as it was previous to the excavation.Â  The affected area shall be
maintained in good repair to the satisfaction of the Council for three months
after refilling.
141.10Â Â Â Â INSPECTION AND APPROVAL.
The driveway must be inspected and approved by the City within thirty (30) days
after completion of the work.Â  The City shall keep a record of such approvals.Â 
If the work is not approved, it must be corrected immediately so it will meet
with the Cityâ€™s approval.Â  If the work has been done improperly, the City shall
have the right to finish or correct the work and shall assess the cost to the
property owner.Â  Such assessment shall be collected with the general property
taxes and in the same manner.
141.11Â Â Â Â EXISTING DRIVEWAYS ALTERED.
Existing driveways being altered or modified which require removal of curbing
must conform to all driveway regulations.Â  Abandonment of existing drives shall
require the removal of existing drop and placement of a full curb conforming to
all City specifications.
CHAPTER 150
BUILDING NUMBERING
Â 
150.01Â  Definitions       150.03Â  Assignment of Numbers
150.02Â  Owner Requirements
Â 
150.01Â  DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined:
1.Â Â Â â€œOwnerâ€ means the owner of the principal building.
2.Â Â Â â€œPrincipal buildingâ€ means the main building on any lot or subdivision
thereof.
150.02Â  OWNER REQUIREMENTS.
Every owner shall comply with the following numbering requirements:
1.Â Â Â Obtain Building Number.Â  The owner shall obtain the assigned number to the
principal building from the Clerk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3d])
2.Â Â Â Display Building Number.Â  The owner shall place or cause to be installed
and maintained on that portion of the principal building which faces the street
and is visible from the street the assigned number in figures not less than
three (3) inches in height and of a contrasting color with their background.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3d])
3.Â Â Â Failure to Comply.Â  If an owner refuses to number a building as herein
provided, or fails to do so for a period of thirty (30) days after being
notified in writing by the City to do so, the City may proceed to place the
assigned number on the principal building and assess the costs against the
property for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3h])
150.03Â  ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS.
Numbers shall be assigned in accordance with the system developed by the
Council.Â  The system consists of consecutive numbering.Â  The even numbers shall
be on the easterly and northerly sides of all streets and the odd numbers shall
be on the westerly and southerly sides of all streets.
CHAPTER 151
TREES
Â 
151.01Â  Definition           151.04Â  Trimming Trees to be Supervised
151.02Â  Planting Restrictions151.05Â  Disease Control
151.03Â  Duty to Trim Trees   151.06Â  Inspection and Removal
Â 
151.01Â  DEFINITION.
For use in this chapter, â€œparkingâ€ means that part of the street, avenue or
highway in the City not covered by sidewalk and lying between the lot line and
the curb line; or, on unpaved streets, that part of the street, avenue or
highway lying between the lot line and that portion of the street usually
traveled by vehicular traffic.
151.02Â  PLANTING RESTRICTIONS.
Trees shall be planted within the parking only in those cases in which trees
cannot be planted adjacent to the parking.Â  No tree shall be planted in any
parking or street except in accordance with Section 165.41 of this Code of
Ordinances.Â  No person shall plant in any parking or street any softwood tree,
fruit-bearing tree or any tree of the kinds commonly known as cottonwood,
poplar, box elder, Chinese elm, evergreen, willow, oak, Russian olive or black
walnut.
151.03Â  DUTY TO TRIM TREES.
The owner or agent of the abutting property shall keep the trees on, or
overhanging the street, trimmed so that all branches will be at least fourteen
(14) feet above the surface of the street and ten (10) feet above the
sidewalks.Â  If the abutting property owner fails to trim the trees, the City
may serve notice on the abutting property owner requiring that such action be
taken within five (5) days.Â  If such action is not taken within that time, the
City may perform the required action and assess the costs against the abutting
property for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2c, d & e])
151.04Â  TRIMMING TREES TO BE SUPERVISED.
Except as allowed in Section 151.03, it is unlawful for any person to trim or
cut any tree in a street or public place unless the work is done under the
supervision of the City.
151.05Â  DISEASE CONTROL.
Any dead, diseased or damaged tree or shrub which may harbor serious insect or
disease pests or disease injurious to other trees is hereby declared to be a
nuisance.
151.06Â  INSPECTION AND REMOVAL.
The Public Works Director shall inspect or cause to be inspected any trees or
shrubs in the City reported or suspected to be dead, diseased or damaged, and
such trees and shrubs shall be subject to the following:
1.Â Â Â Public Property.Â  If it is determined that any such condition exists on
any public property, including the strip between the curb and the lot line of
private property, the Public Works Director may cause such condition to be
corrected by treatment or removal.Â  The Public Works Director may also order
the removal of any trees on the streets of the City which interfere with the
making of improvements or with travel thereon.Â  The City shall be responsible
for the removal of any dead or diseased trees on public property.
2.Â Â Â Private Property.Â  If it is determined with reasonable certainty that any
such condition exists on private property and that danger to other trees or to
adjoining property or passing motorists or pedestrians is imminent, the Public
Works Director shall notify by certified mail the owner, occupant or person in
charge of such property to correct such condition by treatment or removal
within fourteen (14) days of said notification.Â  If such owner, occupant or
person in charge of said property fails to comply within fourteen (14) days of
receipt of notice, the Public Works Director may cause the condition to be
corrected and the cost assessed against the property.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3b & h])
CHAPTER 152
SUMP PUMP AND GROUNDWATER STANDARDS
Â 
152.01Â  Intent                                152.06Â  Surcharge
152.02Â  Prohibited Water                      152.07Â  Nuisance
152.03Â  Sump, Pump and Rigid Pipe Installation152.08Â  Penalty
152.04Â  Inspections                           152.09Â  Hearing
152.05Â  Removal of Connections                Â 
Â 
152.01Â  INTENT.
The intent of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations governing the
installation, use and discharge of sump pumps or other groundwater conveyance
systems and to establish the penalty structures required to enforce said rules
and regulations.Â  The rules and regulations governing the use of sump pumps or
other groundwater conveyance systems are being established:
1.Â Â Â To set forth uniform requirements for the installation, use and discharge
of sump pumps or groundwater conveyance systems.
2.Â Â Â To prevent the introduction of clean surface water, including but not
limited to, water from roof or cellar drains, springs, basement sump pumps and
French drains.
3.Â Â Â Because the City finds it essential to the maintenance of health,
minimization of damage to property, and to maintain and preserve the life and
capacity of the municipal infrastructure.
152.02Â  PROHIBITED WATER.
1.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any owner, occupant or user of any premises to direct
into or allow any storm water, surface water, ground water, well water or water
from industrial or commercial air conditioning systems (residential properties
may have a twenty (20) gallon per day maximum discharge from air conditioning
systems) to drain into the wastewater collection system.Â  No rainspout, or
other form of surface drainage, and no foundation drainage or sump pump shall
be connected or discharged into any wastewater collection system.
2.Â Â Â Any new or existing construction in which a sump and pump have been or
will be installed shall be required to install, inside the structure, a rigid
pipe connection discharge in accordance with this chapter. It is unlawful to
maintain any connection with the sanitary sewer carrying roof water, ground
water, surface water or any other natural precipitation.
152.03Â  SUMP, PUMP AND RIGID PIPE INSTALLATION.
1.Â Â Â A discharge pipe shall be installed through the outside foundation wall of
the building with rigid pipe (plastic, copper or galvanized) one (1) inch
inside diameter minimum, without valves or quick connections that would alter
the path of discharge. The discharge shall be directed away from the foundation
wall.
2.Â Â Â No discharge shall be directed so as to impact neighboring properties.
3.Â Â Â Where a sump pit exists in any building it shall have a pump installed
with rigid piping as specified above.
4.Â Â Â Any plumber licensed in the City of Clear Lake who knowingly installs a
sump, pump and/or piping that is not in conformance with this chapter may lose
their plumbing license privileges in the City for a period of one (1) year,
following the opportunity for a hearing before the City Council.
152.04Â  INSPECTIONS.
Property owners shall allow a City employee or a designated representative,
satisfactory to the City, such as a licensed plumber, to inspect the buildings
to confirm and document that there is no sump pump or other prohibited
discharge into the wastewater collection system. The City may periodically re-
inspect any building or premises to determine compliance with the requirements
of this chapter. An inspection performed by other than a City employee will
require the completion and return of an inspection form provided by the City.
Any plumber licensed in the City of Clear Lake who falsely attests to
documentation regarding compliance with this chapter may lose their plumbing
license privileges in the City for a period of one (1) year, following the
opportunity for a hearing before the City Council.Â  When ownership of any home
or other building is transferred, the building must have a re-inspection
completed and passed within ninety (90) day of the sale date.
152.05Â  REMOVAL OF CONNECTIONS.
1.Â Â Â Any property owner who previously made any connection or installation in
violation of this chapter shall immediately remove such connection or correct
such an installation. If not removed or corrected within 30 calendar days after
notice of the violation has been delivered personally or by certified mail to
the owner, the City shall impose a surcharge in the amount provided by this
chapter. The time frame for making corrections may be extended upon the
approval of the City Administrator for up to 90 days for cause, beyond the
initial 30-day period.
2.Â Â Â The owner of a building or premises found to not be in conformance with
this chapter during periodic re-inspections shall be subjected to a surcharge
as provided herein starting from the previous date of inspection.
152.06Â  SURCHARGE.
1.Â Â Â Any property owner or contractor/builder refusing to allow the property
under their control to be inspected in accordance with this chapter, in order
to determine compliance, shall within 30 days of the date that admittance to
the property is refused or denied, immediately become subject to a monthly
surcharge which shall be applied to the sanitary sewer component of their
utility bill.Â  This surcharge shall commence on the 1st day of the month
following the month when either the property owner or contractor/builder refuse
to allow the property under their control to be inspected by the City or to
otherwise validate compliance in accordance with this chapter to the City.Â 
This surcharge shall continue as long as no documentation satisfactory to the
City, to ascertain compliance with this chapter, has been provided to the
Building Official. This surcharge is intended to offset the added costs
associated with having to treat and collect clear water unnecessarily when the
status of a property's connection to the sanitary sewer system cannot be
ascertained.
2.Â Â Â A surcharge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month is hereby imposed
on every sewer bill to property owners for the following conditions:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Not in compliance with this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Refusal of property inspection.
152.07Â  NUISANCE.
The City may require a property to connect it's sump pump discharge line to a
City storm sewer or drainage tile, if available, and if, in the determination
of the City it is necessary because the discharge from the sump pump is
creating a nuisance or hazardous situation.
152.08Â  PENALTY.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable
to the City for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the City by reason of
such violation. The City will also retain any and all civil remedies including,
but not limited to, injunction or abatement actions to remedy a violation.
152.09Â  HEARING.
Any person aggrieved by any provision of this chapter must request a hearing
before the City Council within 30 days following an inspection or the
imposition of the surcharge.Â  The finding of the City Council shall be final.Â 
Any person aggrieved by the actions of the City Council under the provisions of
this chapter may seek such relief through the Courts as provided by law.
CHAPTER 153
VACATION RENTALS/SHORT-TERM RENTALS
Â 
153.01Â  Definitions             153.03Â  Regulations
153.02Â  Licensing and Permitting
Â 
153.01Â  Â  DEFINITIONS.
1.Â Â Â Vacation Rental(s): Vacation Rental(s) a/k/a Short-Term Rental(s).
"Vacation Rental" or â€œShort-Term Rentalâ€ means any residential property,
dwelling, condominium, or portion thereof that is available for use or is used
for accommodations or lodging of guests, who pay a fee or other compensation,
for a period of less than thirty-one (31) consecutiveÂ  days. "Vacation rentals"
or â€œShort-Term Rentalâ€ means any establishment engaged in the business of
furnishing or providing rooms intended or designed for dwelling, lodging or
sleeping purposes to transient guests and which are known in the trade as such.
The terms "Vacation Rental" or â€œShort-Term Rentalâ€ do not include any hospital,
convalescent or nursing home or sanitarium, or any facility associated with a
hospital providing rooms for medical patients and their families, nor do they
include any hotel, motel, or bed and breakfast facility.
2.Â Â Â Unit. â€œUnitâ€ shall mean any Vacation Rental, Short-Term Rental, or any
portion thereof. In the case of multiple rentals on the same property, each
rental will be considered a separate â€œUnit.â€
3.Â Â Â Local Contact Person. A local person specifically named on the application
and permit who resides within 60 minutes of the city limits of Clear Lake and
who may be contacted twenty-four (24) hours a day if there is an issue or
problem. The Local Contact Person may be the owner or an agent of the owner.
The contact person must be available during the term of the rental.
4.Â Â Â "Owner" means the person(s) or entity(ies) that hold(s) legal and/or
equitable title to the subject short-term vacation rental.
5.Â Â Â "Broker" means any entity or person that offers, lists, advertises,
accepts reservations and/or collects whole or partial payment for a short-term
vacation rental unit and is licensed as such under the laws of the State of
Iowa.Â  A Local Contact Person shall not perform the duties of a Broker without
proper licensure.
153.02Â  Â  LICENSING AND PERMITTING.
1.Â Â Â Districts Where Allowed. Vacation Rentals are allowed in the residential
districts of the City.
2.Â Â Â Permit Required.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A Permit must be obtained for each Unit.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Permit Application Fee. A non-refundable application fee of one hundred
and fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be due at the time of the submission of an
application. This fee is per unit location. Any first time permit shall be
charged pro-rata based on months before the September 30th expiration.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Permit Applications. All permit applications shall be submitted to the
Planning & Zoning and Building Department on approved forms. Applications shall
contain such information as: 1) the location/addressof each Vacation Rental, 2)
the number of bedrooms in each Unit, 3) the property ownerâ€™s name, address, and
phone number, 4) the local contact personâ€™s name, address and phone number, 5)
a proposed parking plan, 6) a copy of a typical rental agreement, 7) sales tax
collection number for the State of Iowa, and 8) any other information
reasonably necessary to establish the required use.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Public Notice of Application. Notices will be mailed via standard mail
to all property owners located within 300 feet of the Vacation Rental within
twenty (20) business days of receipt of the completed application. Property
owners will have ten (10) days from the date of the notice to respond in
writing to the Planning & Zoning Department. Responses to the notice will be
considered in the review process.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Review Process.Â  A permit will be granted within sixty (60) days of the
date of the filing of the application unless the applicant fails to meet the
minimum standard(s) for use of the real property as a Vacation Rental as
outlined herein or for other good cause shown. The review process shall also
include any responses and complaint(s) by citizens in response to the notice.
The review includes staff review of documentation pertaining to the dwelling or
structure, zoning, building codes, and/or other applicable laws or regulations.
Filed complaints involving violations of the zoning ordinance, building codes,
and/or applicable laws or regulations may be a basis for denying a permit.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Copies of violations and complaints shall be made available to the
Applicant. A permit which has been denied may be appealed to the Planning &
Zoning Commission within 10 days of notification of denial and thereafter to
the City Council by presenting copies of the application and any violations and
complaints to the Clerk of the City Council for Council's review and scheduling
of the appeal. The Applicant shall be notified not less than fourteen (14) days
before the scheduled appeal before the City Council.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Term of the Permit. Each Permit shall be for one (1) year and shall
expire on September 30 of each year.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Renewal of Permit.Â  Renewal of each License and Permit may be obtained
for one-hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00). This renewal fee is per permit
location. The Permit renewal process will include City review of City records
and other documentation pertaining to complaints, if any, that have been
received about the specific Unit under consideration. Filed complaints
involving violations of the zoning codes, building codes, and/or applicable
laws or regulations may be a basis for denying a permit renewal.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Approval of a Permit does not legalize any non-permitted use or
structure. Units are not to be used to distribute retail products or personal
services to invitees for marketing or similar purposes. The outdoor display of
goods and merchandise for sale is prohibited.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Licenses and Permits granted pursuant to this Ordinance are non-
transferrable.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Upon the sale and transfer and or change of ownership of the real
property for which a permit has been obtained, the new owner shall apply for a
new permit in accordance with this Ordinance.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Any Unit that is deed-restricted, covenant restricted, and/or
classified as affordable housing shall not be used as a Vacation Rental or
Short-Term rental. Compliance shall be the responsibility of the Applicant.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â Units existing as of May 1, 2017 will have forty five (45) days from
the date of, May 1, 2017, to obtain a permit.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â A Permit may be revoked following the receipt of a written notice of
violation of this Ordinance stating the reasons for any violations. The
Licensee shall have ten (10) days to correct any violation(s). Any revocation
of a Permit by the Planning & Zoning Department may be appealed through the
appeals process set forth herein.
153.03Â  Â  REGULATIONS.
1.Â Â Â Occupancy. The maximum occupancy for a Vacation Rental shall be as
follows: 1) Single bedroom - 2 to 4 guests; 2) Two Bedroom - 4 to 6 guests; 3)
Three Bedroom - 6 to 9 guests; 4) Four Bedroom - 8 to 10 guests; and 5) Five or
more Bedroom - 10 to 12 guests.
2.Â Â Â Parking â€“ Number of Vehicles. In no event shall the maximum number of on-
street vehicles exceed one (1) per unit. This number will be based on off-
street parking availability and on-street conditions. It will be preferred that
the Owner provide off-street parking. In certain circumstances where no off-
street parking exists and on-street constraints exist, the City may require an
off-street parking space to be constructed or secured.
3.Â Â Â Register of Guests. Each Owner shall keep or cause to be kept a register
of guests and keep such register for a period of one (1) year.
4.Â Â Â Nuisance. Owners, Local Contact Persons shall ensure that the occupants of
the Unit do not disturb the peace and enjoyment of the surrounding neighborhood
and area.
5.Â Â Â Premises and Garbage Management. It shall be the duty of every Owner/Local
Contact Person to keep all Units in clean and sanitary condition. Garbage shall
be disposed of in covered dumpsters, if applicable, or in covered containers
and placed at the scheduled pick up, near curb side of street in front of the
dwelling. Containers emptied by the trash collector shall be removed from the
curb within 12 hours after each emptying and placed out of site from the
street.
6.Â Â Â Posting of Rules and Information. Unit rules shall be posted inside the
Unit in a location readily visible by all occupants. The rules shall include
but not be limited to occupancy, parking limits, noise rules, garbage
management, and shall also include the name, address and phone number(s) of the
Owner and Local Contact Person.
7.Â Â Â Local Contact Person. All Vacation Rentals shall designate a Local Contact
Person who will respond to questions or concerns 24-hours a day. Additionally,
the Owner (or designee) shall maintain records of all occupying tenants, rental
agreements, owner information and any other relevant information. The Building
Department shall submit a list of all Units with their respective Owner and
Contact Person and their phone numbers to the City Police Department. The City
Police Department shall immediately notify the Local Contact Person of any
complaint, citation, arrest and or any other concerns of a Vacation Rental, its
lodging and or its occupants.
8.Â Â Â Complaints and Dispute Resolution. Complaints regarding any violation of
this Ordinance will first be directed to the Local Contact Person. If the Local
Contact Person is unable to resolve the issue and/or the issue relates to
public safety, the Local Contact Person will contact the City Police Department
or the appropriate authority.
9.Â Â Â Prohibited Acts. All uses of the property shall be in compliance with
Federal, State and Local Laws and Ordinances.
10.Â Â Â Signs. Any sign(s) for a Vacation Rental shall be determined by the
zoning classification wherein the parcel of land is located.
11.Â Â Â The following regulations shall apply to a Vacation Rental situated on
the Lake:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Parking for boat trailers shall be off street parking only and shall be
a maximum of one trailer per Unit.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Mooring of boats or vessels shall not exceed the width of the parcel
where the Unit is located; shall not be double or greater moored; and shall not
impede the flow of water traffic by any means.
12.Â Â Â Separate Violations. For purposes of prosecution of violations of this
Ordinance, each day that any violation occurs (i.e. rental without a permit) is
deemed to constitute a separate violation. Any person(s), entity, company or
concern that willfully violates this Ordinance shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. Those found guilty of such violation shall, upon conviction, be
fined for each violation not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for
the first offense, not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second
offense within a calendar year, and not exceeding more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for other offenses within a calendar year, plus all court
costs and not more than ninety (90) days in the county jail, or both.
(Ch. 153 â€“ Ord. 826 â€“ May 17 Supp.)

155.01Â  ADOPTION OF STATE BUILDING CODE.
Pursuant to published notice and public hearing, as required by law, the Iowa
State Building Code, promulgated pursuant to Chapter 103A of the Code of Iowa,
is adopted by reference.Â  Official copies of the Iowa State Building Code, the
standard codes adopted therein, and a certified copy of this chapter are on
file in the office of the Clerk.
155.02Â  PERMITS REQUIRED.
1.Â Â Â General.Â  Permits shall be required for all work regulated by this
chapter.Â  No person shall erect, construct, install, enlarge, alter, repair,
move, improve, remove, convert or demolish any building or structure in the
City or commence or proceed with any mechanical, plumbing or electrical
alteration, or cause same to be done, without making application for a permit
for each such building or structure or installation or alteration and receiving
a permit or written approval to commence or proceed from the Building Official.
2.Â Â Â Exceptions.Â  Permits for work regulated by this chapter are not required
of:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Persons doing or causing such work which is performed upon factory-
built structures at the place of manufacture;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A full-time industrial employee doing maintenance work on the
industrial premises of such personâ€™s employer;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An industry doing such work for manufacturing and related purposes in
and upon its manufacturing premises only;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Public utilities or City agencies furnishing electrical power, natural
gas, communication, water or wastewater service in the City, when doing such
work is necessary to provide utility service to the point of connection between
utility or City-owned facilities and customer-owned facilities;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The City and agencies of the City doing such work in and upon public
property.
For purposes of this section, public property is defined as bridges and
streets, alleys, parks and other public land only, and shall not be construed
to mean buildings and structures regulated by this chapter, or apparatus
necessary for the operation of said building.Â  The aforesaid exceptions shall
not relieve any person, including the City, agencies of the City, and Federal,
State, County and other local governmental agencies and subdivisions,
industries, and public utilities, of the requirement to construct, install,
alter or demolish any building, structure or apparatus regulated by this
chapter in accordance with this chapter, and the requirement to comply with
Chapter 166 of this Code of Ordinances.
155.03Â  APPLICATION FOR PERMITS.
To obtain a permit, the applicant shall complete an application on a form
furnished by the Building Official and file same with the Building Official.Â 
The permit application shall:
1.Â Â Â Identify and describe the work to be covered by the permit for which
application is made;
2.Â Â Â Describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by lot, block,
tract, and house and street address, or similar description that will readily
identify and definitely locate the proposed building or work;
3.Â Â Â Indicate the use or occupancy for which the proposed work is intended;
4.Â Â Â Be accompanied by plans and specifications as required herein;
5.Â Â Â State the valuation of the proposed work;
6.Â Â Â Be signed by the applicant or an authorized agent who may be required to
submit evidence to indicate such authority;
7.Â Â Â Give such other information as reasonably may be required by the Building
Official.
155.04Â  PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
When required by the Building Official for enforcement of any provisions of
this chapter, two sets of plans and specifications shall be submitted with
applications for permits required under this chapter.Â  The Building Official
may further require such plans and specifications to be prepared and designed
by an engineer or architect licensed by the State.Â  When authorized by the
Building Official, plans and specifications need not be submitted for the
following:
1.Â Â Â One story buildings of type V conventional wood-stud construction with an
area not exceeding six hundred (600) square feet;
2.Â Â Â Group J, division I, occupancies of type V conventional wood-stud
construction;
155.05Â  ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
The application, plans and specifications as required herein and filed by an
applicant for a permit, shall be checked by the Building Official.Â  Such plans
may be reviewed by other departments of the City to check compliance with
regulations under the jurisdiction of such departments.
1.Â Â Â Mechanical, Plumbing and Electrical Permits.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Application Requirements.Â  If the Building Official is satisfied that
the mechanical, plumbing or electrical work described in a permit application
and the plans filed therewith comply with the requirements of this chapter,
such official shall indicate, on the application, approval to commence or
proceed with such work.Â  Upon completion of the application, approval of same
by the Building Official and payment of the fee specified herein by the
applicant, a permit therefor shall be issued to the applicant.Â  Electrical and
plumbing permits shall be issued only to licensed electricians and licensed
plumbers, respectively.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exception.Â  Any permit required under this subsection may be issued to
the owner of a single family dwelling which is used exclusively for living
purposes to do work regulated by this chapter in and upon said dwelling,
including the usual accessory buildings, provided that the dwelling and
accessory buildings will be occupied by the owner, that the owner appears
before the Building Official and shows himself or herself competent to do such
work, and that the owner personally purchases all materials and performs all
labor in connection with the work.Â  A bond will not be required.Â  All work done
in accordance with this exception must meet all the requirements of this
chapter and shall be inspected like any other work.
2.Â Â Â Emergencies.Â  In emergency situations, work may be initiated without first
submitting a permit application.Â  However, a permit application must be
submitted within a reasonable time after the passage of the critical period.Â 
With this one exception, all emergency work must be done in accordance with
this chapter.
3.Â Â Â Plan Approval.Â  When the Building Official issues the permit or gives
approval to commence or proceed, such official shall endorse in writing or
stamp on both sets of plans or specifications â€œAPPROVED.â€Â  Such approved plans
and specifications shall not be changed, modified or altered without
authorization from the Building Official, and all work shall be done in
accordance with the approved plans.Â  The Building Official may issue a permit
for the construction of a part of a building or structure before the entire
plans and specifications for the whole building or structure have been
submitted or approved, provided adequate information and detailed statements
have been filed complying with all pertinent requirements of this chapter.Â  The
holder of such permit shall proceed at his/her own risk without assurance that
the permit for the entire building or structure will be granted.
4.Â Â Â Retention of Plans.Â  One set of approved plans, specifications and
computations shall be retained by the Building Official for a period of not
less than ninety (90) days from the date of completion of the work covered
therein, and one set of approved plans and specifications shall be returned to
the applicant, which set shall be kept at the site of such building or work at
all times during which the work authorized thereby is in progress.Â  Plans
submitted for checking, for which no permit is used, and on which no action is
taken by the applicant for ninety (90) days, shall be returned to the last
known address of the applicant.Â  To renew action on said plans, a payment of a
new plan-check fee shall be required.
5.Â Â Â Validity.Â  The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and
specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for or approval of, any
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.Â  No permit presuming to
give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter shall be
valid except insofar as the work or use which it authorized is lawful.Â  The
issuance of a permit based upon plans and specifications shall not prevent the
Building Official from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said
plans and specifications or from stopping building operations being carried on
thereunder when in violation of this chapter or of any ordinances of the City.
6.Â Â Â Expiration.Â  Every permit or written approval to commence or proceed
issued by the Building Official under the provisions of this chapter shall
expire by limitation and become null and void if the building or work
authorized by such permit or approval is suspended or abandoned for a period of
sixty (60) days at any time after the work is commenced.Â  Before such work can
be recommenced, a new permit or written approval to commence or proceed shall
first be obtained, and the fee therefor shall be one-half of the amount
required for the original permit or approval to commence or proceed with such
work, provided no changes have been made or will be made in the original plans
and specifications for such work, and provided further that such suspension or
abandonment has not exceeded one hundred eighty (180) days.
7.Â Â Â Exceptions.Â  In those cases where, in the considered judgment of the
Building Official, the holder of a permit or written approval to commence or
proceed with work regulated by this chapter is using the provisions of this
subsection to evade or delay compliance with the intent of a lawful notice and/
or order issued under this chapter, the Building Official may revoke such
permit or written approval and re-issue, reducing the time period allowed to
commence work to a minimum of five (5) days and the time period allowed for
suspension of work to a minimum of five (5) days.Â  The fee for such re-issued
permit or written approval shall be equal to that required for a new permit.
8.Â Â Â Suspension or Revocation.Â  The Building Official may, in writing, suspend
or revoke a permit or approval to commence or proceed issued under provisions
of this chapter whenever the permit is issued in error, or on the basis of
incorrect information supplied, or in violation of any ordinance of the City.
155.06Â  CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
1.Â Â Â Use or Occupancy.Â  No building or structure in Groups A to H inclusive, as
defined in the Uniform Building Code, shall be used or occupied, and no change
in the existing occupancy classification of a building or structure, or portion
thereof, shall be made until the Building Official has issued a certificate of
occupancy therefor, as provided herein.
2.Â Â Â Change in Use.Â  Changes in the character or use of a building shall not be
made except as specified in Section 502 of the Uniform Building Code.
3.Â Â Â Certificate Issued.Â  After final inspection, when it is found that the
building or structure complies with the provisions of this chapter, the
Building Official shall issue a certificate of occupancy which shall contain
the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The building permit number;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The address of the building;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The name and address of the owner;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A description of that portion of the building for which the certificate
was issued;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â A statement that the described portion of the building complies with
the requirement of the State Building Code and this chapter for the group of
occupancy in which the proposed occupancy is classified;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The name of the Building Official.
4.Â Â Â Temporary Certificate.Â  A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued
by the Building Official for the use of a portion or portions of a building or
structure prior to the completion of the entire building or structure.
5.Â Â Â Posting.Â  The certificate of occupancy shall be posted in a conspicuous
place on the premises and shall not be removed by anyone except the Building
Official.
155.07Â  INSPECTIONS.
1.Â Â Â General.Â  All construction or work for which a permit is required shall be
subject to inspection by the Building Official, and certain types of
construction shall have continuous inspection by special inspectors, as
specified herein.Â  A survey of the lot may be required by the Building Official
to verify compliance of the structure with approved plans.
2.Â Â Â Approval Required.Â  No work shall be done on any part of the building or
structure beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without
first obtaining the writtenÂ  approval of the Building Official.Â  Such written
approval shall be given only after an inspection shall have been made of each
successive step in the construction as indicated by each of the inspections
required herein.Â  There shall be a final inspection and approval on all
buildings when completed and ready for occupancy.
3.Â Â Â Required Inspections.Â  The Building Official, upon notification from the
holder of a permit or approval to commence or proceed, or said permit holderâ€™s
agent, shall make the following inspections and shall either approve that
portion of the construction as completed or shall notify the holder or agent
wherein the same fails to comply with this chapter.Â  Reinforcing steel or
structural framework of any part of any building or structure shall not be
covered or concealed without first obtaining the approval of the Building
Official:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Temporary electrical service and pole.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Foundation inspection - to be made after trenches are excavated and
forms erected and when all materials for the foundation are delivered on the
job.Â  Where concrete from a central mixing plant (commonly termed â€œtransit
mixedâ€) is to be used, materials need not be on the job.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Frame inspection - to be made after the roof, all framing, fire-
blocking, and bracing are in place and pipes, chimneys, and vents are complete.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Electrical, plumbing, mechanical - to be made when all â€œroughing inâ€ is
complete and before any finish is applied.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Lath and/or wallboard inspection â€“ to be made after all lathing and/or
wallboard, interior and exterior, is in place; but before any plastering is
applied or before wallboard joints and fasteners are taped and finished.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Final inspection - to be made after construction, installation or
alteration work is completed and ready for use/or occupancy.Â  Final inspections
will be required for building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical.
4.Â Â Â Removal of Covering for Inspection.Â  The inspector shall have the
authority to remove or cause the removal of lath, plaster boarding or other
covering which may prevent the proper inspection of any item for which a permit
has been issued or for which a permit is required.
5.Â Â Â Time of Filing Request for Inspection.Â  The Building Official may require
that every request for inspection be filed at least one day before such
inspection is desired.Â  Such request may be in writing or by telephone at the
option of the Building Official.
6.Â Â Â Other Inspection.Â  In addition to the call inspections specified above,
the Building Official may make or require any other inspections of any
construction, installation or alteration work to ascertain compliance with the
provisions of this chapter.
155.08Â  FEE SCHEDULE.
1.Â Â Â Building Permit Fees.Â  Building permit fees shall be charged in amounts as
set out in the Uniform Building Code edition adopted by the State Building Code
and as the same may be subsequently revised or amended.Â  Where work for which a
permit is required by this code is started or proceeded with prior to obtaining
said permit, the fees shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee
shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this
code in the execution of the work or from any other penalties prescribed in
Section 155.09.
2.Â Â Â Plan-Checking Fees.Â  When the valuation of the proposed construction
exceeds $1,000.00 and a plan is required to be submitted by subsection (c) of
Section 301, a plan-checking fee shall be paid to the Building Official at the
time of submitting plans and specifications for checking.Â  Said plan-checking
fee shall be the actual cost of such plan checking to the City.
155.09Â  PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS.
Any person who violates, omits, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with or
who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall,
upon conviction, be subject to penalty for violation of this Code of
Ordinances.Â  After notification in writing by the Building Official, each day
that a violation is permitted to exist beyond the expiration of the time
designated in said notice shall constitute a separate offense.Â  In case any
building or structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered,
repaired, converted, or maintained, or any building, structure, or land is used
in violation of this chapter, the Council, in addition to other remedies, may
institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful
erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion,
maintenance, or use; to restrain, correct or abate such violation; to prevent
the occupancy of said building, structure or land; or to prevent any illegal
act, conduct, business or use in or about such premises.

165.01Â  PURPOSE.
This chapter is adopted for the purpose of promoting public health, safety,
comfort, order and general welfare; to conserve and protect the natural and
manmade environment, as well as the value of property throughout the City; to
encourage the most appropriate use of land; to secure and provide the social
and economic advantages resulting from an orderly, planned use of land
resources, and to facilitate adequate but economical provisions for public
improvements, such as, but not limited to, the provision of transportation,
water, sewage disposal, schools, parks and other public requirements; to lessen
congestion in the streets; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue
concentration of population; all in accordance with and as permitted by the
provisions of Chapter 414 of the State Code of Iowa.
165.02Â  GENERAL EFFECT.
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the use of premises and
structures in the City shall be in accordance with the minimum standards
hereinafter established.
1.Â Â Â Generally, for all R Zones (except the LR Zone) the following minimum yard
requirements â€  will be enforced:
Front YardÂ Â Â 25 feet (See Sec. 165.39 for exceptions.)
Side YardÂ Â Â 5 feet for first story, plus 3 feet for each additional story, or
fraction thereof that a building exceeds one story in height; on corner lots,
the side yard on the street side shall not be less than 25 feet (See Sec.
165.37 for additional side yard requirements.)
Rear Yard Â Â Â 20 feet.Â  An accessory building may be located in a rear yard but
shall not be closer than 5 feet from a rear or side lot line.
2.Â Â Â No use which is permitted as a conditional use under this chapter shall be
established or enlarged except as permitted by the Board of Adjustment.
3.Â Â Â The Planning and Zoning Commission will require developers to dedicate
land for public purposes pursuant to Chapter 166 of this Code of Ordinances
(Subdivision Ordinance) when appropriate.
4.Â Â Â The yards, parking spaces, or lot area required for one structure or use
under this chapter cannot be used to meet the requirements for another
structure or use, unless the two lots are adjoined by covenant for zoning
purposes.Â  (See Sec. 165.07 â€“ Multi-lot Building Site.)
5.Â Â Â Every use or structure erected or structurally altered shall be located on
a lot as herein defined, and the number of uses and structures permitted on a
lot shall be as follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In the RS Zones, there shall not be more than one (1) principal use or
building on a lot.Â  There may, however, be more than one (1) accessory use or
structure on a lot.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In all other zones, there may be more than one (1) principal use,
building and accessory use and structure on a lot.
6.Â Â Â Whenever any street, road or other public way is vacated by official
action of the City, the zoning district adjoining each side of such street,
road or public way shall be extended automatically to the center of such
vacation and all area included in the vacation shall be subject to all the
regulations of the extended district.
7.Â Â Â No basement shall be occupied for residential purposes until the remainder
of the building has been substantially completed.
8.Â Â Â No structure shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or
structurally altered, nor any use established or enlarged:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To exceed the height limit herein established for the zone in which the
structure is located.Â  If said structure is located in an area regulated by the
Mason City Municipal Airport zoning, any lower height requirement of that
zoning regulation shall prevail.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Except in conformity with the area regulations for the zone in which
the use or structure is located.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Except in conformity with the yard regulations for the zone in which
the building is located.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Except in conformity with the off-street parking regulations for the
zone in which the use or structure is located.
9.Â Â Â Any portion of a building or any structure attached to the building shall
be considered as part of the building for purposes of height and yard
requirements of this chapter unless otherwise provided.

165.03Â  DEFINITIONS.
The following definitions are applicable to this chapter unless a contrary
meaning is indicated by the text.Â  The word â€œbuildingâ€ includes â€œstructure.â€Â 
Terms not defined shall have the meaning customarily assigned to them in
Websterâ€™s New Collegiate Dictionary.Â  Uses not defined or listed shall have the
meanings as defined in or categorized according to the Standard Industrial
Classification (SIC) Manual, Superintendent of Documents, U.S. Government
Printing Office.
1.Â Â Â â€œAbutâ€ or â€œabuttingâ€ means contiguous; having a boundary, wall or property
line in common.
2.Â Â Â â€œAccessâ€ means the place, means or way by which pedestrians or vehicles
shall have ingress and egress to a property or parking area.
3.Â Â Â â€œAccessory apartmentâ€ means a temporary accessory dwelling unit located
within an owner-occupied single-family dwelling and meeting the requirements
stated herein.
4.Â Â Â â€œAccessory building/useâ€ means a building or use which:Â  (a) is
subordinate to and serves a principal building or use; (b) is subordinate in
area, extent or purpose to the principal building or use served; (c)
contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the
principal building or use; and (d) except for off-street parking as provided in
Sec. 165.33(4), is located on the same lot as or across a street, alley or
railroad right-of-way from the principal use.
5.Â Â Â â€œAdditionâ€ means an extension or increase in floor area or height of a
building or structure.
6.Â Â Â â€œAgedâ€ means any person who is eligible because of age to receive old age
insurance benefits under Section 202A, Title II, of the Social Security Act.Â 
(See Social Security Act and Related Law, April, 1982, edition.)
7.Â Â Â â€œAisleâ€ means an asphalt, concrete or similar permanent dust-free surface
which is connected directly to a parking or loading space and designed to
permit ingress or egress of a vehicle to or from the parking or loading space.Â 
(See Figure 6.)Â  In no case can an aisle be a drive; see definition for
â€œdrive.â€
8.Â Â Â â€œAlleyâ€ means an opened public way which is intended only for use as a
secondary means of vehicular access to abutting property.
9.Â Â Â â€œAlter/Alterationâ€ means a structural alteration, enlargement or
remodeling of a building, or the moving of a building from one location to
another.
10.Â Â Â â€œApartment houseâ€ or â€œapartment buildingâ€ â€“ see â€œdwelling, multi-family
unit.â€
11.Â Â Â â€œAssessed valueâ€ means the value of real property as established by the
County Assessor, or by a higher authority upon appeal, and is the value upon
which the next fiscal yearâ€™s real estate taxes are based.

165.04Â  OFFICIAL ZONING MAP.
The City of Clear Lake is hereby divided into zoning districts as shown on the
Cityâ€™s Official Zoning Map in order to classify, regulate and restrict the
location of trades, industries and the location of buildings designed for
specified uses; to regulate and limit the height and use of buildings hereafter
erected or structurally altered; to regulate and limit the intensity of use and
the lot areas; and to regulate and determine the areas of yards, courts and
other open spaces surrounding such buildings.Â  Together with all explanatory
matter thereon, it is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of
this chapter.Â  If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes
are made in zoning boundaries or other matter portrayed on the Official Zoning
Map, such changes shall be entered on the Official Zoning Map promptly after
the amendment has been approved by the governing body, with an entry on the
Official Zoning Map as follows:
â€œOnÂ  Â  (date)Â  , by official action of the City Council, the following change
(s) were made in the Official Zoning Map:Â  (brief description).
No amendment to this chapter which involves matters portrayed on the Official
Zoning Map shall become effective until after such change and entry has been
made on said map. â€

165.06Â  ZONE BOUNDARIES.
Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of any of the aforesaid zones,
the zone boundaries are either lot lines or the centerlines of streets and
alleys, unless otherwise shown, and where the zones designated are bounded
approximately by street, alley or lot lines and are not dimensioned otherwise,
the lot lines of streets and alleys shall be construed to be the boundary of
the zone.
165.07Â  MULTI-LOT BUILDING SITE.
If two or more abutting lots or portions thereof become in single ownership,
the land involved shall be deemed a single parcel for the purposes of this
chapter and shall be so recorded on the property deed as a covenant.Â  No
portion of said parcel shall be sold or used in a manner which diminishes
compliance with lot frontage, width and area requirements.Â 
165.08Â  INTERIM DEVELOPMENT ZONE (ID).
This zone is intended to provide for areas of managed growth within the
corporate limits of the City in which agricultural and other non-urban uses of
land may continue, until such time as the City is able to provide municipal
services and urban development can take place.Â  All lands which are hereafter
voluntarily annexed by the City and which have not been designated within any
zoning district shall automatically be zoned as ID until the City Council has
officially acted, by their own volition or request, to place said lands within
the zoning district deemed appropriate and as provided in Section 165.49(1).Â 
Upon provision of municipal services, the City will and the property owner may
initiate rezoning of property to uses consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.Â 
ID designations on the zoning map shall be re-evaluated with each revision of
the Comprehensive Plan.Â  ID designations shall consist of ID-RS (single-family
residential) and ID-RM (multi-family residential) to reflect the intended use
of the property in the future.
1.Â Â Â Permitted Uses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Farms, farm buildings, other than those used for truck gardens,
orchards and nurseries.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Farm dwellings, provided they are developed in accordance with the
dimensional requirements of the Rural Residential (RR-1) zone.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The raising of crops.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Temporary buildings.
2.Â Â Â Provisional Uses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Clubs, subject to the requirements of Section 165.30.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Single-family dwellings, other than farm dwellings, provided they are
developed in accordance with the applicable special provisions of this zone.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Stables, kennels and veterinary establishments subject to the
requirements of Section 165.30.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Transient enterprises, such as carnivals, circus rides and shows.
3.Â Â Â Conditional Uses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Public utilities.

to the requirements of Section 165.30.

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Livestock and livestock operations, except livestock feed lots and

165.17AÂ  LAKEFRONT MIXED-USE ZONE (LMU).
The LMU Zone is designed to implement the recommendations and re-development
concept strategies of the Clear Lake Lakefront Commercial Districts Special
Development Plan.Â  This plan focuses on commercial, recreational and open
space, and tourism opportunities in selected areas along Clear Lake lakefront.Â 
The zone is intended to promote a combination and variety of permitted or
conditionally permitted uses such as medium and high-density residential,
certain commercial uses, and water-oriented uses, utilizing "form-based"
standards to assure compatible development.Â  These regulations provide a
maximum building envelope and establish requirements for mixing uses on the
street level of multi-story buildings that take advantage of their special
provisions.Â  Because of the limited opportunities appropriate for mixed use
development around Clear Lake, these provisions allow building envelope and
bulk requirements different from those of surrounding properties.Â  District
objectives include retaining or improving views of the shoreline from the lake;
and encouraging and promoting a high-quality design.Â  District provisions are
intended to be consistent with the City's comprehensive plan and subsequent
amendments such as the Clear Lake Lakefront Commercial Districts Special
Development Plan.
1.Â Â Â Permitted Uses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Mixed-Uses.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â A mixed-use building that combines permitted or conditionally
permitted residential, commercial, recreational, and public and civic uses
meeting the "form-based standards" of this zone.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Commercial Uses.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Owner-occupied bed and breakfast homes subject to the requirements
of Sections 165.30 and 165.33.

Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Medical facilities, including nursing and personal care.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Offices and business centers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Personal services, including establishments or places of business
primarily engaged in the provision of services of a personal nature, including
instructional or informational offerings, and nonprofessional services of a
personal nature.Â  Personal service uses include beauty and barber shops;
seamstress, tailor or shoe repair shops; photography studios; health or fitness
centers; dance or music studios; and handicraft, art, and hobby instruction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Eating & drinking and entertainment establishments, including
lounges and restaurants providing table service to customers and/or
accommodation to walk-in clientele.Â  Drive through services relating to eating
and drinking establishments are prohibited in the LMU Zone.Â 
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Retail services, including sale with incidental service of goods

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The maximum height of the surface of any single continuous faÃ§ade

Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Pitched roofs are preferred for all building types, consistent with

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â The highest point of the roof measured from the height of the

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Mansard roofs or other roof forms that appear to extend the

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Gables that run perpendicular to the lakeshore or primary

Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Impervious Surfaces - 90% maximum coverage.Â  Stormwater in an LMU

Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Maximum Residential Density:Â  1 dwelling unit per 1,000 square feet

Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Maximum Floor Area Ratio:Â  4.0
