requirement.Â  Indoor parking uses to support residential or non-residential
uses shall not be credited toward satisfaction of this requirement.
4.Â Â Â Planning and Zoning Commission Review and City Council Approval.Â  The
following "form-based" standards shall apply to all new buildings and
alterations to existing buildings, with exception of minor alterations that do
not add height to an existing building or increase the footprint of the
building by more than 500 square feet.Â  Each application for development within
an LMU Zone shall be reviewed by the Planning and Zoning Commission with its
recommendation(s) being forwarded to the City Council for final approval, based
on the following criteria:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The scale and architectural quality of the project shall be appropriate
to its location along the lakefront.Â  Buildings may be larger or more massive
than their neighbors, but shall include elements and articulation that provide
lakefront scale and character.Â  These elements include, but are not limited to,
varied faÃ§ade planes, turrets, faÃ§ade details, gables, balconies, and window
treatments.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Building materials should be consistent with materials used
traditionally and currently along the lakefront.Â  FaÃ§ade materials may include
clapboard, cement or metal siding, shingles, brick, stone or cast stone, and
other high-quality materials.Â  Generally, metal and concrete masonry units
should be avoided as major faÃ§ade elements.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The building shall provide an active and varied lake faÃ§ade.Â  Site
planning should provide access and good lake exposure for residents and/or
customers.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Buildings shall provide attractive facades along fronting streets,
providing clear entrances and transparency to the adjacent street.Â  Non-
residential mixed uses shall have a distinct entrance to their principle
frontage streets.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The building should be appropriate to its context and its design should
reflect the unique or unusual qualities of its individual site and surrounding
environment.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Signage shall be consistent in scale with uses in the general area or
the overall theme of the building.Â 
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Principal building colors should consist of subtle, neutral or muted
colors with low reflectance, such as warm earth-toned colors.Â  Bright or
primary colors may be used only as accents occupying a maximum of 15% of the
building faÃ§ade.
In reviewing development proposals, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall
instruct the Building Official to prepare a written statement to be presented
to the City Council that summarizes the findings of the Commission for each of
the above criteria and any specific findings of fact that support its decision.
5.Â Â Â General Provisions.Â  All principal and accessory uses permitted within
this zone are subject to the requirements of the following sections of this
chapter:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Existing single-family and two-family dwellings anywhere in the LMU
Zone shall be considered permitted uses, rather than nonconforming uses.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All dwelling units shall be "owner-occupied".Â  The developer of any
residential condominium project shall submit a copy of the proposed covenants
and/or by-laws and condominium declarations of the proposed development as part

165.19Â  NEIGHBORHOOD COMMERCIAL ZONE (CN-1).
The Neighborhood Commercial Zone (CN-1) is intended to permit the development
of retail sales and personal services required to meet the day-to-day needs of
a fully-developed residential neighborhood.Â  Stores, businesses and offices in
this zone should be useful to the majority of the neighborhood residents,
should be economically supportable by nearby population, should not draw
community-wide patronage and should be developed upon full development of the
surrounding residential neighborhoods.Â  A grocery store or grocery store,
drugstore combination is favored as the principal tenant in a neighborhood
commercial zone.Â  In general, the CN-1 Zone is intended for the grouping of a
grocery store and small retail businesses and office uses which are relatively
nuisance-free to surrounding residences and which do not detract from the
residential purpose and character of the surrounding neighborhood.Â  The
location and development of neighborhood commercial sites should follow the
criteria set forth for such sites in the Comprehensive Plan.

165.27Â  PUBLIC ZONE (P).
It is intended that the Public Zone (P) provide reference on the zoning map to
public uses of land.Â  Thus, land owned or otherwise controlled by the Federal
Government, the State of Iowa, Cerro Gordo County, the City of Clear Lake and
the Clear Lake Community School District will be designated a Public Zone (P).Â 
This designation is intended to serve a notice function to those owning or
buying land in proximity to publicly owned land, which is not ordinarily
subject to the regulations of this chapter.
1.Â Â Â Permitted Uses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Farms.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Use of land, buildings or structures of the aforementioned Federal and
State governments or political subdivisions thereof.
2.Â Â Â Provisional Uses.Â  None.
3.Â Â Â Conditional Uses.Â  None.
4.Â Â Â Dimensional Requirements.Â  None.
5.Â Â Â General Provisions.Â  None.
6.Â Â Â Special Provisions.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Should any such land be sold, conveyed or transferred to anyone other
than the government of the United States of America or the State of Iowa or a
political subdivision thereof, the buyer or transferee must submit an
application to the City for a rezoning to a zone other than the Public Zone (P)
in accordance with Section 165.49.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Land which is acquired by the government of the United States of
America or the State of Iowa or a political subdivision thereof after the
effective date of this chapter shall retain its existing zoning designation
until such time as, pursuant to Section 165.49, the zoning map is amended to
designate such land a Public Zone(P).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Before any such land is conveyed by leasehold interest to anyone other
than the Federal and State governments or political subdivisions thereof for a
use other than permitted in this zone, rezoning to an appropriate zone in which
the use is allowed shall be obtained.Â  The use shall be subject to all
requirements of the zone in which it is allowed.Â  Further, the zone shall be
established as an overlay zone, with the underlying zone retaining its original
designation of P.
165.28Â  GREENBELT CORRIDOR OVERLAY (OGC) ZONE.
The Greenbelt [Clear Creek (Outlet Creek) and Willow Creek and their adjacent
lands] is a valuable natural resource, an essential element in local sewer,
water and recreational systems and serves important biological and ecological
functions.Â  The Greenbelt also functions as one of the areaâ€™s most significant
natural amenities which plays an important role in the ongoing development
within the City.Â  The prevention and mitigation of irreversible damage to this
resource and the preservation and enhancement of its natural, cultural and
historic values is in furtherance of the health, safety and general welfare of
the City of Clear Lake.
1.Â Â Â Purpose.Â  The purpose of the Greenbelt Corridor Overlay Zone is to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Protect and preserve Clear Creek and Willow Creek as natural
drainageways and sources of ground and surface water.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Conserve the natural resources of the Greenbelt so that the Greenbelt
retains its value as a significant amenity to the community.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Provide for compatible land uses.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Ensure orderly development within the length of the Greenbelt located
in the City.
2.Â Â Â Intent.Â  The intent of the Greenbelt Corridor Overlay Zone is to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Ensure responsible development that will result in the least possible
amount of storm water runoff and erosion within the Greenbelt corridor.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Ensure responsible development that will not impair either the publicâ€™s
visual access to the Greenbelt or the publicâ€™s view from the Greenbelt.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Encourage the development of a 100-foot vegetative buffer between the
creeksâ€™ banks and new development.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Encourage the use of natural vegetation or other appropriate means of
erosion control that are in keeping with the intent of this zone.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Encourage the preservation of overstory vegetation for erosion control
and for aesthetic purposes.
3.Â Â Â Establishment of the Greenbelt Corridor Zone.Â  The OGC Zone, with its
attendant regulations, is hereby established as part of this chapter.Â  The OGC
Zone shall overlay all other zones established within the boundaries as
described in the following subsection.
4.Â Â Â OGC Zone Boundaries.Â  The OGC Zone shall apply to the Greenbelt corridor
which generally follows or is within the 100-year Flood Boundary.Â  The 100-year
Flood Boundary is delineated on the Cityâ€™s official floodplain map (Flood
Insurance Study, August 4, 1987) on file in the office of the City Clerk and
shall be available for inspection and copying.
5.Â Â Â Permitted Uses.Â  Uses permitted in the OGC Zone shall be the same as those
otherwise allowed in the underlying zone subject to the following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance with the Floodplain Management Ordinance where applicable.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A 30-foot horizontal setback from the 100-year Flood Boundary line,
except that any owner/developer shall be allowed to build a pedestrian and/or
bicycle path in the 30-foot setback area; in the event that the floodway
encroachment line and the creek bank are not the same, the basis of the setback
shall be at the discretion of the owner/developer.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Land-use capability suitable to the type of development proposed, as
determined by evaluation of soils, slope and vegetation, according to the
specified development limitations of soil types published in the U.S.
Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Serviceâ€™s Soil Survey of Cerro
Gordo County, Iowa, issued October, 1981, or any subsequent amendments thereto.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Storm water management in conformance with the Comprehensive Plan and
the City Public Works Department.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Erosion control in conformance with the City Public Works Department.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Retention or replacement of vegetation that provides bank stability in
the floodway and/or the setback area.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Screening shall be provided in accordance with Section 165.43.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Signs, except public signs, shall not be located within 100 feet of the
floodway encroachment line unless located only where they do not impair visual
access to the river and where they cannot be viewed from the river.
6.Â Â Â Site Plan Requirements.Â  No building permit shall be issued until a site
plan has been prepared and approved in accordance with the general requirements
and special provisions of this zone and Chapter 166, Subdivision Regulations,
where applicable.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Exemptions.Â  No site plan shall be required for a single-family
dwelling or for the extension, enlargement, change or alteration thereof, or
accessory structures thereto.Â  However, upon application for a building permit,
the Building Official shall require such additional information as necessary to
determine compliance with the regulations of this zone.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Site Plan Contents.Â  In addition to standard site plan requirements of
Chapter 166, the following information shall be provided on or within the site
plan.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Contours at 2-foot intervals and a clear delineation of all
streams, including intermittent streams, water bodies and wetlands located on
the site.Â  The 100-year Flood Boundary shall also be indicated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Location of the 30-foot setback area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Existing drainage of the storm water, including the direction,
volume and at what rate storm water is conveyed from the site, and the areas of
the site where storm water collects and is gradually percolated into the ground
or slowly released to a tributary stream or the river.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Types and location of the soils of the site, as well as a soil
report containing information on the suitability of the soils for the type of
development, as published in the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil
Conservation Serviceâ€™s Soil Survey of Cerro Gordo County, Iowa, issued October,
1981, or any subsequent amendments thereto.Â  All areas proposed for grading
shall be identified by soil type, both as to soil type of the existing topsoil
and soil type of the new contour.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Location and amounts of excavated soils to be stored on site during
construction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â A description of any features, buildings or areas which are listed
by the Iowa State Division of Historic Preservation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Location, type, size and general description of existing
vegetation, vegetation proposed for removal and proposed landscape materials
which will be added to the site as part of the development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â An erosion control and sedimentation plan which meets the approval
of the Public Works Department.
7.Â Â Â Special Provisions.Â  If an owner/developer of a residentially zoned

165.29Â  PLANNED DEVELOPMENT HOUSING OVERLAY (OPD-H) ZONE.
The OPD-H Zone is established to permit flexibility in the use and design of
structures and land in situations where conventional development may be
inappropriate and where modifications of requirements of the underlying zone
will not be contrary to the intent and purpose of the Zoning Ordinance,
inconsistent with the Comprehensive Plan or harmful to the neighborhood in
which they are located.
1.Â Â Â Intent.Â  The intent of the PDH regulations is to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Provide flexibility in architectural design, placement and clustering
of buildings, use of open space, provision of circulation facilities and
parking, and related site and design considerations.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Encourage the preservation and best use of existing environmentally
sensitive areas and landscape features through development sensitive to the
natural features of the surrounding area.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Promote efficient land use with smaller networks of utilities and
streets.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Encourage and preserve opportunities for energy efficient development.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Promote an attractive and safe living environment which is compatible
with surrounding residential developments.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Provide an alternative method for redeveloping older residential areas
and to encourage infill development.
2.Â Â Â Applicability.Â  Planned development housing shall be permitted in R Zones
as follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â For an undeveloped area of land of 2 acres or more.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For development of areas of land containing less than 2 acres but more
than 1 acre, where, because of existing environmentally sensitive areas, or
natural features, or the land is completely surrounded by development, or the
age of existing development or scenic assets, such development is more
appropriate and more efficient than conventional development.Â  (See Section
165.29(10) for specific standards relating to developments of less than 2
acres.)
3.Â Â Â Preliminary PDH Plan.Â  The owner of an area of land meeting the
requirements of subsection 2 of this section who wishes to develop in
accordance with the provisions of this section shall submit to the Building
Official three (3) copies of a preliminary PDH plan and application for
preliminary approval.Â  The preliminary PDH plan for the use and development of
the area of land shall list all requested variations from requirements of the
particular zone in which the tract of land is located.Â  The preliminary PDH
plan may show a range of dimensions and need not have the specificity of the
final plan.Â  The application shall be accompanied by the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A location map affixed to the plan.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A preliminary PDH plan of the proposed development drawn to scale of 1"
= 100', showing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Contours at 5-foot intervals or less and site topographic features.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Approximate location of all proposed streets and streets abutting
the development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Proposed uses of the land and surrounding land use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Number of dwelling units proposed for the planned development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Proposed general arrangement of the buildings.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Location and area of proposed open space areas (either to be held
in common or publicly and whether to be used for active recreation purposes or
only as an environmental amenity), parking areas, access drives, walks, and
landscaping and planting areas.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Sketches to indicate the general design of building types and the
overall character of the development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Legal description of the planned development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Existing utility or other easements.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â Development stages and timing of each, if applicable.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (11)Â Â Â Approximate location of and natural landscape features and/or
environmentally sensitive areas, if applicable.
4.Â Â Â Preliminary PDH Plan Approval.Â  Approval of a preliminary PDH plan shall
be by ordinance in accordance with the procedures set forth in Section 165.49.Â 
Approval of the zoning of the land to an OPD-H Zone shall constitute approval
of the plan.Â  A preliminary PDH plan shall be valid for no more than 24 months,
unless specifically provided otherwise in the OPD-H approval ordinance.Â  If no
building permit has been issued for the development within the 24-month period,
the area of land to which the PDH ordinance applied may be considered by the
City for rezoning.Â  Preliminary or final OPD-H plans approved prior to the date
of adoption of these regulations shall not be subject to this provision.
5.Â Â Â Report of Planning and Zoning Commission.Â  Upon completion of review of
the preliminary PDH plan of the planned development, the Commission shall
recommend either approval or denial of the plan and shall make a written report
of its findings to the City Council to substantiate its recommendations.Â  The
findings shall deal with the following:Â  that the variances in setbacks, lot
area requirements, building heights, building types, sizes of buildings, and
the combination of land uses will be in the public interest, in harmony with
the purposes of this chapter and other building regulations of the City and
will not adversely affect nearby properties and that the parking requirements
of this chapter otherwise prevailing in the zone have not been reduced.
6.Â Â Â Changes in Approved Preliminary PDH Plan.Â  Material changes in an approved
preliminary PDH plan shall be subject to the approval procedures set forth in
subsection 4 of this section.Â  A material change is any change in the use or
character of the development from the use or uses shown on the preliminary PDH
plan and any dimensional change beyond the ranges specified on the preliminary
plan.
7.Â Â Â Final PDH Plan.Â  Applications for approval of the final PDH plan shall
meet all of the requirements of the preliminary PDH plan and meet the
documentation specifications of the subdivision regulations where applicable.Â 
For an area of land less than two (2) acres, the final PDH plan shall also
include the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Building elevations and floor plans for all structures.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Details of materials to be used for external construction.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A landscape plan, including screening and buffering between the
proposed and existing development.
8.Â Â Â Final PDH Plan of Sub-area.Â  After preliminary approval of the entire
planned development is given, a final plan of a segment or sub-area within the
planned development may be approved if:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The plan of the sub-area meets all requirements of a final plan.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The dwelling unit density within the sub-area does not exceed the
dwelling unit density allowable for the least restrictive use for that area
under existing zoning.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The sub-area can function as an independent development unit with
adequate access, services, utilities, open space, etc.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The developer dedicates all public rights-of-way necessary to support
the sub-area.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The sub-area is more than two (2) acres in size.
9.Â Â Â General Requirements.Â  Planned developments shall meet the following
criteria:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Land Uses.Â  Combinations of land uses, including single-family, multi-
family and commercial uses are permitted and variations in building setback and
lot area requirements as called for in this chapter may be approved for planned
developments.Â  (Commercial uses are not permitted in PDH plans on less than 2
acres.)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Dwelling Unit Density.Â  The overall dwelling unit density (based upon
total land area minus public and private street right-of-way area within the
planned development) may be computed on the basis of that permitted for the
least restrictive use, depending upon the character of the development which
would be allowed under the applicable underlying zoning classifications.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Open Space.Â  Planned developments shall contain open space totaling
twenty-five percent (25%) or more of the total land area minus public and
private street right-of-way area for recreational purposes and to enhance the
general character of the area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â In the event the open space land is to be retained under private
ownership, the developer must submit a legally binding instrument setting forth
the procedures to be followed in maintaining the areas and the means for
financing maintenance costs.Â  Generally, such costs shall be shared by all
owners of property located within the planned development, with unpaid costs
becoming a lien on individual properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â All proposed dedications of land for public use, including that to
be dedicated for recreational use, shall be approved in writing by the Building
Official prior to approval of the plan by the Council.Â  All land dedications
for public use shall conform to the requirements of City ordinances.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Ownership.Â  At the time of approval of a preliminary PDH plan, the
developer must submit evidence of ownership of the property to be developed or
show evidence of legally binding executed option agreements for purchasing all
of the property.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Dedication of Public Right-of-Way.Â  All proposed dedications of land
for public use, including that to be dedicated for recreational use, shall be
approved in writing by the Building Official prior to approval of the plan by
the Council.Â  All land dedications for public use shall conform to the
requirements of City ordinances.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Streets.Â  Planned developments shall make provision for continuation
and extension of streets and shall be done in accordance with current City
standards.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Schedule of Completion.Â  A developer or sponsor of a planned
development shall be required to submit a signed statement generally describing
the proposed development and setting forth an intended time schedule for the
completion of various phases.
10.Â Â Â Additional Requirements and Standards for PDH on Areas of Land Less Than
Two (2) Acres, But One Acre or More.Â  No PDH plan for an area containing less
than 2 acres shall be approved before the following prerequisite is met and
which does not conform to the following standards:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prerequisite to Consideration.Â  Prior to submitting a preliminary plan,
the owner/developer shall notify all property owners within 600 feet of the
proposed development, of the proposed project, and shall meet with as many
property owners as possible to discuss the project.Â  The owner/developer shall
submit to the Building Official a list of property owners, obtained from the
Cerro Gordo County Treasurerâ€™s Office, to whom notice was sent.Â  Documentation
of a meeting with these people shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â General Standards:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The density and design of the PDH shall be compatible in use, size
and type of structure, relative amount of open space, traffic circulation and
general layout with adjoining land uses and shall be integrated into the
neighborhood.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The development shall not overburden existing streets and
utilities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The development shall not adversely affect views, light and air,
property values and privacy of neighboring properties any more than would a
conventional development.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Specific Standards:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Land Coverage.Â  Maximum land coverage for all buildings in the
development shall not exceed thirty-five percent (35%) of the total land area
minus street right-of-way area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Open Space.Â  At least twenty-five percent (25%) of the total land
area minus public and private street right-of-way area shall be open space.Â  At
least fifty percent (50%) of the required open space shall be suitably improved
by the owner/developer for its intended purpose, such work to be completed
before any occupancy certificate may be issued for the development.Â  The
remaining fifty percent (50%) of required open space may be left unimproved,
particularly if natural features worthy of preservation exist on the site.Â 
(Open space means land area of the site not covered by buildings, parking or
vehicular maneuvering areas, but including storm water detention basins,
recreational and pedestrian areas and private yards, if any.)
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Dimensions.Â  There shall be no minimum dimensional requirements
except for setbacks similar to those required for adjacent properties.Â  The
more restrictive zone setbacks will take precedent.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Siting and Design.Â  Multi-family structures located adjacent to
existing single-family dwellings must be sited, landscaped and screened by
natural features and plant materials to harmoniously integrate the PDH with the
surrounding neighborhood.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Commercial or institutional uses shall be prohibited.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Other conditions may be required, if found necessary to protect and
promote the best interest of the surrounding property or the neighborhood.Â 
These conditions may include but are not limited to, the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Improvement of traffic circulation for vehicles and pedestrians in
the proposed development and adjoining properties and streets.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Specific landscaping requirements to maintain privacy or reduce
impacts on adjoining properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Joint use of private open space or amenities by adjoining property
owners.
11.Â Â Â Final Plan Approval.Â  Final approval of any PDH plan shall be by
administrative review.Â  Approval shall be based on compliance with an approved
preliminary PDH plan and any modifications required by the Commission and
Council at the time the land was zoned to OPD-H.Â  After approval of the final
plan, permits may be issued to carry out the approved plan.Â  Material changes
to an approved PDH plan must be approved by ordinance in accordance with the
procedures set forth in subsection 4 of this Section.Â  Material changes are the
same as those specified in subsection 6 of this section.
12.Â Â Â Building Permits.Â  The final plan, or parts thereof as finally approved,
shall be filed in the Building Officialâ€™s office and building permits may be
issued only for structures conforming to the PDH plan.Â  Minor changes in
building arrangements that do not substantially alter the character of the
development are allowable without further Council action.Â  Any other changes,
including changes in street locations, land use and building arrangements,
shall be considered as a material change to the approved plan, to be approved
as amendments in accordance with the procedures set forth in subsection 4 of
this section.Â  In the event commercial uses are approved as a part of a planned
development, no building permit for a commercial use shall be issued until a
minimum of twenty-five percent (25%) of the housing units planned for the area
(or approved sub-area) have been completed or unless twenty-five percent (25%)
of the housing units planned for the area (or approved sub-area) will be built
simultaneously.Â  (Separate building permits shall be obtained by the developers
for the construction of housing and commercial uses where separate buildings
are to be used.)Â  The type of commercial use shall be compatible with the
surrounding residential development.
13.Â Â Â Existing OPD-H Developments (Formerly Referred to as Residential Planned
Unit Development (R-PUD).Â  Any planned developments in existence or with an
approved plan for development at the time of passage of the ordinance codified
in this chapter which are zoned R-PUD (OPD-H) by the adoption of this chapter
shall be considered as having met all of the requirements of this chapter.Â  All
new construction, which is not covered by a plan previously approved by the
City, within any OPD-H Zone after the effective date of the ordinance codified
in this chapter must be in compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
165.30Â  PROVISIONAL USES OR SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS.
The following principal uses are listed as provisional uses or special
exceptions in various zones in this chapter.Â  These uses are required to meet
the regulations indicated, in addition to the regulations of the zone in which
the uses are allowed, only when this section is referred to in the requirements
for each use.Â  In case of any conflict between the regulations of the zone in
which the use is allowed as a provisional use or special exception and the
additional regulations of this section, the most restrictive regulations shall
govern.
1.Â Â Â Accessory Apartments.Â  The installation of temporary accessory apartments
in owner-occupied, single-family homes is permitted in accordance with the
following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The accessory apartment shall be complete, separate housekeeping
(dwelling) unit, independent in function from the principal single-family
dwelling unit.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Not more than one accessory apartment may be established in a single-
family dwelling.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The owner of the dwelling in which an accessory apartment is located
must occupy at least one of the dwelling units on the premises as the permanent
legal resident, except for bona fide temporary absences not to exceed six
months at any one time.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The accessory apartment and the principal dwelling shall be under the
same ownership.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The accessory apartment shall be designed so that the appearance of the
building in which it is located remains that of a single-family residence.Â  Any
new entrances should face the side or rear yard of the building, and no
addition for an accessory apartment shall increase the floor area of the
original dwelling by more than ten percent (10%).
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â One additional off-street parking space shall be provided for the
accessory apartment.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Maximum Floor Area.Â  The accessory apartment shall be clearly
subordinate in area to the single-family dwelling.Â  In no case may the
accessory apartment contain more than thirty percent (30%) of the buildingâ€™s
total floor area, or be larger than 800 square feet, or have more than two
bedrooms.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Minimum Floor Area.Â  The accessory apartment shall have at least 300
square feet of floor area.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Minimum Lot Area Per Unit:Â  None.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Prior to the issuance of an accessory apartment permit, the owner shall
file in the office of the Building Official a declaration of covenants stating
that the right to maintain an accessory apartment ceases upon transfer of title
and the right to maintain an accessory apartment in no way constitutes approval
of the dwelling as a duplex.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â A notarized affidavit from the owner verifying that he/she will occupy
one of the dwelling units on the premises except for bona fide temporary
absences shall be submitted to the City prior to issuance of an accessory
apartment permit.Â  Thereafter, the owner shall, as a requirement for
continuance of the accessory apartment use, submit a notarized affidavit by
January 31, each year, certifying compliance with this requirement.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â The effective period of the permit shall be for three (3) years.Â  At
the end of every three (3) years, renewal of the accessory apartment permit
should be granted after completion of a routine housing inspection verifying
that the property remains the principal residence of the owner and that all of
the conditions of this chapter have been met.
2.Â Â Â Cemeteries and Mausoleums.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any new cemetery shall be located on a site containing not less than 20
acres.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All structures including, but not limited to, a mausoleum, permanent
monuments or maintenance building shall be set back not less than 30 feet from
any property line or street right-of-way line and all graves or burial lots
shall be set back not less than 10 feet from any property line or street right-
of-way.
3.Â Â Â Child Daycare Facilities.Â  The following requirements apply when more than
six (6) children are to be cared for, for more than two (2) hours at a time.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A fenced outdoor play area of not less than 100 square feet per child
using the area at any given time shall be provided.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No playground equipment shall be permitted in the front or side yards.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Fenced play areas shall be enclosed or protected, well drained, free
from hazards, and shall be readily accessible to the center.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The center shall be provided with at least 35 square feet of
accessible, usable interior floor space per child, excluding kitchen, bathrooms
and halls.
In addition to the requirements above, the facilityâ€™s operation and maintenance
shall meet all applicable State and County requirements.
4.Â Â Â Clubs.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Clubs shall be located with access to a major thoroughfare.

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Minimum Yards:

(b)Â Â Â Side Yard â€“ 30 feet
(c)Â Â Â Rear Yard â€“ 50 feet
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Parking â€“ no closer than 20 feet to a side or rear lot line.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Building Bulk:
(a)Â Â Â The maximum permitted floor area ratio shall be 0.3.
(b)Â Â Â The maximum permitted building coverage shall be fifteen percent (15%).
5.Â Â Â Drive-In Theaters.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The site shall have direct access to a major thoroughfare.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The viewing side of the theater screen shall not be visible from within
1,000 feet of any existing or proposed public street.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Cars parked in the viewing area shall be screened on all sides by a

Â Â Â D.Â Â Â All entrances and exits shall be separated and internal circulation

Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Amusement areas shall be limited to patrons of the theater.
6.Â Â Â Dwellings, Zero Lot Line and Townhouses.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Where the abutting lot has been developed with a principal building
having a setback of more than zero feet but less than 10 feet from the side lot

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No portion of a wall, roof or appurtenance on the zero side yard shall

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Legal provision shall be made for permanent access for the maintenance

Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Each end unit of a townhouse shall have one (1) side yard of a minimum

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Each dwelling unit shall be provided with separate building access and

Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Each unit of a townhouse shall be located on a separate lot.
7.Â Â Â Elderly Housing, Dimensional Requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Minimum Lot Area Per Unit:Â  300 square feet
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Minimum Yards:Â  None
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Minimum Separation:Â  Two (2) or more separate buildings on the same lot

Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The height of the highest building; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Eight (8) feet plus two (2) feet for each additional story above
the second story, provided that no window of a dwelling unit is located on a

Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Two (2) times the height of the adjacent building above the window

building.Â  (See Figure 14.)Â  The distance shall in no case be less than eight

8.Â Â Â Extraction.

10.Â Â Â Junk Yards.

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All outdoor storage shall be conducted entirely within an enclosed
fence, wall or other solid screen except for driveway areas.Â  Such solid screen
shall be constructed on or inside the front, side and rear lot lines and shall
be constructed in such a manner that no outdoor storage or salvage operations
shall be visible from an adjacent property, street or highway.Â  Storage, either
temporary or permanent, between such fence or wall and any property line is
expressly prohibited.Â  Junk or salvage materials shall not be piled higher than
the height of the fence, or against the fence.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â For fire protection, an unobstructed firebreak shall be maintained, 15
feet in width and completely surrounding the junk yard.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The storage of rags, paper and similar combustible waste shall not be
closer than 100 feet to any property line, unless enclosed in a masonry
building of not less than 4-hour fire resistive construction.

165.32Â  ACCESSORY USE AND BUILDING REGULATIONS.
1.Â Â Â Detached Accessory Uses and Buildings.Â  In all zones, except as otherwise
provided, detached accessory uses and buildings shall be subject to the
following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Time of Construction.Â  No accessory building shall be constructed prior
to the start of construction of the principal building.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Setback From Property Lines.Â  Except as otherwise provided, an
accessory building shall be separated from lot lines in compliance with the
following requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Accessory buildings, except for roadside stands, shall not be
located in a front yard and garages and carports shall be located to provide a
minimum 25-foot length â€œaisleâ€ between the building and the street right-of-way
line (except in the LR Zone).
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In R Zones, an accessory building shall not be located closer than
five (5) feet to a side lot line or a rear lot line.Â  In an OBP Zone, an
accessory building shall not be located in a side or rear yard.Â  An accessory
building for a zero lot line dwelling shall comply with the above requirements
and shall not be located in the required 10-foot side yard.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Setback From Alley.Â  When a garage or carport is entered directly
from an alley, it shall not be located closer than 10 feet from the alley
right-of-way line.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Not Used for Dwelling.Â  No accessory building shall be used for
dwelling purposes other than by domestic help employed entirely on the
premises.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Setback From Principal Building.Â  No portion of an accessory building
shall be located closer than three (3) feet to the principal building.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Maximum Rear Yard Coverage.Â  In all RS Zones, accessory buildings shall
not exceed the aggregate of 1000 square feet in area and shall not occupy more
than thirty-five percent (35%) of the rear yard area.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Maximum Rear Yard Coverage.Â  In all RM Zones, accessory buildings shall
not exceed the aggregate of 1000 square feet in area and shall not occupy more
than thirty-five percent (35%) of the rear yard area.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Maximum Height.Â  Accessory buildings and structures shall not exceed a
height of eighteen (18) feet in all R Zones or the maximum height permitted for
a principal building in other zones.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Distance from Lakeshore.Â  In the LR Zone, no storage or accessory
buildings shall be placed closer to the lakeshore line than the rear building
line or closer than five (5) feet from any side lot line.
2.Â Â Â Attached Accessory Buildings.Â  Attached accessory buildings shall be
located pursuant to the requirements for principal buildings.Â  Attached garages
and carports shall be located on a lot so that a minimum 25-foot length â€œaisleâ€
between the building and the street right-of-way line is provided (except in
the LR Zone).Â

2.Â Â Â General Rules Applicable to Off-Street Parking.Â  The following rules shall
govern in the design, location and number of off-street parking and stacking
spaces, aisles and drives.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Where a fractional space results, the number of parking and stacking
spaces required is the closest whole number.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Whenever a use existing prior to the effective date of this chapter is
enlarged to the extent of less than fifty percent (50%) in floor area, the
addition or enlargement shall comply with the parking requirements set forth
herein.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Whenever a building existing prior to the effective date of this
chapter is structurally altered by one or more additions, the sum total of
which increases the floor area to the extent of 50% or more, the uses contained
within the original building and all enlargements shall thereafter comply with
the parking requirements set forth herein.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A use existing prior to the effective date of this chapter, for which
the current required number of parking or stacking spaces is not provided, may
be converted to another use without full compliance with the required number of
parking or stacking spaces, provided that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If subsection 1 of this section would require a greater number of
parking or stacking spaces for the converted use than were required for the
established use, the increased number of parking or stacking spaces shall be
provided in compliance with subsection 3.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In addition to the number of spaces required under subparagraph
(1), or if subparagraph (1) is not applicable, as many additional spaces shall
be provided as the lot will accommodate.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In the case of mixed uses, the parking and stacking spaces required
shall equal the sum of the requirements of the various uses computed
separately.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The storage of merchandise, materials, equipment, refuse containers,
obsolete or junk vehicles, or the major repair of vehicles is prohibited in
required off-street parking and stacking spaces.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Prior to the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy as provided in
Section 165.47, all parking and stacking spaces, drives and aisles shall, as
provided in paragraph 3(A) of this section, be paved with concrete, asphalt or
a similar dust-free surface; except that the Building Official may issue a
temporary Certificate of Occupancy in those instances where the Building
Official finds that the paving cannot reasonably be completed due to adverse
weather conditions or settling of land on the site after demolition or
filling.Â  A temporary Certificate of Occupancy shall be effective only to a
date specific, and, as a condition to issuance of such a temporary certificate,
the property owner shall place in an escrow account, established with the City,
an amount which shall cover 110 percent of the anticipated cost of paving.
3.Â Â Â Construction, Design and Location Requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Construction.Â  All parking and stacking spaces, drives and aisles shall
be constructed of asphalt, concrete or similar permanent dust-free surface.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Design.Â  Except for single-family dwellings (including zero lot line
and townhouse units) and duplexes, parking and stacking spaces, aisles and
drives shall be designated as follows (except as required by the 1991 Americans
With Disabilities Act (ADA) Accessibility Guidelines for Buildings and
Facilities):
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Parking areas shall have the minimum dimensions illustrated in
Figure 5 for each of the parking configurations permitted (where the edges of
parking spaces are curved, as on a curved aisle, all angles shall be measured
between the straight edges of the parking spaces and tangents to the curved
edges at their point of intersection).
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Up to ten percent (10%) of the required number of parking spaces
may be eight (8) feet in width by fifteen (15) feet in length if the parking
spaces are signed â€œCompact Vehicles Only.â€
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â All parking spaces shall be connected to an aisle which shall have
a minimum width as indicated in FigureÂ 5.Â  Aisles designed for two-way traffic
shall have a minimum width of twenty-six (26) feet.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The greatest aisle width shown in Figure 5 shall be provided when
combining different parking space configurations on the same aisle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Parking spaces shall be designed to permit ingress and egress of
the vehicle without moving any other vehicle occupying a parking space.Â  For
single-family dwellings (including zero lot line and townhouse units) and
duplexes, when located pursuant to the requirements of this chapter, one space
may be behind another.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â No parking area shall be designed in such a manner that exiting a
parking area would require backing into a street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â If the number of parking spaces required or provided for a use or a
combination of uses on a lot is greater than eight (8) spaces, none of those
spaces may be located in such a manner that would require backing into an
alley.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Parking spaces along lot lines and alleys shall be provided with
car stops or curbing so no part of a parked vehicle can extend beyond the lot
line or into the alley (FigureÂ 4).Â  In addition, traffic islands of pervious or
impervious material shall be located so that parking spaces are separated from
drives and alleys in a manner similar to that illustrated in FigureÂ 6.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â All parking spaces, stacking spaces, drives and aisles in parking
areas shall be pitched or curbed and drained to prevent the flow of excess
water from such areas onto streets and alleys which do not have adequate
drainage facilities as determined by the City Engineer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â In all parking areas required by this chapter, parking spaces
shall be visibly delineated on the surface by painted or marked stripes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (11)Â Â Â If two or more parking areas on a lot are connected by a drive,
the parking areas shall be designed so that an aisle connected to more than
twelve (12) parking spaces is not used as a drive in providing access to
another parking area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (12)Â Â Â A drive providing access to a parking area with more than 18
spaces shall be no less than 18 feet in width if designated for two-way
traffic, or 10 feet in width if designated for one-way traffic.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Location.Â  Parking spaces, aisles and drives shall be located as
follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Off-street parking and stacking spaces, aisles and drives shall be
located on the same lot as the use served except as provided in subsection 4 of
this section (Off-Street Parking Located on a Separate Lot).
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In all R Zones, except for zero lot line dwellings, and in all
other zones abutting an R Zone, drives and aisles shall not be located closer
than three (3) feet to a lot line or an R Zone boundary unless pitched or
curbed and drained to prevent the flow of water onto adjoining property or
unless a drainage course has been established along lot lines for the purpose
of storm water runoff.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A parking area in a C or I Zone shall not be located closer than
five (5) feet to an R Zone boundary; except an existing nonconforming parking
area with a permanent, dust-free surface may be located within five (5) feet of
an R Zone boundary if the parking area is screened from view within the R Zone
by a solid fence of durable construction which complies with the regulations of
Sections 165.43(8) and 165.36.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Except for single-family dwellings (including zero lot line and
townhouse units) and duplexes, no parking space shall be located closer than
five (5) feet to a ground floor doorway or a window of a dwelling unit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Except as provided below, in R Zones and in the C and I Zones
within 50 feet of an R Zone, no parking shall be permitted in the front yard.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â For detached single-family dwellings in the R Zones, one (1) of the
required parking spaces may be provided in the front yard on a regularly
constructed aisle provided that not less than 50% of the front yard area shall
remain in open space free of impervious surface.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â For zero lot line dwellings, duplexes and family care facilities,
two (2) of the required parking spaces may be provided in the front yard on a
regularly constructed aisle provided that not less than 50% of the front yard
area shall remain in open space free of impervious surface.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â In the OBP Zone, only 10% of the required number of parking spaces
may be located in the front yard not closer than 50 feet to a street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Where the paved surface of a street is narrower in width, four (4)
of the parking spaces required by Chapter 166 (Subdivisions) may be located in
the front yard on a regularly constructed aisle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â Side Yard.Â  Except for single- and two-family dwellings or where
two lots share the same parking and stacking spaces, drives and aisles pursuant
to subsection 4, no parking spaces, aisles or drives shall be permitted in that
portion of the required side yard which is contiguous to the principal building
on a lot.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (11)Â Â Â Rear Yard.Â  Parking and stacking spaces, drives and aisles may be
provided in the rear yard.
4.Â Â Â Off-Street Parking Located on a Separate Lot.Â  Off-street parking and
stacking spaces, aisles and drives may be located on a separate lot from the
use served provided a conditional use is granted by the Board of Adjustment and
that the following conditions are met:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Special Location Plan.Â  A special location plan shall be filed with the
Board by the owners of the entire land area to be included within the special
location plan and shall contain such information deemed necessary to comply
with the requirements herein.Â  A covenant running with the land area shall be
submitted with the special location plan stating that individual lots shall not
be sold separately.Â  In addition, evidence of property ownership shall be
required.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Off-Street Parking Location.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â In R and C Zones, the nearest point of the parking area to the
nearest point of the building that the parking area is required to serve shall
not be greater than 300 feet.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In I and OBP Zones, the nearest point of the parking area to the
nearest point of the building that the parking area is required to serve shall
not be greater than 600 feet.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Where off-street parking is used jointly by two (2) or more uses, the
number of parking spaces shall be equal to the sum total of off-street parking
space requirements of all such uses.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Up to 50% of the parking spaces required for commercial recreational
uses, clubs, schools or restaurants and up to 100% for a religious institution
may be shared by financial institutions, offices, retail establishments, repair
shops, personal service establishments and similar uses not normally open, used
or operated during the same hours.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â A written agreement properly executed by the owners within the area of
the special location plan assuring the retention of the parking and stacking
spaces, aisles and drives and binding upon their successors and assigns shall
be submitted with the special location plan as a covenant running with the
land.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In instances where a use is within 600 feet of a City-owned parking
area, up to 50% of the required number of parking spaces may be provided in the
parking facility.Â  When a use abuts a City-owned parking area, up to 100% of
the required number of parking spaces may be provided in the parking facility.Â 
In the instance where an applicant wishes to provide off-street parking in a
City-owned parking facility, the Council shall substantiate that, with the
addition of the number of cars for a use accommodated in the facility, the
capacity of the parking facility will not be exceeded.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â In assessing an application for a conditional use, the Board shall
consider the desirability of the location of off-street parking and stacking
spaces, aisles and drives, on a lot separate from the use served in terms of
pedestrian and vehicular traffic safety and any detrimental effects such off-
street parking and stacking spaces, aisles and drives may have on adjacent
property.
5.Â Â Â Screening Requirements.Â  In addition to the applicable requirements for
screening of Section 165.43(8), the following screening requirements in
connection with parking areas shall be met:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Where a parking area is provided on a lot within 50 feet of an abutting
lot with a residential use which requires four (4) or fewer parking spaces, the
portion of the parking area within 50 feet of the abutting lot shall be
screened from view within the abutting lot or at such time as provided in
Section 165.43(8).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Where a parking area is provided on a lot within 100 feet across the
street from a lot with a residential use which requires four (4) or fewer
parking spaces, the portion of the parking area within 100 feet shall be
screened from view within the lot or at such time as provided in Section 165.43
(8).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The materials for screening and the placement shall comply with the
regulations of Section 165.43(8).
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The Board of Adjustment may grant a conditional use to modify the
screening requirements when a parking area requires screening as provided in
paragraphs A and B above, when neither the lot on which the parking area is
located and the lot abutting or across the street are zoned RS.Â  The
conditional use shall be subject to all the requirements of Section 165.52(5)
and may only be granted when the applicant can demonstrate that modification of
screening requirements would better serve the public interest than would strict
compliance with said requirements.Â  Public interest may include but is not
limited to reasons of public safety or aesthetics.Â  In no case shall a
conditional use be granted to modify the screening requirements for a lot
abutting or across the street from a lot in an RS Zone.
6.Â Â Â Off-Street Parking in the CB-1 Zone.Â  Except as otherwise provided, off-
street parking in the CB-1 Zone shall be permitted only after approval of a
conditional use by the Board of Adjustment.Â  The Board shall consider the
impact of the proposed parking upon surrounding uses in relation to the
following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Screening.Â  In addition to the applicable requirements for screening of
subsection 5 herein, where a parking area abuts a street it shall be separated
therefrom by a solid fence, wall or coniferous hedge having a height of not
less than three (3) feet or more than five (5) feet.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Access.Â  Each entrance and exit to the parking area shall be
constructed so that vehicles entering or leaving the parking area shall be
clearly visible to a pedestrian on any sidewalks at a distance of not less than
10 feet (FigureÂ 2).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Signs.Â  Appropriate signs, including stop signs posted at the exits to
streets, shall be provided.
7.Â Â Â Special Vehicle and Watercraft Parking and Storage.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions.Â  â€œSpecial vehicleâ€ means every device, more than seven and
one-half (7Â½) feet in height and more than twenty (20) feet in length, which is

including, without limitation, any motor vehicle, truck, trailer, tractor,
wagon, watercraft or any combination thereof exceeding these dimensions.Â 
â€œStorage areaâ€ means a space, equal in size to the outer perimeter of a special
vehicle, used for storage of such a vehicle.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Except for the purpose of making local deliveries, no vehicle designed
for the shipment of detonable or flammable solids, liquids or gasses shall be
parked or stored on any lot in an R Zone.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Commercial vehicles more than 7Â½ feet in height shall not be stored in
any residential zone.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In the RR-1, RS-5, RS-8 and RS-12 zones, special vehicle storage shall
comply with the following requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â No special vehicle may be stored in a front yard, except on a
regularly constructed drive, aisle or parking space for a period of no more
than four days for the purpose of loading and unloading.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A special vehicle may be stored inside any building provided it is
not stored in a required parking space.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A special vehicle stored outside a building shall:
(a)Â Â Â Belong to the owner or tenant of the property on which the vehicle is
located, except for special vehicles of guests, as provided in subparagraph (c)
below.
(b)Â Â Â Be in operational condition and properly licensed as required by State or
Federal law.
(c)Â Â Â Not be used for dwelling purposes except by guests of the property owner
or tenant for a period of no more than 21 consecutive days or 45 days in any
calendar year (an extension may be approved by the Building Official).
(d)Â Â Â Not be used for storage of items other than those considered to be part
of the unit.
(e)Â Â Â Not be parked or stored upon a vacant residential lot.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â A special vehicle may be stored outside a building in the required
side yard (except along a street) or in a required rear yard, provided:
(a)Â Â Â The vehicle is no closer than five (5) feet to a side lot line, or to a
rear lot line of a reversed corner lot.
(b)Â Â Â The storage area is surfaced with crushed rock, asphalt, concrete, or a
similar surface designed and maintained to prevent muddy conditions, erosion,
the flow of water onto adjoining property and weed growth.Â  In cases where
crushed rock is used, the perimeter of such storage area shall be defined by
bricks, railroad ties or similar materials.
(c)Â Â Â No more than 30% of a required rear yard may be occupied by accessory
structures and a special vehicle storage area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â The Building Official may permit outside storage of a special
vehicle in the required front yard or the required side yard along a street,
provided:
(a)Â Â Â Storage space is not available in or there is no access to either the
side or rear yard.Â  For purposes of this subparagraph (5), a corner lot shall
always be deemed to have access to the rear yard; and accessory structures and
buildings less than 160 square feet in area, or vegetation which is
transplantable are not deemed to prevent access.
(b)Â Â Â Inside storage is not possible because the size of the special vehicle
exceeds either the space available or the size of the entrance available in any
existing building, or both.
(c)Â Â Â A planting screen is planted and maintained in accordance with the Fence,
Wall and Hedge Requirements, Section 165.36 and the Performance Requirements,
Section 165.43(8).
(d)Â Â Â No part of the special vehicle extends beyond the property line or over
public right-of-way.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Nonconforming Storage Areas.
(a)Â Â Â A special vehicle owner or lessee may establish nonconforming status for
a special vehicle storage area which, on the date of adoption of these
regulations, is located in a required front yard, or the required side yard
along a street, if it can be demonstrated that there is no access to either the
side or rear yard.Â  If access to either the side or rear yard is available, a
nonconforming storage area shall be relocated to either the side yard or rear
yard within two (2) years after passage of this regulation.
(b)Â Â Â Nonconforming status for a special vehicle storage area shall be
established by submitting to the Building Official within 12 months after the
date of adoption of these regulations a plot plan showing the location, design
and size of the storage area and the surface material existing on the storage
area.
(c)Â Â Â Should any property be sold, conveyed or transferred, the special vehicle
storage area shall thereafter comply with the provisions of this section.
(d)Â Â Â Twelve (12) months after the date of adoption of these regulations,
nonconforming status of existing special vehicle storage areas may not be
established.
(e)Â Â Â A nonconforming special vehicle storage area which is not used for a
period of one (1) year, for any reason, intentional or otherwise, shall not
thereafter be permitted for special vehicle storage unless the area is brought
into full compliance with these regulations.
8.Â Â Â Parking for Persons With Disabilities.Â  Accessible parking spaces shall be

Disabilities Act (ADA) Accessibility Guidelines for Buildings and Facilities.Â 
Specific information about numbers, types, sizes and accessible routes to
parking spaces for various facilities can be found in the ADA document.
9.Â Â Â Modification of Parking Requirements.Â  Where it can be demonstrated that a
specific use has such characteristics that the number of parking or stacking
spaces required is too restrictive, the Board of Adjustment may grant a
conditional use to allow not more than a 50% reduction and more for buildings
placed on the National Register of Historic Places, in the required number of
parking or stacking spaces.

165.35Â  SIGN REGULATIONS.
It is the purpose of the sign regulations to enhance and protect the physical
appearance and safety of the community, to protect property values and to
promote the preservation of the Cityâ€™s areas of natural, historic and scenic
beauty.Â  It is further intended to reduce distractions and obstructions that
may contribute to traffic accidents, reduce hazards that may be caused by signs
projecting over public rights-of-way, provide for a reasonable opportunity for
all sign users to display signs for identification without interference from
other signage, to provide for fair and equitable treatment of all sign users,
and to establish a reasonable period of time for the elimination of
nonconforming signs.Â  The administration of this section shall be the duty of
the Building Official.
1.Â Â Â General Rules and Applicability.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No sign on private property shall be erected or changed in any manner
without compliance with the regulations stated herein.Â  Routine maintenance
shall not be subject to this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â These regulations are intended to be exclusionary and any sign not
specifically listed shall be prohibited.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â These regulations are structured within the two general categories of
temporary and permanent signs.Â  Temporary signs are governed by the provisions
of Section 165.35(3)(H).Â  Permanent signs may be either off-premises or on-
premises signs.Â  Off-premises signs are governed by the provisions of Section
165.35(4)(J).Â  All on-premises signs are governed by the regulations of the
zone in which they are located.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In all zones, a maximum sign allowance is permitted for all permanent
signs placed on a building.Â  Any quantity or type of building sign may be
erected within this maximum allowance and according to the specific
requirements of the zone in which the building is located.Â  The building sign
allowance shall relate to the wall on which a sign is to be placed and shall be
determined by calculating a percentage of the total square footage of the sign
wall, as specified in the zone.Â  In the case of two or more uses or occupants
in a single building, the total building signage on a wall for all the uses
shall not exceed the maximum building sign allowance for that wall.Â  Free-
standing signs, monument signs or any other signs not mounted on a building are
not included in this maximum building sign allowance and are governed by the
specific requirements of the zone.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Existing signage that is not in compliance with the sign regulations
contained in this section prior to the adoption of this chapter will have one
(1) year to become in compliance with the minimum standards hereinafter
established for the zone in which the sign is located.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In any case in which the Code of Iowa is more restrictive than the
regulations contained herein, the Code of Iowa shall be applied.
2.Â Â Â Definitions.Â  The following definitions shall be applicable to the
provisions of the sign regulations.Â  The definitions contained in Section
165.03 of this chapter shall apply to all terms not herein defined:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â â€œAdvertising signâ€ means a sign that displays the type or name of a
product, good or service sold either on or off the premises on which the sign
is located.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â â€œAnimated signâ€ means any sign or part of a sign that moves or has
intermittent lighting.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â â€œAwning signâ€ means a building sign placed on the surface of an awning.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â â€œBalloonâ€ means an inflatable bag filled with gas and displayed in such
a way as to attract attention to the premises on which it is located.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â â€œBannerâ€ means a strip of flexible material such as cloth, paper or
plastic securely fastened on all corners to a building or a structure and used
to advertise a special event.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â â€œBillboardâ€ means an off-premises sign on which poster panels or
bulletins are mounted.Â  Billboard signs are not free-standing signs or monument
signs.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â â€œBuilding signâ€ means any sign which is in any way attached to a
building or to an appurtenance of a building.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â â€œCanopy signâ€ means a building sign attached to or in any way
incorporated with the face or underside of a canopy, marquee or any other
similar building projection, and which does not extend beyond the projection by
more than six (6) inches.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â â€œChangeable copy signâ€ means a sign, such as a reader board, which has
components which are easily changeable by physical and not electronic methods.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â â€œChanging signâ€ â€“ see â€œelectronic sign.â€
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â â€œCommon signâ€ means a sign which serves two (2) or more uses.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â â€œConstruction signâ€ means a temporary sign identifying the architects,
engineers, contractors and other individuals involved in the construction of a
building and/or announcing the future use of the building.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â â€œDevelopment signâ€ means a sign designating the name of a residential
or nonresidential development or of a subdivision.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â â€œDirectional signâ€ means a sign designed to guide or direct pedestrian
or vehicular traffic and containing no advertising message.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â â€œDirectory signâ€ means a sign displaying the name of a building,
building complex and/or the occupants.
Â Â Â P.Â Â Â â€œDrive-through restaurant menu signâ€ means a sign displaying a menu or
similar advertising for the purpose of allowing patrons of a restaurant to
order food at a drive-through facility.
Â Â Â Q.Â Â Â "Electronic sign" means a sign on which a changing message is displayed
through the use of an electronically controlled and illuminated medium.Â  An
electronic sign is not considered to be an animated sign.
Â Â Â R.Â Â Â â€œErectâ€ means to build, construct, attach, hang, suspend or affix a
sign which also includes the painting of wall signs.
Â Â Â S.Â Â Â â€œFacia signâ€ means a single-faced building sign which is parallel to or
at an angle of not more than 45 degrees from the wall of the building on which
it is mounted.Â  Such signs do not extend more than one (1) foot out from
vertical walls or more than one (1) foot out at the signâ€™s closest point from
non-vertical walls.
Â Â Â T.Â Â Â â€œFacing or surface signâ€ means the surface of the sign upon, against or
through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign.
Â Â Â U.Â Â Â â€œFilling station signsâ€ means signage which generally appears as an
integral part of the equipment accessory to automotive service stations and
other establishments engaged in the dispensing of motor vehicle fuel or oil,

11.Â Â Â Additional Dimensional Requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Maximum Sign Area.Â  For free-standing and monument signs, the
individual signage allowance includes the total area of all sign faces
associated with that sign and no sign face shall exceed one-half of the allowed
sign area.Â  For building signs, the maximum building sign area shall represent
the total area of all building signs added together.Â  The building sign area
may be divided up among any of the building signs permitted in the zone in
which the use is located, provided that each individual sign does not exceed
the maximum size limits established for that zone.Â  The maximum number of signs
and the maximum sign areas, as provided herein, shall be applied on a per lot
basis.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Sign Wall Area.Â  Where size of a sign is regulated by the sign wall
area, the sign wall area shall be the total area of the wall on which the sign
is to be mounted.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sign Area Determination.Â  The area of each sign, regardless of shape,
shall be computed by determining the area of a triangle, rectangle or circle
which completely encloses the outer perimeter of the sign face, or which
completely encloses the whole group of characters or words in the case of a
sign composed of characters or words attached directly to a building or an
appurtenance to a building.Â  When multiple sign faces are attached to a single
sign support and face the same direction, the faces and any area between them
shall be viewed as one sign face and shall be measured from the extremities of
the sign face.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Sign Height Determination.Â  The maximum height of a sign shall be the
measurement from grade to the highest point on the sign.Â  In the case where a
minimum height is established, the minimum height shall be measured from grade
to the lowest point on the sign.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Minimum Sign Height.Â  A canopy sign or free-standing sign shall not be
less than ten (10) feet above grade.
12.Â Â Â Additional Location Requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except for those zones not requiring a minimum front yard, no
billboard, canopy, free-standing or monument sign or sign support shall be
located within a triangular area at street intersections, where the triangle is
measured from the intersection of curb lines and its sides are 50 feet in
length along major thoroughfares and 30 feet in length along local streets.Â 
Signs may project into this area at 10 or more feet above grade.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No part of a billboard, canopy, free-standing or monument sign or sign
support shall be located within five (5) feet of any lot line except that signs
may be closer than five (5) feet at ten feet or more above grade, provided that
no part of the sign or sign support overhangs any property lines.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â No sign shall obstruct ingress to or egress from any door, window or
fire escape.Â  No sign shall be attached to a standpipe or fire escape.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Building signs may be located on any building wall.Â  However, no single
sign wall may be covered by more than 15 percent.
13.Â Â Â Additional Requirements for Signs Adjacent to Residential Zones.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Signage and area requirements of the CO-1 and CN-1 zones shall apply to
signs which are within 100 feet of a residential zone.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Except for facia signs, no sign shall be located in a required front
yard within 50 feet of a residential zone.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Facia signs located within 50 feet of a residential zone on the same
side of the street shall not be placed on the wall of the building facing the
residential zone.
14.Â Â Â Additional Requirements for Illuminated Signs.Â  Illuminated signs shall
conform to the following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except for signs in the ID and residential zones and special event
signs, all permitted signs may be internally or externally illuminated.Â  Those
signs permitted in the ID and R Zones and special event signs may only be
externally illuminated with white light.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Illumination through the use of exposed lamps and/or inert gas tubes
shall be allowed provided the exposed lamp does not exceed 11 watts or that an
inert gas tube does not draw more than 60 milliamperes.Â  When inside frosted
lamps or exposed lamps with a diffusing screen are used, no lamp shall exceed
25 watts.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Artificial light sources used to illuminate a sign face shall not be
visible from any street right-of-way.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Illuminated signs shall comply with the provisions of subsection 23 of
this section.
15.Â Â Â Additional Construction Requirement.Â  All signs except those temporary
signs enumerated in paragraph (3)(H) of this section shall be designed and
constructed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than 30 pounds per square
foot of area and loads.
16.Â Â Â Additional Maintenance Requirement.Â  All signs shall be maintained in
such a manner as to avoid becoming a hazardous sign.
17.Â Â Â Additional Requirements for Removal.Â  In accordance with the following
procedure, the Building Official shall be authorized to require the removal of
any illegal or prohibited sign.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Before taking action to require the removal of any illegal or
prohibited sign, the Building Official shall provide written notice to the
owner or operator of the business to which the sign relates.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The notice shall specify that the illegal or prohibited sign shall be
removed or brought into compliance with this section within a reasonable time
of such notice.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If the sign is not removed or repaired, as the case may be, within the
time allowed, the Building Official is hereby authorized to have the sign
removed and be used as evidence and assess the costs of removal against the
property for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
18.Â Â Â Additional Requirements for Nonconforming Signs.Â  It is the intent of
these regulations that all non-conforming signs be eliminated as set forth
below.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All signs which are or become nonconforming by adoption of these
regulations shall be permitted to remain as nonconforming signs.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Owners of nonconforming signs shall be required to comply with the

of this section.
19.Â Â Â Special Sign Provisions.Â  A nonconforming use shall be permitted to have

most restrictive zone in which such use is allowed.

165.36Â  FENCE, WALL AND HEDGE REQUIREMENTS.
1.Â Â Â Location and Height.
2.Â Â Â Fences, walls and hedges, when located within the limits of a front, side
or rear yard or within five (5) feet of a lot line, shall be subject to the
following location and height requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No portion of a fence or wall shall exceed six (6) feet in total
height.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fences, walls and hedges shall be located so no part thereof is within
five (5) feet of an alley or a street right-of-way line.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the case of retaining walls supporting embankments, this sectionâ€™s
requirements shall apply only to that part of the wall above the ground surface
of the retained embankment.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â At street intersections, no fence, wall or hedge more than three (3)
feet in height above the elevation of the established curb level shall be
located within a (sight) triangular area, two (2) of its sides 30 feet in
length and measured along the right-of-way lines from the point of intersection
(FigureÂ 1).Â  All planting shall be maintained such that they will not obstruct
the view of drivers of vehicles approaching the street intersections.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In R Zones or within 50 feet of an R Zone along the same frontage,
fences or walls within the front yard shall not exceed four (4) feet in height
and be at least 65 percent open.Â  Fences or walls may be constructed within a
front yard abutting an expressway or major thoroughfare to a height not
exceeding six (6) feet total when:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The front yard is within a double frontage lot.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The front yard is within a corner lot and abuts the front yard of a
double frontage lot.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In the LR Zone, in addition to the above requirements, fences, walls
and hedges shall be placed no closer to the lakeshore line than the rear
building line, with the exception of walls used for embankment purposes along
the lakeshore line.Â  The height of such wall shall not exceed the average grade
of the rear yard.
3.Â Â Â Enclosures.Â  Except as otherwise provided, fenced enclosures shall be
provided for swimming pools with a depth of 18 inches or more and for dog runs
and shall be subject to the following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An outdoor swimming pool, the edge of which is less than four (4) feet
above grade, shall be completely enclosed by a fence not less than four (4)
feet in height.Â  The fence shall be so constructed as not to allow a five (5)
inch diameter sphere to pass through the fence.Â  A principal or an accessory
building may be used as part of such enclosure.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All gates or doors opening through an enclosure shall be equipped with
a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door securely
closed at all times when not in actual use, except that the door of any
building which forms a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped.Â  The
Building Official may permit other protective devices or structures to be used
so long as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute device or
structure is not less than the protection afforded herein.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Dog runs shall be enclosed by a fence of sufficient height and
construction to contain the dog at all times.
4.Â Â Â Barbed Wire and Electric Fences.Â  Barbed wire and electric fences shall be
subject to the following requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Barbed wire shall consist of twisted wires with barbs on each wire a
minimum distance of four (4) inches apart.Â  Concertina wire shall be
prohibited.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Except for the enclosure of livestock operations, barbed wire fences
shall be permitted only in the C, I or OBP Zones, provided that the bottom
strand of barbed wire shall not be less than six (6) feet total above grade.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Except for the enclosure of livestock operations, electric fences shall
not be permitted in any zones.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No electric fence shall carry a charge greater than 25 milliamperes or
a pulsating current longer than one-tenth (1/10) second in a one (1) second
cycle.Â  All electric fence charges shall carry the seal of an approved testing
laboratory.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Barbed wire and electric fences are prohibited within five (5) feet of
a public sidewalk or within four (4) feet of street right-of-way line where a
public sidewalk does not exist.Â  In the latter case, however, either fence may
be erected or constructed along the right-of-way line if the property owner
agrees to move the fence back the required distance within two (2) months after
the installation of a public sidewalk.Â  Said agreement shall be processed with
the application for a permit.
5.Â Â Â Permit Required.Â  It is unlawful to erect or construct or cause to be
erected or constructed any electric or barbed wire fence or any fence over six
(6) feet in height without obtaining a permit.Â  All applications for fence
permits shall be submitted to the Building Official and shall be accompanied by
a sketch or design of the proposed fence and a plot plan showing the location
of the proposed fence.
165.37Â  GENERAL YARD REQUIREMENTS.
1.Â Â Â In an R Zone, lots platted after the adoption of this chapter and abutting
a major thoroughfare.
2.Â Â Â The side yard on the street side of lots fronting on two (2) or more

3.Â Â Â Where a frontage is divided among zones with different front yard

have a front yard with not less than 25 feet.
4.Â Â Â Where a lot in a C or I Zone abuts an R Zone, a yard at least equal to the
