therefor shall be set forth in writing and a copy of the recommendation shall
be provided to the subdivider.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Upon receipt of the final plat and written reports thereon, the Council
shall review the final plat and attachments thereto.Â  If the final plat is
found to conform to the ordinances and standards of the City and the
Comprehensive Plan and other duly adopted plans, all as of the date of approval
of the preliminary plat, and is found to substantially conform to the
preliminary plat, the Council shall approve the final plat and shall cause its
approval to be entered on the plat as required by law.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Action on the final plat by the Council shall be taken within thirty
(30) days of the date of receiving recommendations of the Commission, unless
such time period is extended by agreement between the subdivider and the City.Â 
If the action is to disapprove the plat, the reasons therefor shall be set
forth in the official records of the Council and such decision shall be
provided to the subdivider.
166.16Â  DESIGN AND IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS GENERALLY.
The purpose of good subdivision and site design is to create a functional and
attractive development, to minimize adverse impacts, and to ensure a project
will be an asset to the community.Â  To promote this purpose, all subdivisions
shall conform to the following standards which are designed to result in a
well-planned community without adding unnecessarily to development costs:
1.Â Â Â Improvements Required.Â  The subdivider shall, at the subdividerâ€™s expense,
install and construct all improvements required by this chapter.Â  All required
improvements shall be installed and constructed in accordance with the design
standards established for such improvements by the City and as shown on the
approved preliminary plat.
2.Â Â Â Standards Prescribed.Â  The standards set forth in this chapter shall be
considered the standards necessary to protect the public health, safety, and
general welfare, and can only be deviated from by authorized variance.
3.Â Â Â Inspection.Â  All improvements shall be inspected by the City Engineer to
ensure compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
4.Â Â Â Lands Subject to Flooding.Â  No subdivision containing land located in a
designated or undesignated floodway or flood hazard area shall be approved by
the City without the approval of the Iowa Department of Natural Resources.Â  No
lot shall be located so as to include land located within a designated or
undesignated floodway or flood hazard area unless the lot is of such size and
shape that it will contain a buildable area not within the designated or
undesignated floodway or flood hazard area suitable for development as allowed
by the Zoning Ordinance for the zone in which the lot is located.Â  Land located
within a designated or undesignated flood hazard area or floodway may be
included within a plat as follows, subject to the approval of the City.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Included within individual lots in the subdivision, subject to the
limitations of this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Reserved as open space for recreation use by all owners of lots in the
subdivision, with an appropriate legal instrument, approved by the City,
providing for its care and maintenance by such owners.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If acceptable to the City, dedicated to the City as public open space
for recreation or flood control purposes.
5.Â Â Â Plat to Conform to Comprehensive Plan.Â  The arrangement, character,
extent, width, grade and location of all streets and the general nature and
extent of the lots and uses proposed shall conform to the Comprehensive Plan of
the City, provided such plan has been adopted by the Council and shall conform
to such other plans, including but not limited to a Transportation Master Plan,
a Sanitary Sewer System Plan, and an Open Space and Recreation Master Plan,
provided such plans have been adopted by the City.
6.Â Â Â Construction Standards for Improvements.Â  In addition to the standards set
forth in this chapter, the City Engineer shall, from time to time, prepare, and
the Council shall, from time to time, adopt by resolution, technical standards
for public improvements.Â  Such technical standards for public improvements
shall contain the minimum acceptable specifications for the construction of
public improvements.Â  Such technical standards may vary for classes of
improvements, giving due regard to the classification of streets or other
improvements, and the extent and character of the area served by the
improvements.Â  Upon adoption by the Council by resolution, such technical
standards for public improvements shall have such force and effect as if they
were fully set forth herein.
166.17Â  SITE DESIGN STANDARDS.
1.Â Â Â Site Analysis.Â  An analysis shall be made of characteristics of the
development site such as site context; geology and soil; topography; climate;
ecology; existing vegetation, structures, roadways and streets; visual
features; and past and present use of the site.
2.Â Â Â Subdivision and Site Design.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Design of the development shall take into consideration all existing
local and regional plans for the surrounding community.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Development of the site shall be based on the site analysis.Â  To the
maximum extent practicable, development shall be located to preserve the
natural features of the site, to avoid areas of environmental sensitivity, and
to minimize negative impacts and alteration of natural features.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The following specific areas shall be preserved as undeveloped open
space to the extent consistent with the reasonable utilization of land, and in
accordance with applicable State or local regulations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Unique and/or environmentally sensitive areas, including wetlands
as defined in Section 404 of the Clean Water Act, as amended, and delineated on
National Wetland Inventory maps prepared by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service,
field verified by on-site inspection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Significant trees or stands of trees, defined as the largest known
individual trees of each species in the State, large trees approaching the
diameter of the known largest tree, or species or clumps of trees that are rare
to the area or of particular horticultural or landscape value.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Lands in the flood plain, as defined in Chapter 165 (Zoning
Ordinance).
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Steep slopes in excess of 20% as measured over a 10-foot interval
unless appropriate engineering measures concerning slope stability, erosion and
resident safety are taken.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â State and Federal threatened and endangered animals and plants, as
well as their habitats, as identified on Federal and/or State lists.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Historically significant structures and sites, including
significant archaeological sites, as listed on Federal and/or State lists.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â The development shall be laid out to avoid adversely affecting
groundwater and aquifer recharge; to reduce cut and fill; to avoid unnecessary
impervious cover; to prevent flooding; to provide adequate access to lots and
sites; and to mitigate adverse effects of shadow, noise, odor, traffic,
drainage and utilities on neighboring properties.
3.Â Â Â Residential Development Design.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In conventional developments, the Commission may vary lot areas and
dimensions, yards and setbacks for the purpose of encouraging and promoting
flexibility, economy and environmental soundness in layout and design, provided
that the average lot areas and dimensions, yards and setbacks within the
subdivision conform to the minimum requirements of Chapter 165 (Zoning
Ordinance) and provided that such standards shall be appropriate to the type of
development permitted.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every lot shall have sufficient access to it for emergency vehicles as
well as for those needing access to the property in its intended use.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The placement of units in residential developments shall take into
consideration topography, privacy, building height, orientation, drainage and
aesthetics.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Buildings shall be spaced so that adequate privacy is provided for
units.
4.Â Â Â Commercial and Industrial Development Design.Â  Commercial and industrial
developments shall be designed according to the same principles governing the
design of residential developments; namely, buildings shall be located
according to topography, with environmentally sensitive areas avoided to the
maximum extent practicable; factors such as drainage, noise, odor and
surrounding land uses considered in siting buildings; sufficient access shall
be provided; and adverse impacts buffered.
5.Â Â Â Circulation System Design.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The road system shall be designed to permit the safe, efficient and
orderly movement of traffic; to meet, but not exceed, the needs of the present
and future population served; to have a simple and logical pattern; to respect
natural features and topography; and to present an attractive streetscape.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In residential subdivisions, the road system shall be designed to serve
the needs of the neighborhood and to discourage use by through traffic.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The pedestrian system shall be located as required for safety.Â  In
conventional developments, walks shall be placed parallel to the street, with
exceptions permitted to preserve natural features or to provide visual
interest.Â  In planned developments, walks may be placed away from the road
system, but they may also be required parallel to the street for safety
reasons.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Bikeways shall be required only if specifically indicated in the Open
Space and Recreation Master Plan.
6.Â Â Â Landscape Design.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Reasonable landscaping shall be provided at site entrances, in public
areas and adjacent to buildings.Â  The type and amount of landscaping required
shall be allowed to vary with type of development.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Plantings or other landscaping materials that best serve the intended
function shall be selected.Â  Landscaping materials shall be appropriate for the
local environment, soil conditions and availability of water. The impact of the
proposed landscaping plan at various time intervals shall also be considered.
166.18Â  OPEN SPACE AND RECREATION.
1.Â Â Â Purpose.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All subdivisions shall be required to provide a minimum amount of open
space.Â  Developed open space shall be designed to provide active recreational
facilities to serve the residents of the development.Â  Undeveloped open space
shall be designed to preserve important site amenities and environmentally
sensitive areas.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All residential subdivisions shall be so designed as to meet the
neighborhood park and open space needs of its residents as specified in the
Open Space and Recreation Master Plan.Â  Such needs may be met by dedication and
acceptance of public park land and/or by reservation by covenant of private
open space, provided there exist sufficient covenants, running with the land,
to insure adequate maintenance by the property owners benefiting from such open
space.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â When a tract being subdivided includes lands proposed to be a park site
in the Comprehensive Plan or other official plan of the City, the subdivider
shall indicate such areas on the plat.Â  Proposed park sites shall be reserved
for eighteen (18) months, giving the City or other authorized public agency the
option to purchase the land at the appraised raw land value prior to the
subdivision as established by a certified land appraiser.Â  The purchase price
shall also include one-half (1/2) of the cost for grading and paving, including
curbs, of the portion of any streets that are contiguous to the site and any
taxes and interest incurred by the subdivider between the date of reservation
and date of purchase by the public agency.Â  Should the park site not be
purchased within eighteen (18) months, the subdivider may then amend the final
plat.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Efforts shall be made to conserve natural resources and advantageously
utilize all natural features and vegetation on the property to minimize soil
erosion.Â  Consideration will be given to eliminate any form of underground or
surface water pollution.
2.Â Â Â Minimum Requirements.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Amount of Open Space Required.Â  Twenty-five percent (25%) of the tract
proposed for development shall be set aside for developed and undeveloped open
space, adjusted, as appropriate, for conditions such as population density,
existing municipal facilities, topography, socioeconomic characteristics of the
prospective population, and other appropriate site and development-specific
factors.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Size of Open Space Parcels.Â  The area of each parcel of open space
designed for active recreational purposes shall be of such size to be
functionally usable.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Location of Open Space Parcels.Â  Open space parcels shall be convenient
to the dwelling units they are intended to serve.Â  However, because of noise
generation, they shall be sited with sensitivity to surrounding development.
3.Â Â Â Improvement of Open Space Parcels.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Developed Open Space.Â  The Commission may require the installation of
recreational facilities, taking into consideration:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The character of the open space land.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The estimated age and the recreation needs of persons likely to
reside in the development.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Proximity, nature and excess capacity of existing municipal
recreation facilities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The cost of the recreational facilities.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Undeveloped Open Space.Â  As a general principle, undeveloped open space
should be left in its natural state.Â  A developer may make certain
improvements, such as the creation of trails for walking or jogging, or the
provision of picnic areas, bikeways, etc.Â  In addition, the Commission may
require a developer to make other improvements, such as removing dead or
diseased trees, thinning trees or other vegetation to encourage more desirable
growth and grading and seeding.
4.Â Â Â Exemptions to the Standards.Â  The Commission may permit minor deviations
from open space standards when it can be determined that:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The objectives underlying these standards can be met without strict
adherence to them.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Because of peculiarities in the tract of land or the facilities
proposed, it would be unreasonable to require strict adherence to these
standards.
5.Â Â Â Deed Restrictions.Â  Any lands dedicated for open space purposes shall
contain appropriate covenants and deed restrictions approved by the City
Attorney ensuring that:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The open space area will not be further subdivided in the future.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The use of the open space will continue in perpetuity for the purpose
specified.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Appropriate provisions will be made for the maintenance of the open
space.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Common, undeveloped open space shall not be turned into a commercial
enterprise admitting the general public at a fee.
6.Â Â Â Open Space Ownership.Â  The type of ownership of land dedicated for open
space purposes shall be selected by the owner, developer or subdivider, subject
to the approval of the Commission.Â  Types of ownership may include, but are not
necessarily limited to, the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The City, subject to acceptance by the City Council.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Other public jurisdictions or agencies, subject to their acceptance.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Quasi-public organizations, subject to their acceptance.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Homeowner, condominium or cooperative associations or organizations.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Shared, undivided interest by all property owners in the subdivision.
7.Â Â Â Homeowners Association.Â  If the open space is owned and maintained by a
homeowner or condominium association, the developer shall file a declaration of
covenants and restrictions that will govern the association, to be submitted
with the application for the preliminary plat approval.Â  The provisions shall
include, but are not necessarily limited to, the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The homeowners association must be established before the homes are
sold.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Membership must be mandatory for each homebuyer and any successive
buyer.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The open space restrictions must be permanent, not just for a period of
years.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The association must be responsible for liability insurance, local
taxes, and the maintenance of recreational and other facilities.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Homeowners must pay their pro rata share of the cost, and the
assessment levied by the association can become a lien on the property if
allowed in the master deed establishing the homeowners association.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The association must be able to adjust the assessment to meet changed
needs.
8.Â Â Â Maintenance of Open Space Areas.Â  The person or entity identified in
subsection 6 of this section as having the right of ownership or control over
the open space shall be responsible for its continuing upkeep and proper
maintenance.
166.19Â  LANDSCAPING STANDARDS.
Pursuant to Section 165.41 Tree Regulations, landscaping shall be provided.Â  It
shall be conceived in a total pattern throughout the site, integrating the
various elements of site design, preserving and enhancing the particular
identity of the site and creating a pleasing site character.
1.Â Â Â Topsoil Preservation.Â  Topsoil moved during the course of construction
shall be redistributed on all regraded surfaces so as to provide at least four
(4) inches of even cover to all disturbed areas of the development and shall be
stabilized by seeding or planting.
2.Â Â Â Removal of Debris.Â  All stumps and other tree parts, litter, brush, weeds,
excess or scrap building materials or other debris shall be removed from the
site and disposed of in accordance with the law.Â  No tree stumps, or portions
of tree trunks or limbs shall be buried anywhere in the development.Â  All dead
or dying trees, standing or fallen, shall be removed from the site.
3.Â Â Â Protection of Existing Plantings.Â  Maximum effort shall be made to save
significant plant specimens.Â  No material or temporary soil deposits shall be
placed within four (4) feet of shrubs or ten (10) feet of trees (unless
otherwise noted) designated on the landscape plan to be retained.Â  Protective
barriers shall be installed around each plant and/or group of plants that are
to remain on the site.Â  Barriers shall not be supported by the plants they are
protecting, but shall be self-supporting.Â  They shall be a minimum of four (4)
feet high and constructed of a durable material that will last until
construction is completed.Â  Snow fences and silt fences are examples of
acceptable barriers.
4.Â Â Â Slope Plantings.Â  Landscaping of all cuts and fills and/or terraces shall
be sufficient to prevent erosion, and all roadway slopes steeper than one (1)
foot vertically to three (3) feet horizontally shall be planted with ground
cover appropriate for the purpose and for soil conditions, water availability
and environment.
166.20Â  STREETS.
1.Â Â Â General.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The arrangement of streets shall conform to the circulation plan of the
Transportation Master Plan.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For streets not shown on the Master Plan, the arrangement shall provide
for the appropriate extension of existing streets.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Local streets shall be arranged so as to discourage through traffic and
provide for maximum privacy.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The owner, developer or subdivider shall make provisions for
continuation and extension of streets and shall be done in accordance with
current City standards.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All proposed dedications of right-of-way for streets shall be approved
in writing by the Building Official and shall conform to the requirements of
City ordinances.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The subdivider of land being subdivided shall provide the grading of
the entire street right-of-way, alley, or public place and provide appropriate
paving, including curb and gutter on all streets.Â  All streets or alleys shall
be of such width and shall be so constructed as to meet the standards of the
City, unless otherwise specified.Â  Under some circumstances, the City may
require, as a condition for approval of the final plat, dedication and
improvement of a street having a width greater or less than necessary to meet
the needs of the platted area, but necessary to complete the City street system
as it relates to both the area being platted and other areas.Â  In the event of
a greater street width, the City will pay the subdivider the difference in cost
of improving the wider street and the street width reasonable to meet the
foreseeable needs of the subdivision taken alone.Â  The streets shall, upon
final approval and acceptance by the City, become the property of the City.
2.Â Â Â Street Hierarchy.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Streets shall be classified in a street hierarchy system with design
standard relating to function, as specified by the Federal Highway
Administration Functional Classification and administered by the Iowa
Department of Transportation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The subdivider shall demonstrate to the Commissionâ€™s satisfaction that
the distribution of traffic to the proposed street system will not exceed the
ADT thresholds for that street type.
3.Â Â Â Street Standards.Â  The following standards shall apply to all streets to
be located within the subdivision:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Streets shall provide for the continuation of major thoroughfares from
adjoining platted areas and the extension of major thoroughfares into adjoining
unplatted areas.Â  Where a plat encompasses the location for a major
thoroughfare proposed in the Comprehensive Plan or the Transportation Master
Plan, the plat shall provide for such street.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Street grades shall align to existing streets and all grades for
streets shall be as approved by the City.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Major thoroughfares shall be located so as to not require direct access
from the major thoroughfares to abutting lots.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Street right-of-way widths and pavement width shall be as specified in
the Comprehensive Plan, the Transportation Master Plan or technical standards
for public improvements.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Half-streets are prohibited, except where an existing platted half-
street abuts the subdivision.Â  A platted half-street to complete the street
shall then be required.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Minor streets should be designed to discourage through traffic while
safely connecting to major thoroughfares.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-
five (125) feet are prohibited.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Streets shall intersect as nearly at right angles as possible, and no
street shall intersect any other street at less than sixty (60) degrees.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â At intersections of major streets and otherwise as necessary, lot
corners abutting the intersection shall be rounded with a radius sufficient to
provide necessary space within the right-of-way for sidewalks, traffic control
devices and other necessary improvements without encroachment onto the corner
lots.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Dead-end streets are prohibited, except where a street is planned to
continue past the subdividerâ€™s property, a temporary dead end may be allowed.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Streets which connect with other streets or loop streets are preferred
over cul-de-sacs for reasons pertaining to maintenance, fire protection and
vehicular circulation.Â  Cul-de-sacs, although permitted, shall be allowed on a
limited basis and only when the developer can show that connecting streets or
loop streets will prevent the property from being fully developed.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Dead-end alleys shall be provided with a turn-around with a minimum
right-of-way diameter of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â When a tract is subdivided into larger than normal lots or parcels,
such lots or parcels shall be so arranged as to permit the logical location and
opening of future streets and appropriate resubdivision with provision for
adequate utility connection for such resubdivision.Â  Easements for the future
openings and extensions for such streets or utilities may, at the discretion of
the Council, be made a requirement of the plat.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Streets which are, or will become, extensions of existing streets shall
be given the same name as the existing streets.Â  New street names shall not be
the same or sound similar to existing street names.Â  All street names shall be
at the approval of the Council.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â The Council may approve a private street provided adequate covenants or
other legal documents ensure that the City will not have or need to assume any
maintenance or other responsibility for such street.
4.Â Â Â Curbs and Gutters.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Curb requirements shall vary according to street hierarchy and
intensity of development in accordance with City standards.Â  Curbing may also
be required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â For storm water management.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â To stabilize pavement edge at intersections, corners and/or tight
radius curves.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â To delineate parking areas.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Ten (10) feet on each side of drainage inlets.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Where curbing is not required, some sort of edge definition and
stabilization shall be furnished for safety reasons and to prevent pavement
unraveling.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Where curbing is required, this requirement may be waived and shoulders
and/or drainage swales used when it can be shown that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Shoulders are required by State regulations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Soil or topography make the use of shoulders and/or drainage swales
preferable.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â It is in the best interest of the community to preserve its rural
character by using shoulders and/or drainage swales instead of curbs.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â At medium development intensity, the curbing requirement may be waived
where front setbacks exceed forty (40) feet and it can be demonstrated that
sufficient on-site parking exists.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Flexibility regarding curb type shall be permitted as long as the curb
type accommodates the system of drainage proposed.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Curb ramps shall be provided for all sidewalks and bikeways in
accordance with requirements of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA)
Accessibility Guidelines for Buildings and Facilities.
5.Â Â Â Shoulders.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Shoulders and/or drainage swales shall be required instead of curbs
when:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Shoulders are required by State standards.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Soil or topography make the use of shoulders and/or drainage swales
preferable.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â It is in the best interest of the community to serve its rural
character by using shoulders and/or drainage swales instead of curbs.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Shoulder requirements shall vary according to street classification and
intensity of development in accordance with City standards.
6.Â Â Â Sidewalks.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Sidewalks shall be required depending on road classification and
intensity of development.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Where sidewalks are optional, the subdivider may be required, if close
to pedestrian generators, to continue a walk on an existing street, and/or to
link areas depending on probable future development.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In conventional developments, sidewalks shall be placed in the right-
of-way, parallel to the street, unless an exception has been permitted to
preserve topographical or natural features or to provide visual interest, or
unless the applicant shows that an alternative pedestrian system provides safe
and convenient circulation.Â  In commercial and in high-density residential
areas, sidewalks may abut the curb.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In planned developments, sidewalks may be located away from the road
system to link dwelling units with other dwelling units, the street and on-site
activity centers such as parking areas and recreation and/or open space areas.Â 
They may also be required parallel to the street for safety and other reasons.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Pedestrian-way easements shall be a minimum width of ten (10) feet and
may be required by the Commission through the center of blocks greater than 700
feet long to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping or
other community facilities.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Sidewalks shall measure four (4) feet in width; wider widths may be
necessary near pedestrian generators and employment centers.Â  Where sidewalks
abut the curb and cars overhang the sidewalk, width shall be five (5) feet.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Sidewalks shall be constructed according to City standards.
7.Â Â Â Bikeways.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Separate bicycle paths shall be required only if such paths have been
specified as part of the Cityâ€™s adopted Open Space and Recreation Master Plan.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bikeways shall be constructed according to the Iowa DOT publication
titled The Iowa Statewide Recreational Trails Plan.
8.Â Â Â Utility and Shade Tree Areas.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Utilities and shade trees shall generally be located within the right-
of-way on both sides of and parallel to the street.Â  Shade trees may also be
placed outside the public right-of-way as per Section 165.41 of the Zoning
Ordinance.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Utility and shade tree areas shall be planted with grass or ground
cover, or treated with other suitable cover material.
9.Â Â Â Right-of-Way.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The right-of-way shall be measured from lot line to lot line and shall
be sufficiently wide to contain the traveled way, curbs, shoulders, sidewalks,
graded areas, utilities and shade trees (if they are placed within the right-
of-way), and bikeways.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The right-of-way width of a new street that is a continuation of an
existing street shall in no case be continued at a width less than that of the
existing street.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The right-of-way shall reflect future roadway/street development within
the subdivision.
10.Â Â Â Underground Wiring.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All electric, telephone, television and other communication lines, both
main and service connections, servicing new developments shall be provided by
underground wiring within easements or dedicated public rights-of-way,
installed in accordance with the prevailing standards and practices of the
utility or other companies providing such services.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Lots that abut existing easements or public rights-of-way where
overhead electric or telephone distribution supply lines and service
connections have previously been installed may be supplied with electric and
telephone service from those overhead lines, but the service connections from
the utilitiesâ€™ overhead lines shall be installed underground.Â  In the case of
existing overhead utilities, should a road widening, or an extension of
service, or other such condition occur as a result of the subdivision and
necessitate the replacement or relocation of such utilities, such replacement
or relocation shall be underground.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Where overhead lines are permitted as the exception, the placement and
alignment of poles shall be designed to lessen the visual impact of overhead
lines.Â  Alignments and pole locations shall be carefully routed to avoid
locations along horizons; clearing swaths through treed areas shall be avoided
by selective cutting and a staggered alignment and trees shall be planted in
open areas and at key locations to minimize the view of the poles.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Year-round screening of any utility apparatus appearing above the
surface of the ground, other than utility poles, shall be required.
11.Â Â Â Signs.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Design and placement of traffic signs shall follow Iowa Department of
Transportation (DOT) regulations.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â At least two street name signs shall be placed at each four-way street
intersection, and one at each â€œTâ€ intersection.Â  Signs shall be installed as
per City standards and free of visual obstruction.Â  The design of street name
signs shall be consistent of a style appropriate to the community and of a
uniform size and color.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Site information signs in planned developments shall follow a design
theme that is related and complementary to other elements of the overall site
design.
12.Â Â Â Block and Lot Standards.Â  The following standards shall apply to the
layout of blocks and lots in all subdivisions and, to the extent possible, in
all resubdivisions:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No residential block shall be longer than thirteen hundred (1,300) feet
measured from street line to street line.Â  The width of blocks should be
arranged so as to allow two tiers of lots, with utility and pedestrian
easements.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In blocks over seven hundred (700) feet in length, the Council may
require a public way or an easement at least ten (10) feet in width, at or near
the center of the block, for use by pedestrians and/or bicyclists.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The size and shape of blocks or lots intended for commercial or
industrial use shall be adequate to provide the use intended and to meet the
parking, loading and other requirements for such uses contained in the Zoning
Ordinance.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Lot arrangement and design shall be such that all lots will provide
satisfactory building sites, properly related to topography and surrounding
land uses.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The size and shape of all lots shall comply with all requirements of
the Zoning Ordinance for the zone in which the lot is located.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â All lots shall abut a public street or an approved private street with
a minimum frontage of sixty (60) feet measured as a straight line between the
two front lot corners, except frontage on a radius may have a minimum frontage
of not less than thirty-five (35) feet.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Unless unavoidable, lots shall not front or have direct access to major
thoroughfares.Â  Where unavoidable, lots shall be so arranged as to minimize the
number of access points.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â All lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or
radial to curved street lines, except where, in the judgment of the Council, a
variation to this provision will provide a better street and lot layout.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Corner lots shall have sufficient extra width to permit the required
front yard setback as specified in the Zoning Ordinance, oriented to either
street.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Double frontage lots shall only be permitted where abutting a major
street and a minor street, and such lots shall front only on the minor street.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Any lot to be served by a private sanitary sewage system shall have
sufficient area to allow for a satisfactory drain field.Â  No subdivision to be
served by septic systems shall be approved by the Council until percolation
tests have been performed and the results of said tests have been provided to
and reported on by the City Engineer.Â  Furthermore, no subdivision served by a
private sanitary sewage system within the Cityâ€™s jurisdiction shall be approved
by the Council unless adequate covenants and/or other legal documents ensure
that the City will not have or need to assume any maintenance or other
responsibility for such system.Â  The system shall also comply with all City,
County and State standards and specifications.
166.21Â  OFF-STREET PARKING.
1.Â Â Â Number of Spaces.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An adequate number of off-street parking spaces shall be required in
all developments to accommodate residents and visitors.Â  See Section 165.33 of
the Zoning Ordinance.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For residential developments, off-street parking shall be provided as
set forth in Section 165.33 of the Zoning Ordinance.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â For nonresidential developments, off-street parking standards shall be
provided as set forth in Section 165.33 of the Zoning Ordinance.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Alternative off-street parking standards shall be accepted if the
subdivider, developer or owner demonstrates that such standards better reflect
local conditions.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â For mixed-use developments, a shared parking approach to the provision
of off-street parking shall be permitted.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Where the total number of off-street parking spaces required is not
immediately required for a particular use, a staged development plan may be
permitted requiring that only a portion of the parking area, but not less than
sixty-five percent (65%) of the required spaces, be completed initially,
subject to the following regulations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The site plan shall clearly indicate both that portion of the
parking area to be paved initially and the total parking needed to provide the
number of spaces required.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The site plan shall provide for adequate drainage of both the
partial and total parking areas.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The portion of the parking area not to be paved initially shall be
landscaped with a ground cover to prevent erosion.Â  The ground cover shall be
appropriate for soil conditions, water availability and the environment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The subdivider shall post a performance bond reflecting the cost of
installing the additional parking facilities necessary to provide the total
number of parking spaces required.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â In lieu of a permanent certificate of occupancy, a temporary
certificate of occupancy shall be issued for a period of two (2) years.Â  Prior
to the expiration of the two-year period, the subdivider may either install the
additional parking shown on the site plan and apply for issuance of a permanent
certificate of occupancy or apply to the Commission after the use has been in
operation a minimum of eighteen (18) months for a determination as to whether
or not the initial parking area provided is adequate.Â  If the Commission
determines that the parking facility is adequate as originally constructed, the
performance guarantees shall be released and a permanent certificate of
occupancy issued.Â  If, however, the Commission determines that the partial off-
street parking area is not adequate, the subdivider shall be required to
install the additional parking facilities in accordance with the terms of the
performance bond prior to issuance of a permanent certificate of occupancy.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Any change of use on a site for which the Commission may have
approved a partial paving of off-street parking areas to a use which requires
more parking spaces than are provided on the site shall require submission of a
new site plan.
2.Â Â Â Size of Spaces.Â  See Section 165.33 of the Zoning Ordinance.
3.Â Â Â Parking Areas.Â  See Section 165.33 of the Zoning Ordinance.
166.22Â  WATER SUPPLY.
1.Â Â Â General.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All installations shall be properly connected to an approved and
functioning City water supply system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Depending on the number of housing units, residential subdivisions
shall be connected to an existing public water supply system if public service
is available.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If a public water supply system is to be provided to the area within a
six-year period as indicated in a municipal water master plan, official map or
other official document, the City may require installation of a capped system,
or dry lines (mains only) within the road right-of-way; or the City may require
a payment in lieu of the improvement.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â All proposals for new public community water supplies or extensions to
existing public water systems or the installation of dry lines or use of wells
and other water sources shall be approved by the City Engineer and meet City
standards and State specifications.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Under some circumstances, the City may require as a condition for
approval of the plat installation of a water supply system that is larger than
necessary to meet the needs of the platted area but necessary to complete the
City water supply system as it relates to both the area being platted and other
areas.Â  In such event, the City will determine the over-sizing needs and size
of pipe and pay the subdivider the difference in cost of pipe and installation
between the larger water line and the diameter of water line reasonable to meet
the foreseeable needs of the area.
2.Â Â Â Capacity.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The water supply system shall be adequate to handle the necessary flow
based on complete development.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The demand rates for all uses shall be considered in computing the
total system demand.Â  Where fire protection is provided, the system shall be
capable of providing the required fire demand plus the required domestic
demand.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The water system shall be designed to carry peak-hour flows and be
capable of delivering the peak hourly demands.
3.Â Â Â System Design and Placement.Â  System design and placement shall comply
with all City specifications and ordinances.
4.Â Â Â Alternative Private Systems for Water.Â  Where connection to the City water
system cannot reasonably be made, the City may approve alternate private
facilities for the distribution of water or the collection and disposal of
sanitary wastes.Â  Such alternate private systems shall be designed to fully
protect the public health, safety and welfare and shall meet all requirements
of State, County or other applicable health regulations.Â  Prior to granting
approval of such alternate private systems, the City shall require that the
owner and subdivider provide to the City a waiver of assessment protest or such
other legally binding documents necessary to protect the City from the expense
of the subsequent installation of water facilities.
166.23Â  SANITARY SEWERS.
1.Â Â Â General.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The subdivider of the land being platted shall make adequate provision
for the disposal of sanitary sewage from the platted area with due regard being
given to present or reasonably foreseeable needs.Â  There shall be constructed,

Cityâ€™s sanitary sewers.Â  The sanitary sewer system shall be constructed in

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Under some circumstances, the City may require as a condition for
approval of the plat installation of a sanitary sewer that is larger than
necessary to meet the needs of the platted area but necessary to complete the
City sanitary sewer system as it relates to both the area being platted and
other areas.Â  In such event, the City will determine the over-sizing needs and
size of pipe and pay the subdivider the difference in cost of pipe and
installation between the larger sewer and the diameter of sewer reasonable to
meet the foreseeable needs of the area.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All installations shall be properly connected to an approved and
functioning sanitary sewer system prior to the issuance of a certificate of
occupancy.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Depending on the number of housing units, residential subdivisions
shall be connected to an existing public sanitary sewer system if public

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If a public system is not in place or cannot be extended, the developer

Â Â Â F.Â Â Â If a public sanitary sewer system will be provided to the area within a

or â€œdry linesâ€ (mains only), within the road right-of-way; or the City may

Â Â Â G.Â Â Â All proposals for new public sanitary sewer systems, or extensions to
existing public sewer systems or the installation of â€œdry linesâ€ or the use of
subsurface disposal systems, shall be approved by the City, State or other
officially designated unit of government and meet all City standards and State
specifications.
2.Â Â Â System Design and Placement.Â  The sanitary sewer system shall be adequate
to handle the necessary flow based on complete development.Â  System design and
placement shall comply with City, State and County specifications.
166.24Â  STORM WATER MANAGEMENT.
1.Â Â Â The subdivider of land being platted shall install and construct a storm
water management system adequate to serve the area, including anticipated
extension of use to serve additional areas.Â  The storm water system shall be
constructed in accordance with the standard plans and specifications of the
City.
2.Â Â Â Under some circumstances, the City may require as a condition for approval
of the plat installation of a storm water system that is larger than necessary
to meet the needs of the platted area but necessary to complete the City storm
water system as it relates to both the area being platted and other areas.Â  In
such event, the City will pay the subdivider the difference in cost of pipe and
installation between the larger system and the system proposed to meet the
foreseeable needs of the area.
3.Â Â Â Design of the storm water management system shall be consistent with
general and specific concerns, values and standards of the City and applicable
County, regional and State storm drainage control programs.Â  Design shall be
based on environmentally sound site planning and engineering techniques.
4.Â Â Â The best available technology shall be used to minimize off-site storm
water runoff, increase on-site infiltration, encourage natural filtration
functions, simulate natural drainage systems and minimize off-site discharge of
pollutants to ground and surface water.Â  Best available technology may include
measures such as retention basins, recharge trenches, porous paving and piping,
contour terraces and swales.
166.25Â  PERFORMANCE AND MAINTENANCE MECHANISMS.
Performance and maintenance guarantees shall be provided by a variety of means
including, but not limited to, the following:
1.Â Â Â Security Bond.Â  The applicant may obtain a security bond from a surety
bonding company authorized to do business in the State.
2.Â Â Â Letter of Credit.Â  The applicant may provide an irrevocable letter of
credit from a bank or other reputable institution.
3.Â Â Â Escrow Account.Â  The applicant shall deposit cash, or other instruments
readily convertible into cash at face value, either with the municipality or in
escrow with a bank.
4.Â Â Â Property.Â  The applicant may provide as a guarantee land or other
property.
5.Â Â Â Subdivision Improvement Guarantee.Â  An applicant may provide as a
guarantee a subdivision improvement agreement between the applicant, lender and
local government.Â

167.01Â  PURPOSE.
The Site Plan Review procedure provides for special review in addition to plan
review required by other regulations and/or sections of this Code of projects
that have potentially significant effects on traffic circulation or a
significant effect on land uses in adjacent neighborhoods.Â  The procedure
provides for review and evaluation of site development features and possible
mitigation of unfavorable effects on surrounding property.Â  It is the intent
and purpose of this chapter to establish a procedure which will enable the City
to plan for and review certain proposed improvements of property within
specified zoning districts of the City in order to accomplish the following:
1.Â Â Â Promote and permit flexibility that will encourage a more creative and
imaginative approach in development and result in a more efficient, aesthetic,
desirable and economic use of land;
2.Â Â Â Provide minimal effect upon adjacent properties and existing development
(to this end, the Planning and Zoning Commission may make appropriate
requirements);
3.Â Â Â Promote development that can be conveniently, efficiently and economically
served by existing municipal utilities and services or by their logical
extension;
4.Â Â Â Provide for the enhancement of the natural setting through careful and
sensitive placement of manmade facilities and plant materials;
5.Â Â Â Encourage adequate provision for surface and subsurface drainage in order
to assure that future development of other areas of the City will be available;
6.Â Â Â Provide suitable screening of parking, truck loading, refuse disposal,
outdoor storage areas and noise from adjacent and nearby property.
167.02Â  INITIAL REVIEW PROCEDURE.
1.Â Â Â A site plan review is required whenever a person or other group wishes to
develop any tract or parcel of land within all zoning districts, except for any
detached single-family residence and two-family residences including any
accessory structure thereto; new construction of nonresidential accessory
buildings less than 1,000 square feet in gross floor area; and additions to
existing nonresidential buildings when the addition is less than ten percent
(10%) of the existing buildingâ€™s gross floor area or the addition does not
exceed one thousand (1,000) square feet, whichever is more restrictive.Â  Said
person shall cause to be prepared a site plan of such development and shall
submit nine (9) copies of said site plan to the Building Official for review.Â 
An additional seven (7) copies will be submitted at the time of review by the
Council.Â  The provisions of this section shall be applicable to the
redevelopment, enlargement or extension of any commercial or industrial uses
and structures existing as of January 1, 2003.Â  The site plan shall contain
such information and data as outlined herein.
2.Â Â Â A copy of the site plan shall be referred to the Building Official, or
such other person as shall be designated from time to time by the Council, who
shall review said site plan as to its compliance with the ordinances of the
City, its effect upon public utilities and the public street system.
3.Â Â Â Whenever any person proposes to develop any tract or parcel of land or
modify any existing development which requires a site plan submittal, a pre-
application conference is required.Â  The conference shall include the applicant
or representative, the City Building Official, and the Public Works Director.Â 
The purpose of the conference shall be to acquaint the City Staff with proposed
development and to acquaint the applicant or representative with the procedures
and with any special problems that might relate to the development.Â  The
applicant shall furnish a legal description of the property to be developed at
the time of the pre-application conference.
4.Â Â Â The Building Official shall forward a copy of the site plan to each member
of the Planning and Zoning Commission.Â  The Commission shall, after receiving
the Building Officialâ€™s report, review the site plan for conformity with the
regulations and design standards contained herein, and may confer with the
developer on changes deemed advisable in such site plan.
5.Â Â Â The Commission shall consider the site plan within thirty (30) days of the
date of submission of the site plan.
6.Â Â Â The Commission may, in its discretion, hold a public hearing on the site
plan of the proposed development and prescribe the notice thereof and to whom
such notice shall be given.
7.Â Â Â The Commission shall, upon receipt of the recommendation of the Building
Official, either approve or deny the site plan.
8.Â Â Â No building permit for any structure, for which a site plan is required,
shall be issued until the site plan has been approved as provided.
9.Â Â Â Upon final action by the Commission on any site plan, a copy of said site
plan with the action of the Commission noted thereon and signed by the
Chairperson shall be filed with the City Clerk.
10.Â Â Â If the Building Official finds that any construction or proposed
construction or occupancy of a development on a tract of land for which a site
plan has been approved will not comply with the site plan as approved, or if
the Building Official finds that the construction and development of the tract
is not being carried out in accordance with the development schedule filed with
the site plan, the Building Official shall suspend all building permits for the
development and order all construction stopped until such time as the owner of
the project, or any successors in interest, shall have provided the Building
Official with proof satisfactory to said Building Official that the site plan
will be complied with.Â  Any person aggrieved by any decision or action of the
Building Official under this subsection may appeal such action or decision to
the Board of Adjustment.
11.Â Â Â If the owner or developer of a tract of land for which a site plan has
been approved determines that an extension of time is necessary or that a
modification of the site plan would provide for a more appropriate or more
practicable development of the site, the owner or developer may apply for an
amendment of the site plan.Â  The Commission may grant an extension of time or a
modification of a previously approved site plan if it determines that such
modification of the site plan would provide for a more appropriate development
of the site.
167.03Â  DESIGN STANDARDS.
1.Â Â Â The standards of design are intended as minimum requirements so that the
general arrangement and layout of the development requiring the site plan may
be adjusted to a wide variety of circumstances.
2.Â Â Â All proposed developments for which site plans are required shall conform
to the Comprehensive Plan of the City and the provisions of the Zoning
Regulations, the Subdivision Regulations, if applicable; and all other
applicable City ordinances and statutes and regulations of the State.
3.Â Â Â The proposed development shall have such entrances and exits upon public
streets as are necessary for safety and the general welfare of the public.Â  The
development shall have such interior drives as are necessary for free movement
of emergency vehicles and shall have such pedestrian walkways as are necessary
for safety and general welfare of the public.Â  The proposed development shall
have such entrances and exits upon adjacent streets and such internal traffic
circulation pattern which will not unduly increase congestion on adjacent or
surrounding public streets or create undue hazards to traffic safety.
4.Â Â Â The proposed development shall be designed with a proper regard to
topography, surface drainage, natural drains and streams, wooded areas, and
other natural features.Â  The design of the proposed improvements shall make
adequate provisions for surface and subsurface drainage, so as not to increase
the danger of erosion, flooding, landslide or other endangerment of adjoining
or surrounding property.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The plan must provide for adequate routing of downspout discharge, sump
pump and footing drain discharge and parking lot runoff.Â  Storm water may not
be directed out driveways into the City right-of-way, except where permitted by
City.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Storm water shall be collected and piped to a storm sewer where a storm
sewer is available within three hundred (300) feet from the property line.Â  The
storm sewer systemâ€™s pipes and intakes shall be capable of conveying runoff
from a five-year recurrence interval storm from the site and tributary upstream
areas.Â  Storm water runoff calculations shall be made utilizing the Soil
Conservation Service methods as presented in Technical Release No. 55, Urban
Hydrology for Small Watersheds, Soil Conservation Service, U.S. Department of
Agriculture.Â  The Building Official may waive this requirement, provided the
area to be developed is less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet.Â  The
calculations shall be certified by an engineer, architect or landscape
architect registered in the State of Iowa and familiar with such calculations.
5.Â Â Â The proposed development shall be designed with adequate water mains,
provisions for sanitary sewage facilities, storm sewers (storm sewers to be
designed for 5-year storm calculations) and drains and flood control, in
accordance with the ordinances and regulations of the City and statutes and
regulations of the State and good engineering practice to protect the public
health and welfare and not overload any existing public utilities.Â  Storm water
drainage shall emphasize on-site storm water management or retention.Â  Storm
water detention is required for all sites larger than one acre in size, unless
it is determined by the Building Department to be unnecessary or impractical.Â 
The maximum allowable discharge rate from the storm water detention facility
will be limited to that from a five-year return frequency storm after
development of the site or to the proportionate capacity of existing downstream
sewers and drainage ways during a five-year storm which was utilized by the
runoff from the site prior to the development, whichever discharge rate is
less.Â  Storm water runoff and storm water detention facilities shall be
determined using the method prescribed in paragraph B of subsection 4 of this
section.Â  The discharge rate shall be controlled at the detention facilities
outlets and not in the storm sewer size serving the site.
6.Â Â Â The proposed development shall be designed and the buildings and
improvements located in such a manner as not to unduly diminish or impair the
use and enjoyment of adjoining or surrounding property and to such end shall
have such buffers, screen fences and landscaping as may be proper and shall
minimize the adverse effects on such adjoining property from automobile
headlights, illuminations of required perimeter yards, refuse containers, and
impairment of light and air.Â  For the purpose of this section, the term â€œuse
and enjoyment of adjoining propertyâ€ means the use and enjoyment presently
being made of such adjoining property, unless such property is vacant.Â  If
vacant, the term â€œuse and enjoyment of adjoining propertyâ€ means those uses
permitted under the zoning district in which such adjoining property is
located.
7.Â Â Â The proposed development shall not unduly increase the public danger of
fire or diminish the public safety, and shall be designed to adequately
safeguard the health, safety and general welfare of the public and of persons
residing and working in the development and in the adjoining or surrounding
property.
8.Â Â Â The proposed development and all structures therein shall be designed in
such a manner as to create a quality environment and shall be architecturally
and aesthetically harmonious and attractive.
167.04Â  SITE PLAN REQUIREMENTS.
1.Â Â Â Site plans shall be drawn on sheets no larger than 24 inches by 36
inches.Â  Where the size of the site precludes all required information from
being shown on a sheet, the Building Official may permit a larger sheet size or
an increase in scale.Â  A reduced copy of the site plan on a sheet 11 inches by
14 inches shall also be submitted.
2.Â Â Â All site plans shall be drawn at a scale not less than 1" = 50'.Â  Four (4)
copies of the site plan shall be submitted to the Building Official.Â  An
additional seven (7) copies of the site plan must be submitted at the time of
Planning Commission review.Â  The purpose of the site plan is to show all
information needed to enable the Public Works Director, Building Official, and
the Commission to determine if the proposed development meets the requirements
of the regulations.
167.05Â  INFORMATION REQUIRED.
The site plan shall include the following information concerning the proposed
development:
1.Â Â Â Name, address, and phone number of all persons having an interest in the
property including the owners, engineer, architect, landscape architect, land
surveyor or person preparing the site plan.
2.Â Â Â Legal description of property, point of compass, scale, date and revision
dates.
3.Â Â Â Applicantâ€™s name, present and proposed land use and zoning, location and
names of adjoining subdivisions, the numbers of the adjoining lots and the
names and addresses of adjoining landowners.
4.Â Â Â If the applicant is other than the legal owner, the applicantâ€™s interest
shall be stated.
167.06Â  REQUIRED ILLUSTRATIONS.
The site plan shall clearly set forth the following information concerning the
proposed development:
1.Â Â Â Property boundary lines indicated by a heavy line, dimensions and total
area of the proposed development (where possible ownership or possible boundary
problems exist, as determined by the Building Official, a property survey by a
licensed land surveyor shall be required).
2.Â Â Â Existing and proposed contour lines of the proposed development at
intervals of not more than two (2) feet (soil erosion control practices must be
shown where necessary).
3.Â Â Â The availability, location, size and capacity of existing utilities, and
of proposed utilities.
4.Â Â Â Existing and proposed utility lines and easements in accordance with the
Standard Specifications and Subdivision Regulations.
5.Â Â Â The proposed location, size, height, shape, use and architectural theme of
all buildings or structures in the proposed development.
6.Â Â Â The total square footage of building floor area, both individually and
collectively, in the proposed development.
7.Â Â Â Existing buildings, rights-of-way, street improvements, railroads,
easements, drainage courses, streams and wooded areas.
8.Â Â Â All required building setback lines.
9.Â Â Â Estimated number of employees for each proposed use where applicable and
any other information which may be necessary to determine the number of off-
street parking spaces and loading spaces required by the Zoning Regulations.
10.Â Â Â Complete traffic circulation and parking plan showing location, number,
dimensions and design of off-street parking in the proposed development,
including:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Driveways;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Islands and planters;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Striping and safety curbs;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Loading facilities;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Type and location of lighting;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Surface treatment;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Grade and direction of drainage.
11.Â Â Â Features to be considered in the proposed development shall include but
not be limited to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Open spaces and yards;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Recreation areas, wetlands, woodlands, nature areas, connection to
recreation trails and extension of greenways.
12.Â Â Â Manmade features to be considered in the landscape for the proposed
development shall include but not be limited to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Recreation areas;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Walls and fences;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Monuments and statues;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Outside lighting;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Walkways and driveways;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Signs and other manmade features.
13.Â Â Â Facilities for the collection and disposal of garbage and trash.
14.Â Â Â Location and type of all plants, grass and trees to be used in the
landscape of the proposed development.Â  Landscaping to be used for screening
purposes shall be illustrated in the elevation and perspective as well as the
plan, with the approximate size and name of plants, shrubs or trees to be
planted clearly indicated.
15.Â Â Â Location of entrances and exits from the proposed development onto public
roads, and interior drives and proposed sidewalks in the development.
16.Â Â Â Proposed drainage facilities, storm water management, retention and
provisions for flood control.
17.Â Â Â Location, height and area of all signs (directional signs, identification
signs or temporary signs) in the proposed development.
18.Â Â Â Location of existing trees six inches or larger in diameter, landslide
areas, springs and streams and other bodies of water, and any area subject to
flooding by a one hundred year storm.
19.Â Â Â A â€œVicinity Sketchâ€ at a scale of 1" = 500' or larger showing the
location of the property.
20.Â Â Â Three (3) copies of architectural elevations of all proposed buildings,
for the purpose of understanding the structures, the location of windows,
doors, overhangs, projection height, etc., and the grade relationship to floor
elevation, and the number of stories of each existing building to be retained
and of each proposed building.
21.Â Â Â Soil tests and similar information, if deemed necessary by the City
Engineer, to determine the feasibility of the proposed development.
167.07Â  EXPIRATION OF APPROVAL.
All site plan approvals shall expire and terminate one year after the date of
the Commissionâ€™s approval unless a building permit has been issued for the
construction provided for in the site plan.Â  The Commission may, upon written
request by the developer, extend the time for the issuance of a building permit
for sixty (60) days.Â  In the event the building permit for the construction
provided for in a site plan expires or is canceled, then such site plan
approval shall thereupon terminate.
167.08Â  SITE PLAN AMENDMENT.
Any approved site plan may be amended in accordance with the standards and
procedures established herein.Â  The Building Official may approve those
amendments, which are consistent both with the specific design standards and
the general design standards set out herein.Â  If the Building Official does not
approve amendments, the applicant may resubmit amendments to the Planning and
Zoning Commission.Â  Any amendments, however, shall not be made unless the prior
written approval for such amendment is obtained from the Building Official or
Planning and Zoning Commission.Â  No fees are required for an amendment.
167.09Â  APPEALS; PLAN RESUBMITTAL.
Any person, board, department or bureau aggrieved by any final decision of the
Commission or Building Official relative to a site plan may seek review by a
court of record of such decision.Â  A site plan that has been denied by the
Commission may be resubmitted by the applicant to the City Council, pursuant to
the terms of this chapter and upon payment of a $150.00 filing fee.
167.10Â  PROFESSIONAL ASSISTANCE.
The Council, the Planning and Zoning Commission or City staff may request such
professional assistance as they deem necessary to properly evaluate the site
plans as submitted.Â  The owner or developer shall reimburse the City for the
reasonable expenses incurred by the City for all contracted professional
engineering or consulting services.Â  Building permits shall not be issued until
the City is reimbursed for such expenses.
167.11Â  VIOLATION; ADDITIONAL REMEDIES.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and the imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not
excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be
required to correct or remedy such violation or defects within a reasonable
time, and when not otherwise specified, each thirty (30) days that prohibited
conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense.Â  In addition,
the City may proceed in law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such
violation, to prevent the occupancy of said building, structure or land, or to
prevent any illegal act, conduct of business or use in or about such premises.
167.12Â  FEE
Before the site plan is considered by the Commission, the developer or the
developerâ€™s agent shall pay a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a Site
Plan of one (1) acre or less, and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a
site plan on more than one (1) acre.
